story:
Update 1:

The $11 'Amigo' Perk comes with one puzzle piece to have YOUR name forever recorded on our Art Installation. On this one piece, we can write your name as you wish. For example, we can write it as "David Durica" or "family of David and Jenny Durica" or "David Durica from Irvington" or you can dedicate the piece to a loved one, such as "in honor of [name]."

If you'd like to record family names on separate pieces, you can add $10 per piece to any Perk claimed from the right. For example, if you were to claim the 'Guardian' Perk that would give you one piece to the puzzle already (as all perks include previous perks). If you add $10 at the time of payment, which in this instance for the 'Guardian' would then total $31, then we'll reserve a second piece for you with an additional name of your choosing.

We will confirm which name you wish to be displayed on the piece at the time of fulfillment of the perks (between April and June 2015).

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Need-to-Know Basics

We are David and Jenny Durica, and for the past two years we've been the Volunteer CEO's (ie Co-Founders) of Las Casas, a fair trade venture with the slogan to 'Make Life Fair.'

Las Casas is both a journey and a destination...a means and an end. Now we're launching a second initiative, called #BeReconciled. This will help ignite a stronger, more reconciled local community in Indianapolis through art and advocacy.

This campaign is meant to propel us into a full-scale operation to include the following business model components:
1) sales of retail Fair Trade merchandise
2) complemented by a restaurant cafe offering Guatemalan food and specialty drinks (coffee, teas, and juices)
3) while featuring the #BeReconciled Art Gallery and hosting #BeReconciled Educational Segments to foster community growth

Your contribution will help us acquire a storefront location in Indianapolis so we can further our mission (with those 3 components). 

The Journey

After having lived in Guatemala for a year, we grew passionate and inspired by the Mayan culture and people. We saw the need - lack of education/jobs, malnutrition, and a tragic history of oppression - for fair trade by recognizing that if people matter, then the way we trade matters.

Two years ago we invested $4,000 out of pocket to get the fair trade venture underway with inventory. Since then, that out of pocket money has enabled us to restock and reinvest over $25,000 in business development for the artisans in Guatemala.

So for these two initial start-up years we've spent our weekends setting up booths at local art shows, farmer's markets, and festivals to sell the fair trade merchandise on behalf of the artisans in Guatemala. 100% of all sales have gone back to Guatemala and attributed to the betterment of the artisans and their communities.

The need for a store is about sustainability...creating a longevity to our commitment to the artisans in Guatemala for years to come.

Now with #BeReconciled, we get to implement a $5,000 Focus2020 Community Action Grant that we received in November 2014. This project strengthens our overall mission to advocate and create sustainable and peaceful communities. With the grant, we'll visit diverse community sites throughout Indianapolis to host educational segments and facilitate dialogue to pursue various forms of reconciliation.

The result of the Grant Project will conclude in Summer of 2015 with a #BeReconciled Public Art Installation co-created by Indianapolis community members.

The Destination

Our campaign goal of $45,000 will enable us to negotiate and secure a storefront property to fulfill our mission based on the three components listed above.

With the funds, we'd increase our capacity of inventory, make a deposit for a lease, undergo building renovations, purchase furnishings, and prepare to open up shop.

Beyond the goal of $45,000, we have several STRETCH GOALS to help fund advertising and kitchen equipment to reduce any reliance on outrageous loans (as the campaign goes along, we'll post updates regarding STRETCH GOALS).

To show our gratitude, we're arranging the production of some pretty awesome perks - handmade & fair trade from Guatemala! Take a gander over this way --> --> -->

We're the kind of people who find "meaning in everything." So you'll notice that our Perk $ Amounts aren't in your typical increments. The numbers signify something, giving extra meaning to your contribution.

Once you click the 'Contribute' button on the right you'll be given the option to enter an alternate amount. You may also donate anonymously if you so choose.

Be a Piece to Our Puzzle

We're excited to develop our 'Directory of Amigos' [in reference to the 'Amigo' Perk on the right] for the showcase of our #BeReconciled Puzzle. This Art Installation will be developed as a collage based on the results of the Community Action Grant (referenced above).

The collage will be printed as a ginormous puzzle, each piece being assigned to our 'Amigo' Perk Contributors (your name will be written on a piece). Both sides of the puzzle will be visible by being secured on a plexiglass frame.  See example below.

Also, check out the 'Giver' Perk featuring 5 Seasonal Gifts great for self-use or re-gifting for the holiday seasons!

*Keep in mind that each Perk includes all previous (lesser amount) perks, too! 

The Full-Circle Impact

Because of our small-scale/low-risk approach these past 2 years, we're still just Volunteer CEO's. So help us get in a store! Your contribution to our #BeReconciled campaign makes the impact (initially from our out-of-pocket money) come around full circle! 

Your contribution is a win/win both for local communities and Guatemala! Because although we've been supporting Guatemalan communities, we'd now be able to empower our local communities right here in Indianapolis (and more broadly across the US) through our work with art, advocacy, and reconciliation.

A storefront location would give us the opportunity to be a key neighborhood establishment. It'd be a place to allow you to grow in a diverse, Guatemalan atmosphere, get more connected with artists of all kinds, and reconcile your way of life as a consumer.

Lets be a bridge to the artisans living in a completely different reality and pursue reconciliation together!

    Risks & Challenges? Check.

    The depth of our long-term goals described above may seem daunting. Afterall, we are talking about a cafe and art/gift shop business, and we've all seen the statistics of failed small businesses.

    But, first and foremost, this campaign will be measured for success based on the result/completion of the #BeReconciled Art Installation (which already has the backing of a grant). 

    Second, our success will be based on an increased capacity to expand our market for fair trade merchandise. Therefore, this is reliant on a storefront Grand Opening to give us reach into new markets. The store space would allow us to advocate and share stories through product displays, story boards, and video tributes to the artisans.

    Regardless of our campaign goal being reached, we are committed to providing contributors their chosen perk(s) because our work with the artisans is a definite commitment, not dependent on how much money is raised here.

      So...Now What?

      More than anything, we need your help spreading the word (and link) about our vision and campaign. Please commit to sharing this campaign directly and intentionally throughout your immediate network.

      As many shares and direct messages as you're comfortable with making, that's exactly how many we need! We'd love to see what kind of noise we can generate. Don't forget to use the easy share tools on this Indiegogo campaign page to post to your social media outlets!

      If you have made a contribution and chosen a perk...stay tuned. We'll post updates regarding 'fulfillment expectations.' Production of your items will begin once the campaign has ended (January 2015). Therefore, we anticipate 'perk' delivery dates at your door by June 2015 - these are coming from Guatemala ( :  For our 'Voyager' Perk Contributors, your estimated delivery timeline will vary based on your transportation schedule.

      Thank you...Muchas Gracias...Matiox (Mayan dialect for 'Thank You')...
      We are very grateful for your support!!!

      Templates to Use to Spread the Word

      1) Email your friends and family a link to the campaign:
      Hi [name of contact/group],

      I'm intentionally passing this along to you because of the way it inspired me. I thought you'd be interested in the cause. It's a fair trade venture supporting indigenous Mayan textile artisans from Guatemala, but now they're taking the next step by pursuing reconciliation through art and education.

      All contributions raised will allow them to expand their market for retail sales, while also creating a more reconciled and welcoming local community in Indianapolis. Specifically, they're proceeding with plans to open a storefront to house a fair trade gift shop, along side a #BeReconciled Art Gallery and small Guatemalan cafe.

      Check out their campaign. They're offering awesome handmade perks!

      Thanks for your consideration and support. Even if you could just forward this on to your friends and family that'd be great.

      Hope you're doing well,
      [sign name]

      2) Write a Tweet by clicking the tweet button at very top by video
      #BeReconciled @MakeLifeFair Check out this #NotYourAverage crowd-funding campaign on @indiegogo Amazing work...http://tinyurl.com/prvkw6d

      3) Post on Facebook by clicking the share button at very top by video

      #NotYourAverage campaign. Check out this fair trade venture supporting indigenous Mayan textile artisans from Guatemala. Now they're taking the next step by pursuing reconciliation through art and education.

      So many cool ways to give your support. Amazing perks are being offered!

      Just take a look...and spread the word ( :

story:
We are a small group of dedicated Burners that roam the playa PRE-EVENT providing hot hearty meals to build crews AT THEIR BUILD SITE. They are dusty, hungry and tired. We fix that by providing hot meals and icy energy drinks in a shaded space. We fed over 700 people in 2014. Help us help them.

Below are some pictures of our perks.  First is the BRC magnet/bumper sticker, also pictured are the plastic sporks (which also have Wheels on Meals imprinted on them), and of course, our stickers.  Not pictured in our wearables.  Our titanium spork is pictured above.

story:
Sssh, Krampus are sleeping...

The Krampus had a wonderful evening taking care of the naughty children (and a few adults) in Bloomington this year, with over 1,800 people lined up for the parade plus more at the Showers Bazaar and a rampage through downtown - this was our biggest turn-out yet!

Thankfully, with the restraining magic of Saint Nicholas, the Krampus are back in their lair, sleeping... for now. 


Thank you!

Bloomington Krampus Night is a labor of love with a crew of nearly a hundred volunteers working year-round donating their time, energy, materials, and skills to bring the magic alive. 

We are as creative as possible to keep our costs low, including seeking grants from the city of Bloomington - but at the end of the day, we still need funds to keep the Krampus well fed and entertained enough so their numbers can grow for next year. 

Your contribution is critical in keeping the magic going; allowing us to introduce a new group of naughty kids to Krampus next year and to create an ongoing tradition; part of what makes Bloomington such a unique and wonderful place to live.

story:
Short Summary

For your contribution BalanVino will send to you the very first, collectible piece of functional art.  Please take the time right now to invest in America business and then I'm asking you to share this with that wine lover you all know!

Pictures of Perks:

StilettoVino - Red/Blk


Bull Horn - Black Lacquer


The Original BalanVino - Paduak /Maple


RockinVino - Paduak


Reg T-shirt RockinVino on the Back


Reg T-Shirt StilettoVino on the Back


Women's Shirt - Elegant,Sexy on the front Red StilettoVino on the back as shown above.

Thank you for your support!
I have over ~20 different models of BalanVino's in my home for sometime, and the people who see them for the first time usually ask the same 3-4 questions:

FAQ's:

Q1: "You made that?                                                                                                                         A1: I designed all of them myself originally but have improved on many with the feedback from my close friends. Thank you!

Q2: How do they Balance?                                                                                                             A2: Without referencing too much physics, the weight of the bottle creates a torque in one direction while the BalanVino sculpture creates a torque in the other direction.

Q3: If you take one bottle of wine out of the RockinVino guitar, will it fall over?          A3: Yes

Q4: How did you come up with that?                                                                                         A4: For the history in further detail See Below...Else the product speaks for and sells it self - Please take the steps necessary right now to order your favorite!

The BalanVino Story...

I will try to explain in detail the story of how BalanVino came about as it seems to add clarity to those new to it.

How did you come up with that?  Balancing a bottle of wine in a flat board "Wine Tilt" is not a new idea in fact there have been may people who have created similar products for years and years.  The "Original" BalanVino design was derived from much trial and error.  A co-worker at the time had a wine tilt in his office that he had just bought, and I told him "That is no big deal, I'll go home tonight and make one way better than that!" (As I like a challenge and he didn't believe I could do it.)  I started with a cheap scrap of 2x4 and a plug-in hand drill from the 60's that my Grampa had given me.   The 2x4 was all beat up and I didn't have the right bits or tools to recreate the one I had seen, but I tried anyway. Skipping over a few hours of relearning high school shop skills and swearing at the cheapest table saw known to mankind.  I realized that with the proper tools, I could easily reproduce the wine tilt I had seen and therefore gave up on the reproduction.  I thought to myself, "How could I make one that looked like it was really going to fall over?  I found my Dad's old "Saber" saw/jigsaw and started going to town.  I made over 40-50 prototypes of different shapes and colors, trying to prove to my coworker that I could make a more unique and gravity defying wine bottle holder.

Then I went into the exotic woods, then I bought new woodworking tools, and sanders and sandpaper and lacquers and stains and disc sanders and routers( All which I still have today in my garage.)

 I ended up dropping one of the early models, and broke a chunk off, and then developed that one into the Original BalanVino.  I couldn't wait to bring it to work after it was done, as I knew it was beautiful.

I gave away all my prototypes to friends and was going to clean up the sawdust and move on, but a friend of a friend wanted not only one of them, but ordered 5, I think, and offered to pay me for them.  That is when I knew I had something.

I sold a couple hundred of that first model via word of mouth only, and was becoming very passionate about the idea of this becoming a legitimate business!

I figured out the trick on how to make new designs very quickly, and have made many many one of a kind prototypes while pecking away at creating inventory of the Original.  Some "life circumstances" happened and the business got put on back burner for a few years.

Several months ago I started making them again in my garage and realized with the help of a couple friends pushing me to start this up again, that there is still a high demand for my original designs and my passion and dream of making this a full time business became a priority again.  I again was blessed with inspiration and creativity and developed a new model that I think may be very popular to a good sized market. Collectors, Art lovers, Wine Lovers and those who can appreciate high heeled shoes! Enter the Elegant and Sexy- StilettoVino.

Everyone has a different favorite so I am offering  multiple choices for those who help me kick-start my business. I am campaigning for funds to cover some newer high end woodworking tools in order to be able to make them more efficiently, and in greater quantities with higher quality. The better response I get, the better equipment I will invest in.

Check out the rewards section for unique options that I'll give you for your help!!

It will be curious to see which perk gets to most interest. 

I'm setting a goal of $15,000 in order to cover a large raw material purchase and 4-5 machines at $2,000 each.

As soon as the orders start to come in, I will start to make and ship these. I will make and ship these first in/first out.

If the perks/contributions are slower than expected I see no major delays.

If the demand is on target I think that I can get a large percentage of the StilettoVino's done by Valentines Day 2016.

If the demand is better than expected, then I will expect all orders over the 15,000 goal to be delayed equally with a lead time TBD.

I have been preparing for all scenarios for some time now, and am not concerned about satisfying everyone to the fullest.  Any and all feedback will be shared and communicating with honesty and clarity.

Thank you for your investment in myself, in BalanVino, and in keeping this product made in America.  I am for free trade, but I firmly believe that we need to bring manufacturing jobs back to the USA to balance it out. You, the consumers can make this happen by creating demand for Made in the USA!

Mark Dieleman

Owner/President - BalanVino LLC

Then I went into the exotic woods, then I bought new woodworking tools, and sanders and sandpaper and lacquers and stains and disc sanders and routers( All which I still have today in my garage.)
 I ended up dropping one of the early models, and broke a chunk off, and then developed that one into the Original BalanVino.  I couldn't wait to bring it to work after it was done, as I knew it was beautiful.
I gave away all my prototypes to friends and was going to clean up the sawdust and move on, but a friend of a friend wanted not only one of them, but ordered 5, I think, and offered to pay me for them.  That is when I knew I had something.
I sold a couple hundred of that first model via word of mouth only, and was becoming very passionate about the idea of this becoming a legitimate business!
I figured out the trick on how to make new designs very quickly, and have made many many one of a kind prototypes while pecking away at creating inventory of the Original.  Some "life circumstances" happened and the business got put on back burner for a few years.
Several months ago I started making them again in my garage and realized with the help of a couple friends pushing me to start this up again, that there is still a high demand for my original designs and my passion and dream of making this a full time business became a priority again.  I again was blessed with inspiration and creativity and developed a new model that I think may be very popular to a good sized market. Collectors, Art lovers, Wine Lovers and those who can appreciate high heeled shoes! Enter the Elegant and Sexy- StilettoVino.
Everyone has a different favorite so I am offering  multiple choices for those who help me kick-start my business. I am campaigning for funds to cover some newer high end woodworking tools in order to be able to make them more efficiently, and in greater quantities with higher quality. The better response I get, the better equipment I will invest in.
Check out the rewards section for unique options that I'll give you for your help!!

It will be curious to see which perk gets to most interest. 
I'm setting a goal of $15,000 in order to cover a large raw material purchase and 4-5 machines at $2,000 each.
As soon as the orders start to come in, I will start to make and ship these. I will make and ship these first in/first out.
If the perks/contributions are slower than expected I see no major delays.
If the demand is on target I think that I can get a large percentage of the StilettoVino's done by Valentines Day 2016.
If the demand is better than expected, then I will expect all orders over the 15,000 goal to be delayed equally with a lead time TBD.
I have been preparing for all scenarios for some time now, and am not concerned about satisfying everyone to the fullest.  Any and all feedback will be shared and communicating with honesty and clarity.
Thank you for your investment in myself, in BalanVino, and in keeping this product made in America.  I am for free trade, but I firmly believe that we need to bring manufacturing jobs back to the USA to balance it out. You, the consumers can make this happen by creating demand for Made in the USA!
Mark Dieleman
Owner/President - BalanVino LLC

story:
For the last two and a half years, Interface Gallery has presented over twenty-four exhibitions featuring work by over fifty Bay Area artists, while offering an engaging mix of interactive projects and more traditional solo and group shows.

Funds from this campaign will primarily help support Interface Gallery in its unique practice of offering honorariums to artists for their installation labor and bringing their projects to fruition. Past exhibition honorariums range from $150-$500, with an average of $250 per exhibition, and have been given out to over twenty artists already.

My goal is to give at least $300 per exhibition this year.

In 2013, thanks to a $5000 Alternative Exposure grant through Southern Exposure, we were able to give out $800 stipends for several projects in addition to materials support. So the more I am able to raise, the more I can give back to artists!

Additionally, Interface regularly supports artists in creating prints, readers and books to accompany their exhibitions - a sampling of which are offered here as backer rewards!  To see photographs of the "perks" check out the Indiegogo Image Gallery. 


UPCOMING PROGRAMMING

In the coming year, Interface will collaborate with dancers to bring movement, performance and body into relationship with visual art practices. The gallery will also continue to highlight the work of artists who engage in experiential, interactive social-practice based projects, as well as continuing to serve as a project space for installations and more traditional solo and group shows by emerging Bay Area artists.

Please visit our website to see a complete list of our exhibitions and interactive projects.

Please help support Interface Gallery's ever strengthening programming and my commitment to providing artists with opportunities to experiment and receive a degree of financial compensation for their work.


Thanks!!

Suzanne L'Heureux
Founder and Director, Interface Gallery

story:
TALENT SHOW 2016

Ensemble, construisons un spectacle de qualité permettant aux talents de demain de se faire valoir sur une plateforme néo-musico-culturelle allumée, réceptive et amusante.

Les changements

  • Musique et animation
  • Jus et biscuits
  • Décorations festives (ballons, guirlandes, couteaux, seringues, etc)

Non-seulement ce sera fun, ce sera aussi rock'n'roll, rassurez-vous la gang, pas trop quand même. Respect sain dans un corp sain = un esprit sain et des jeux sains.

Ce dont on a besoin

16 000 $

L'impact

Une culture des jeux changée à jamais, un héritage pour le bureau de poste et un avenir rayonnant d'amour et de coopération

Pourquoi nous aider ?

Ben là, parce que l'entraide, c'est cool !

story:
Background on the Project

Site Specific Cameras combines photography and land art. We build large cameras out of materials found in the landscape and then use the cameras to photograph that landscape. If we want to photograph the forest, the camera is likely made of materials such as logs, sticks, leaves and dirt. We always use a found aperture, something with a preexisting tiny, roundish hole.  In this way the physical components of the landscape, feedback into the character of the camera and the final photograph. The cameras are also large enough for one of us to fit into. We act as the mechanical parts of the camera, like the shutter and film advance. We have spent the last few years using this process to catalogue the varied landscapes around the San Francisco Bay Area: redwood forest, oak woodlands, rocky and sandy beaches, and grasslands. We have exhibited the work extensively in the Bay Area but the project has evolved since David moved away from the Bay. Our new approach is to document specific locations via road trips throughout the US. For this journey, we are trying to raise additional money to fund a small documentary film crew to join us and help tell our story.

We have been working on this project since 2012 and have exhibited the work in places throughout the Bay Area including the Kala Art Institute, The Santa Cruz Museum of Art and History, Rock Paper Scissors Collective, and Rayko Photo Center.


Short Summary

This spring we are planning on traveling to the South West to build cameras along the Rio Grande River,  from the western panhandle of Texas through New Mexico and into southern Colorado. We are trying to raise enough money so that Matthew Brown and Mario Casillas can join us on the journey in order to record our endeavors and create a documentary film. Matthew and Mario are both artists, photographers, and film makers in their own right. Matthew has volunteered to direct the documentary with Mario acting as his sole assistant. Unfortunately, David and I can't afford to pay them for their generous efforts but we are hoping to fund their trip through this campaign so there is no out of pocket expenses for either of them.  

The Rio Grande River follows a course set by a geologic rift that began forming about 35 million years ago.  The rift valley has acted as a conduit for the movement of materials and life for thousands of years and it is fairly analogous to the rift valleys of East Africa. Within the scientific field of paleoanthropology, the most widely accepted hypothesis is that anatomically modern humans originated in East Africa. Both of these rift valleys opened up numerous ecological niches in otherwise broadly homogeneous and harsh landscapes. Humans have had a long history in both rift valleys. Early humans evolved in East Africa and the Rio Grande Valley has acted, and continues to act, as a conduit for humans moving north and south from present day Mexico and the central United States. Our goal is to document these histories and landscapes by directly interacting with environments along the valley.

 You're generous contributions will help fund the trip and the money raised will be used for airfare, travel expenses, and the materials we need to make the work. Without your help we won't be able to afford the trip.


What We Need & What You Get

Adam, Matthew, and Mario currently live in the San Francisco Bay Area and David resides in Houston, Texas. The money will help with airfare so that the trio can meet David in Texas where they will begin their drive west into New Mexico.  Money raised will be used to cover Matthew and Mario's expenses such as airfare, food, lodging and camping fees. It will also be used to purchase some gear they need to make the film such as memory cards, camera batteries, and hard drives to back up footage. Any additional money that is raised will be used by David and Adam to cover some of their own travel expenses and on the photographic materials they need like Fuji FP-100c instant film, direct positive silver gelatin paper, and x-ray film. Our goal is to only use photographic materials that create one of a kind positive processes.

We will be offering some of these unique prints to the kind people who contribute to our campaign! By contributing you can get a one of a kind print that was created with a camera built from the earth. In addition, you'll have an insider first look at the film Matthew and Mario create! 

Here's a breakdown of our estimated costs

Flights:                                                                                                                   Three Round trip flights from Oakland, CA to Houston $380 each                               Total: $1140

Car Rental: Enterprise                                                                                           Economy Car: $650

Gas: Two Cars                                                                                                       Estimated Total Drive: 819 miles                                                                                         Estimate miles per gallon: 30mpg                                                                                     Average price of gas in New Mexico: $1.50                                                                        Total: $810

Food: Four People                                                                                                         $35 per day for 14 days:                                                                                                               Total: $2000

Hard Drives: Lacie Brand                                                                                            Two 2TB: $400

Memory Cards:                                                                                                                   6 High Speed 64GB Scan Disc CF at $70 a piece                                                           Total: $420

Extra Camera Batteries:                                                                                           $400

Fuji FP100c: 30 Boxes                                                                                               $500

Hotels: Two Rooms for Seven Nights                                                                      Estimated Cost: $1400

Grand Total: $7,720


Creating Community

As artists, we believe in community, collaboration, and sharing. Creating this documentary as a product of our work allows us to demonstrate our artistic process. Our audience is a part of the process and a witness to how we all function creatively. We do not believe that creating art should be a solitary act - without support from other artists and art lovers their is little to no purpose in creating. This campaign allows us to raise money for a project we are passionate about and it also allows to reach out to more people and share our experiences and our work! By donating to our campaign you get to participate and become part of the project and our team! 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the means to contribute money to our campaign but there are other ways you can lend a hand. Help us spread the word about our project! The Indiegogo share tools are a quick and easy way to tell others about our project.

Thanks for checking out our project!

story:
Mein Vorhaben ist es, den größten Bären der Welt aus Holz zu schnitzen. Dies soll im Zeitraum März, April 2017 umgesetzt werden. 

Dafür benötige ich einen Holzklotz mit einer Grundfläche von ca. 2 x 2 Meter und einer Höhe von ca. 10 Meter, also insgesamt 40 qm3 Holz. Da es ein Schande wäre einen Baum mit solchen Ausmaßen zu fällen und es sich sowieso schwierig gestalten würde ein solches Exemplar in Deutschland oder Europa zu finden, plane ich den Holzklotz aus gehobeltem Fichten-Konstruktionsvollholz zusammen zu leimen und daraus den Bären zu schnitzen. Die Gesamtkosten für Holz, Leim, Schleif- und Betriebsstoffe für die Fertigstellung des Bären liegen ca. bei 10.000 Euro.

Nach der Fertigstellung und der Abnahme durch Guinness World Record, soll der Bär versteigert werden und die Einnahmen zu 50 Prozent an die Soeste-Schule-Barßel und zu 50 Prozent an unterschiedliche gemeinnützige Unternehmen gespendet werden. Diese 50 Prozent werden mit Hilfe einer Abstimmung durch die Crowdfunder festgelegt. 

_________________________________________________________

My plan is to carve the largest bears in the world of wood. This will be implemented in the period March, April 2017th This means I need a wooden block with an area of ​​about 2 x 2 meters and a height of about 10 meters, for a total of 40 QM3 wood. Since it would be to cut down a tree with such magnitude a shame and it would make anyway difficult to find such a specimen in Germany or Europe, I plan to chump from planed spruce construction timber to glue together and therefrom to carve the bear. The total cost of wood, glue, abrasive materials and supplies for the completion of the bear are approximately at € 10,000. Upon completion and acceptance by Guinness World Record, the bear will be auctioned and the revenue to 50 percent will be donated to the Soeste School Barßel ​​50 percent to various nonprofits. These 50 percent are determined by means of a vote by the Crowd Funder.

story:
Methuselah 

Imagine you’re walking on playa at night. The dust is whipping around your face, you take your scarf out to cover your mouth as a storm brews on the horizon. A faint orange light catches your eye in the approaching expanse. A shadow surrounds the light in the distance, a dark structure that houses curiosity within. As you approach, a massive 20 foot steel structure extends toward the sky. The backdrop of billowing dust and chaotic festival lights amplifies the stoic nature of this magnificent creature. What lies before you is, Methuselah.

Modeled after the oldest living tree in the world, this replica of the ancient 4,848 year old bristlecone pine speaks of ancestry and honor. Your weary feet find reprieve as you take your place amongst the tree’s roots on benches that seem to grow out of the desert ground. The fire which you first saw from so far away burns warmly in the heart of its trunk. Soft illumination reflects off of the large convex mirror nestled at the base of the flame and shines through the stained glass embedded in the bark. The storm dies down as you’re lulled to sleep by the tree’s soft chimes blowing in the wind and the hushed conversations of other travelers.

The sun peeks over the horizon as you stir awake. The world is perfect in this moment of absolute stillness; just the sun, yourself, and this symbol of nature. You can now see the details of the bark, the colored glass, the intricately woven pieces of swirling metal, and the depths of color created by a beautiful patina.  

The stillness dissolves as an aerialist takes position under one of the branches.  You hadn’t noticed before but Methuselah is also an enchanted performance space. She hangs a hoop and you sit mesmerized by this display of raw and passionate talent. As the performance concludes you slowly stand up. Your heart, mind, and soul are filled to the brim with the experiences you have shared with this timeless symbol of strength. You walk forth, replenished and rejuvenated. Methuselah follows in your heart, forever finding a home amongst the iconic spirits and myths who pay homage to the Earth.

This vision, this passion, this story can only be made possible with you, the traveler. Methuselah, is a symbol of resilience, honor, and ancestry that has only been able to stand the test of time with the support of an extensive root system. We now humbly ask you to be our root system; to be like the sun, soil, and rain that brings life to the real Methuselah and allow this installation, erected in her honor, to thrive. Your contributions create the unique opportunity for Majorelle Arts to bring Methuselah to our home, your home, to Burning Man 2017.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Material costs (steel and glass)
  • Flame Effects System
  • Propane Fuel
  • Patina Chemicals
  • Studio Rental
  • Transportation to and from Burning Man
  • Fundraising gifts, taxes, and fees
 

Your donations will go towards the operation, transportation, and fabrication costs of creating Methuselah.  We have already received a generous Burning Man Honorarium Grant, however, in order to ensure the safety of our aerial rig point Methuselah has had to grow larger than its original design.  Your money will help fund the purchase of the necessary thousands of pounds of steel this massive structure will require, as well as the beautiful pieces of stained glass, fuel for the heart of the tree, and transportation to the desert.

In return we are excited to offer our supporters costume Methuselah swag!  Our most unique gifts include prints and original art work created by lead artists Misha Naiman and Gray Davidson. As well as aerial, welding, flow, and dance lessons from crew members. We are especially proud of offer the Methuselah necklace, designed by Gray specifically for this campaign.  

 

Risks & Challenges

Methuselah is the biggest project this crew has ever created. One of the biggest challenges is designing and fabricating a tree that is structurally sound for aerial performance and participant safety.  We are combining the professional expertise of a local engineer with the knowledge and experience of the aerialists and architects on our crew to overcome this paramount task.  We have also enlisted the help of experienced welders who will aid and supervise in the sculpture's construction.  

Further challenges include creating a beautiful patina, complex textures, and a stunning silhouette.  Although we are a highly artistic community with an eye for design few of us have worked so intimately on projects with such large proportions and dimensions.  By simultaneously maintaining processes of design and construction we allow them to inform each other, generating our desired results. 

A final, dreadful challenge is the logistics of making a 3-ton sculpture and transporting it 600 miles. We hope to team up with other local projects to cut some of the transportation costs and have a few dedicated community members taking up the task of supporting and caring for the crew during construction and break down.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can donate money to Methuselah but there are lots of ways you can be a part of the Majorelle Arts community.  One of the most integral parts of success for this project is awareness! Telling your friends, family, and colleagues about this project in person is the best way to get people involved. We also encourage everyone to use Indiegogo's "share" feature to help spread the word about the Methuselah fundraiser on social media. Liking our Facebook page (Majorelle Arts) is the best way to get updates about whats going on with Methuselah and the team, it is also where we will publicly thank our donors. We invite everyone to stop by on playa and come say hello! You can also contact us with interest in volunteering at our Oakland studio.
story_txt:
Methuselah 
Imagine you’re walking on playa at night. The dust is whipping around your face, you take your scarf out to cover your mouth as a storm brews on the horizon. A faint orange light catches your eye in the approaching expanse. A shadow surrounds the light in the distance, a dark structure that houses curiosity within. As you approach, a massive 20 foot steel structure extends toward the sky. The backdrop of billowing dust and chaotic festival lights amplifies the stoic nature of this magnificent creature. What lies before you is, Methuselah.

Modeled after the oldest living tree in the world, this replica of the ancient 4,848 year old bristlecone pine speaks of ancestry and honor. Your weary feet find reprieve as you take your place amongst the tree’s roots on benches that seem to grow out of the desert ground. The fire which you first saw from so far away burns warmly in the heart of its trunk. Soft illumination reflects off of the large convex mirror nestled at the base of the flame and shines through the stained glass embedded in the bark. The storm dies down as you’re lulled to sleep by the tree’s soft chimes blowing in the wind and the hushed conversations of other travelers.

The sun peeks over the horizon as you stir awake. The world is perfect in this moment of absolute stillness; just the sun, yourself, and this symbol of nature. You can now see the details of the bark, the colored glass, the intricately woven pieces of swirling metal, and the depths of color created by a beautiful patina.  
The stillness dissolves as an aerialist takes position under one of the branches.  You hadn’t noticed before but Methuselah is also an enchanted performance space. She hangs a hoop and you sit mesmerized by this display of raw and passionate talent. As the performance concludes you slowly stand up. Your heart, mind, and soul are filled to the brim with the experiences you have shared with this timeless symbol of strength. You walk forth, replenished and rejuvenated. Methuselah follows in your heart, forever finding a home amongst the iconic spirits and myths who pay homage to the Earth.

This vision, this passion, this story can only be made possible with you, the traveler. Methuselah, is a symbol of resilience, honor, and ancestry that has only been able to stand the test of time with the support of an extensive root system. We now humbly ask you to be our root system; to be like the sun, soil, and rain that brings life to the real Methuselah and allow this installation, erected in her honor, to thrive. Your contributions create the unique opportunity for Majorelle Arts to bring Methuselah to our home, your home, to Burning Man 2017.  
 

What We Need & What You Get

Material costs (steel and glass)
Flame Effects System
Propane Fuel
Patina Chemicals
Studio Rental
Transportation to and from Burning Man
Fundraising gifts, taxes, and fees

As well as aerial, welding, flow, and dance lessons from crew members. We are especially proud of offer the Methuselah necklace, designed by Gray specifically for this campaign.

We hope to team up with other local projects to cut some of the transportation costs and have a few dedicated community members taking up the task of supporting and caring for the crew during construction and break down.

story:
Who Are We?

No platform exists within entertainment for the sole purpose of connecting marginalized creators to entertainment companies specifically. NAL/Nay Lilly is a platform dedicated to highlighting creators who are often silenced. The platform is available for marginalized communities to network and work cross-functionally. The platform is also open for entertainment companies to diversify their roster of employees for created content. Through obtaining this access, entertainment will be reflective of the diverse audiences’ it caters to.

Who is on the team?

We are a team of seven phenomenal women spanned out between North Carolina, Washington, DC, LA, and Wisconsin. Each of us comes from a different background and we each are looking to create community amongst marginalized creators.

What is our mission and vision?

M: Empower marginalized communities within media by fostering relationships and connecting industry professionals to diverse talent.

​V: Diversify the media industry by creating a network of the world’s creatives.

What are the objectives of NAL?

NAL has 3 meaningful objectives: to create a pipeline between marginalized communities and professional opportunities in the entertainment industry;  to foster community for members of these diverse groups; and to impact future generations of entertainers through mentorship initiatives and partnerships across the country.

Why didn’t we merge with an existing platform?

While there are other efficient professional platforms like LinkedIn and Indeed, NAL caters to a unique, and more importantly, diverse community of artists, creatives, and entertainers.  We are aware that there is a space and need for NAL, so we’re choosing to empower those communities by tailoring a platform to their specific needs.

Why is NAL unique?

NAL is the only platform within the entertainment industry that solely focuses on building bridges between marginalized creators and opportunities in the entertainment industry.  Now more than ever we recognize a need for intentional representation of these creators on and behind the camera.

story:
With so much gratitude we’re thrilled that we've reached our initial goal! You amazing people got us there in just over a week! Since we can't change the time line of 60 days to reach our goal,  we've decided to celebrate by adding more perks to the mix and create a stretch goal.

At $7,500 we will be fully covered for the Shoppe Object event. Anything that comes in above that will be added to the new equipment fund for the Tulusa studio. Jump over to the Perks and see what we've added in celebration of YOU!  Thank you much, there has been a whirlwind of good vibes flowing through the studio and we hope to make you proud to be part of our growth this year. 

xo

Sue

.........

My name is Sue Henry, I'm the founder and designer behind Tulusa, a highly-original textile brand and business where we spend our days block printing our hearts out to bring our hand-crafted goods to people who love great design.  Tulusa was born out of a desire to create products that can be passed from one generation to the next.  We emphasize that our pieces are made with love, out of beautiful materials that get better over time. We produce our goods in our Alexandria, VA studio, where we value and are inspired by our community, family, live music, nature, and travel.

Our goal is simple:  Create inspiring products that will bring joy to your home.

I’m working to further build Tulusa, and with this page I am seeking funding to realize an exciting new opportunity to show my work to a special audience.

New Opportunity:  Tulusa was recently accepted to be part of a new trade show in NYC called Shoppe Object, a carefully curated event for 175 businesses that supply goods to stores all over the world.  The design and trade show worlds are buzzing about Shoppe Object and how this show is elevating the way in which wholesale buyers interact with independent artists and makers like me.  Being chosen for the show is an honor that will put me in front of key decision makers.  Buyers from stores such as Anthropologie, Bergdorf Goodman, and ABC Carpet & Home, among others, will be attending this show to find extraordinary products for their retail spaces.

Fostering Family and Community:  Being part of Shoppe Object will create huge opportunities for Tulusa.  Rather than me reaching out individually to stores across the country (which is hard to do by myself), the stores will essentially come to me, which will allow me to spend more time in my studio creating new products, as well as having more time to be with my family.  The prospect of getting some significant orders will also allow me to hire people within my local community, a goal that is at the top of my list for 2019.

Funding Goal - $5,000:  If small, independent businesses and great design motivate you, I’d love for you to help me take this leap and continue the growth of Tulusa.  I am looking to raise $5,000 to help to pay for part of my costs to be in this special show.  Funds are needed for my booth space, display, and travel expenses.  Amounts received above the goal will go toward fulfilling orders, hiring other local makers to help with production, buying raw materials, and finding a more permanent solution for representation in the field.  We are ready to take Tulusa to the next level, and with your help I know we can!

Something Special for You:  To the right you’ll find Tulusa perks for your kind contribution.  Any and all contributions will be accepted - we are so thankful for whatever amount you feel comfortable giving.  Thank you for your support.  You're the best!

Please spread the word and share this link with anyone who loves art and design, likes to support small business, or simply has a generous heart.  I truly appreciate the effort!

Please note, products found in our SELECT A PERK list for $25-$50 contributions, will be shipped by the beginning of March.  For higher contribution levels, I will send you an email with pattern and color options and/or next steps and will have them finished in March.

Sincere Gratitude:  I want to THANK YOU for taking the time to read this and for considering your donation.  There are many worthy causes to give to and one of the things that I have been very conscious of is how, as a business, I can give back to my community.  Each year I increase the amount that I contribute, either in products, gift cards, or in personal donations. With your help, I hope to turn Tulusa into a company that can sustain not only our own growth but also the growth of our role in the community by doing good and paying it forward.

If you have any questions, I am more than happy to answer them.  Please reach out to me personally or shoot me a message here and I'll get right back to you.

All the best and happy 2019!

Sue

With your help, I hope to turn Tulusa into a company that can sustain not only our own growth but also the growth of our role in the community by doing good and paying it forward.If you have any questions, I am more than happy to answer them.  Please reach out to me personally or shoot me a message here and I'll get right back to you.All the best and happy 2019!Sue

story:
Meet Wahani Puzzles

This Indigenous-owned small business is born from a passion for Native art and a dream for representation. Wahani Puzzles will provide high-quality jigsaw puzzles featuring art by extraordinary Native artists, an affordable way to spend time with and learn about Native art while also supporting each artist. 

Meet the Founder

My name is Singer Horse Capture, I am a member of the A'aninin tribe of Northern Montana, and Wahani means together in A'aniii. I grew up in Minnesota in a family that deeply values the arts. I am starting a puzzle company to share Native art through a medium that is accessible, shareable, reuse-able, and relaxing while honoring the quality of the art itself. I am excited to provide a fun way to connect with Native art and supply a beautiful activity to enjoy at home.

My passion for Native American-made art, familiarity with Native artists, and attention to detail prepare me to create and run a business that I am very excited to share with you-- I just need some support getting it off the ground.

What I am Asking For

The first series of Wahani Puzzles will feature three puzzles of art each by a different Native artist (more on them below!). While I am personal investing a significant amount, I am asking for additional support to help with the start-up costs. Our target is $4500, which will go to:

  • Logo and branding design (by a Native designer!)
  • Manufacturing of the initial puzzle series
  • Transportation of the manufactured puzzles to Flagstaff, AZ for distribution

Be sure to "claim" a perk if you are able to contribute any funds by making your selection on the right!

Why Should You Care About Puzzles?

Are you Native.... and tired of the cheesy products that represent us in gift shops? Do you feel like everyone else regards us as a monolith? Do you longingly look at Native art and wish it was in your home-- or is that just me? Maybe you're already into puzzles but struggle to find imagery you connect to.

Maybe you aren't Native.... and want to learn more about Native art but aren't sure how. Have you ever wandered a museum gift shop, unsure if the products actually support Native people or were even created by Native people? Have you ever wanted to purchase something Native-made but were worried if it was appropriate for you to have in your home?

Well here comes Wahani Puzzles.

This business addresses the lack of respectful, affordable, at-home access to the diversity of the Indigenous art of this continent. You'll be able to sit around a table with your roommates or family piecing together a beautiful piece of art, referencing the puzzle box to learn about the artist and the history. Maybe you'll keep your puzzle all to yourself, turning to it as a relaxing activity away from the TV.

A portion of the sale of each Wahani puzzle will go to that puzzle's artist.

Learn about the artists below and why they are excited to be a part of Wahani Puzzles.

Dyani White Hawk, Sičáŋǧu Lakota​

Dyani White Hawk is a visual artist based in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Recent support for White Hawk’s work has included the 2020 Bemis Alumni Award,  2019 United States Artists Fellowship in Visual Art, 2019 Eiteljorg Fellowship for Contemporary Art, 2019 Jerome Hill Artists Fellowship, 2020 and 2019 Forecast for Public Art Grants, and 2018 Nancy Graves Grant for Visual Artists. Her work is among many public and private collections such as the Museum of Modern Art, Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, Walker Art Center, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts Museum, Denver Art Museum, Minneapolis Institute of Art and Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian. She is represented by Bockley Gallery in Minneapolis. 

Stay tuned for which of Dyani's pieces will be featured on a Wahani puzzle by following @wahanipuzzles on Instagram.

 

"There is very little, or oftentimes, no merchandise available in museum gift shops and cultural centers that is actually produced by Native people, yet there is a sizable market for culturally relevant products. Wahani Puzzles will add an exciting and unique product to a growing movement of Native entrepreneurs building small businesses to ensure that Native people are representing Native content." -Dyani White Hawk

 

Cara Romero, Chemehuevi​

Cara Romero (b. 1977, Inglewood, CA) is a contemporary fine art photographer. An enrolled citizen of the Chemehuevi Indian Tribe, Romero was raised between contrasting settings: the rural Chemehuevi reservation in Mojave Desert, CA and the urban sprawl of Houston, TX. Romero’s identity informs her photography, a blend of fine art and editorial photography, shaped by years of study and a visceral approach to representing Indigenous and non-Indigenous cultural memory, collective history, and lived experiences from a Native American female perspective.

Cara’s Wahani puzzle will feature her photograph TV Indians, 2017.

 

Kevin Pourier, Ogala Lakota

Kevin Pourier, a member of the Oglala Sioux Tribe, has been carving Buffalo horn on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota for about 20 years. Pourier is one of the only artists in the country working in the medium of incised buffalo horn. The works he produces carry forward Lakota artistic practices for creating spoons and vessels of sublime beauty from the horns of the revered animal. His carvings reveal the beauty he sees in the world around us, utilizing imagery intent on inspiring thought, growth and creating the opportunity for education.

Stay tuned for which of Kevin's pieces will be featured on a Wahani puzzle by following @wahanipuzzles on Instagram.

 

"I have my art in museums and private collections all around the world. Having my art image on a puzzle is a whole new direction I am very excited about! My art has always been about educating, understanding, and creating dialogue. It’s another avenue to educating and exposing more people to the amazing art Native artists are making today." - Kevin Pourier

 

Other Ways You Can Support Wahani

Whether or not you are able to financially contribute, there are other ways you can help:

  1. Use the "Share" button to share this campaign on your Facebook page
  2. Sign up for the Wahani Puzzle email list at www.wahanipuzzles.com
  3. Follow Wahani Puzzles on Instagram @wahanipuzzles for updates
  4. Tell your friends about Wahani Puzzles!

If you got this far, thank you for your time and support. Wahani is coming to change the puzzle game!

Whether or not you are able to financially contribute, there are other ways you can help:

Use the "Share" button to share this campaign on your Facebook page
Sign up for the Wahani Puzzle email list at www.wahanipuzzles.com

Follow Wahani Puzzles on Instagram @wahanipuzzles for updates
Tell your friends about Wahani Puzzles!

If you got this far, thank you for your time and support. Wahani is coming to change the puzzle game!

story:
Why Are We Spinning A Bicycle?

"The people of Winter, who always live in the Year One, feel that progress is less important than presence."
-The Left Hand of Darkness (Ursula LeGuin)

In today's world of constant technological advancement, we are rarely given an opportunity to take a step back, and question the motivations behind our obsession with tangible progress. Whether it's increasing factory output, making cars go faster, or constantly shrinking the size of a transistor, we as a species have this internal pressure for external improvement. Could this be an evolutionary drive to advance humankind, or could it be a form of escapism from the human condition itself?

By using an array of technological achievements in an completely functionless manner, we are attempting to create a space for people to reflect on what progress means to them both individually and to humankind as a whole. Some may simply perceive a spinning bicycle, while others may walk away with a newfound clarity of perception itself.


Why are we asking for money?

It turns out that spinning a bicycle is a bit more complicated than we initially assumed it would be. All of the money from this campaign is going towards parts used in the construction of the sculpture.

Click here for a breakdown of the budget

Call for Artists

We are currently looking for one or more volunteer artists to paint our logo on the facade of our sculpture. The canvas will be a large piece of plywood (~3' x 5') and should say "Progress" somewhere. Other than that, we are giving artistic license to whomever would like to work on this.

story:
Short Summary

Over the last decade I have been fortunate enough to create kustom art for a variety of different companies. I have worked with music events, bands, apparel and surf companies - all of which have allowed me to come up with my own ideas for art, posters, t-shirts, and accessories. These products have always been funded by the clients for which I am incredibly grateful...however, my dream is to also start producing my own Kruse merchandise.

This is were my Indiegogo project comes in. With your help, I can finally get this underway, and ideally, also get more art out into the world.

What I Need & What You Get

If you dsupport this campaign it will help fund a limited edition run of El Borracho silkscreen posters! These posters are only for this campaign and if they all go... they won't be available anywhere else. Only here, and only for the next 30 days.

Any extra funds will go toward a much needed website where I will be able to sell my art. To be straight, I am a self-taught, lowbrow artist. I just do art. And for many years now I have needed to hire someone to build a website to merchandise all the other current and upcoming Kruse designs. 

So you're probably asking yourself, "What do I get out of this?"

Let me just say that any level of support is greatly appreciated, and depending on how much you are able to contribute, you may receive any of the following:

  • Sticker packages
  • Iron-on embroidered patches
  • Borracho t-shirt 
  • Limited Edition Borracho 18" x 24" Silkscreen poster !!! (signed & numbered out of 100)
  • Giclée print of a brand new design, "Coffink" 18" x 24" poster
  • Or, all of the above!!

All will come with extra stuff!!! So you'll be stoked, no matter what you choose.

Please note ~ To make this campaign international, any support from outside the United States may be contacted regarding shipping cost. 

Sample of Borracho Surf sticker ! (included with most donations )

Borracho embroidered iron-on patches ! 

The Impact

If the Borracho Silkscreen Project is successfully funded, you will be supporting a local artist and help me pave the way to create more innovative junk to make the world a slightly more interesting place.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time...no worries.  You can help a lot just by getting the word out and sharing the link to this campaign with others who might be interested or want to be a part of something cool.

story:
Short Summary

Hello friends, family, and supporters!
 
I am a fiber artist and painter newly living in Burlington, VT after spending the last ten years in Boston. I am excited to reveal plans for some new large projects for Lauren Kenneally: Fine Art; Not-So-Fine Art.
 
The short of it: I am looking to make several whimsical, human-sized, needle-felted animal sculptures.
 
The long of it: These creatures will lovingly explore a "hipster-culture" fairytale world where commonly-loved animals do human things. An owl will strum a banjo, a vest-clad fox will squeeze an accordion, and a dapper bear will indulge in commonly-loved Vermont pass-times. The goal is for them to be a fun, engaging, relateable, and aesthetically-pleasing commentary on the culture that so many of us are a part of, (or are at least familiar with), these days. These creatures will be available for sale, and my goal is to have them on display in Vermont-based galleries. Once the first large sculpture is made, I will be submitting my work to Frog Hollow, Vermont's State Craft Center, (more information at www.froghollow.org), and Burlington City Arts.
 
This is where I turn to you, my dear community. I can't make this project come true without your support and you will be rewarded handsomely for your sweet generosity!

What I Need & What You Get

 
 What your money goes to:
 
  • Several colors of quality, local, long-staple wool roving in large quantities. (This is the expensive part.)
  • Chicken wire.
  • Large-guage wire.
  • Felting needles.
  • Any other unforeseen miscellaneous supply costs.
 
I hope to get started on these sculptures as soon as possible and my time frame for completing about four of them is roughly 4 months. I hope to turn out the first piece by the end of September. I expect each creature will cost upwards of $300 in materials to make and I hope to make at least four.
 
I have many incentives for this project, so please take a look! You can email me or send me a facebook message for the incentives that allow you to pick specifics. *I'm not sure why each prize is repeating itself several times on the site. I've tried fixing it, but it insists on showing up a whole bunch of times for each option. It should work just fine, though.*
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Let folks know about the project.
  • Send encouraging words my way.
  • Buy art from my etsy site. (www.artfulingo.etsy.com)
  • If you're in the Burlington area and have extra newspaper, chicken wire, wire cutters, or thick and malleable wire that you don't need, I'll happily accept!
  • Offer to house a finished sculpture for a period of time if they start taking over! (I prefer a cat-free household, or housed in an area away from cats...I've experienced many a felted creature cat-attack!)

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Common Ground Arts Society — or CGAS— is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to the promotion, development and advocacy of emerging Edmonton artists. We represent artists from a wide variety of genres, including: dance, theatre, music, film, creative writing, visual arts and more.

Meet our management team:

MOLLY GISELA STALEY (Executive Director)

ANDREW RITCHIE (Artistic Director)

VICTORIA MORRISON (Communications Director)

ELENA BELYEA (Found Festival Producer)                                               

BRANDON PANICCIA (Front of House Manager)                                        

SOPHIE GAREAU-BRENNAN (Volunteer Coordinator)

 

THE FOUND FESTIVAL:

This summer, we are organizing and hosting Edmonton’s second-annual Found Festival, an interdisciplinary performing arts event taking place in the Old Strathcona District from June 27-30, 2013. After our out-all-night, glam-jam Opening Gala, emerging artists across numerous disciplines will showcase their work in various unconventional site-specific — or “found” — spaces. Each event runs twice and has been uniquely tailored to Edmonton's urban landscape. Think: plays in moving cars, moonlit evening performances and dancing in the treetops!

Our artists have been working for months to create exciting, dynamic pieces that will have you running, laughing and tearing your way through one of Edmonton’s most beloved arts districts. In order to make this possible, WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Many costs are associated with creating a festival of this magnitude, but ALL DONATIONS MADE THROUGH OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN GO DIRECTLY TOWARDS PAYING OUR FESTIVAL ARTISTS! We believe artists deserve to be paid for their work, with no exceptions. However, in order to make that (as well as the festival) happen, we need outside support. Every donation really does help and even small gifts add up quickly!

 

WHO YOU CAN EXPECT TO SEE! THE FOUND FESTIVAL ARTISTS:


Ben Stevens 

Gianna Vacirca

Megan Dart

Beth Dart 

Morgan Smith

Mary Hulbert

Joel Crichton

Vince Forcier

Elena Belyea 

Lianna Makuch

Davis Levine

Hannah Gelderman

The Pigeon Breeders (Myles Bartel, Will Scott, Tyler Harland)

Anastasia Maywood

Tatiana Cheladyn

Alyson Dicey

Paula Humby

Emma Houghton

Janet Kwantes

Charlene LaPlante

Leah Metcalf

Sam Jeffery

Lindsay Roseke

Michelle Martin

Sarah McKarney

Marlee Yule

Colin Matty

Syd Gross

Ben Gordetsky

Neil Kuefler

Mark Vetsch   

Morgan Melenka

Alex Felicitas

Jonathan Kobewka

Jodi Vandkerhove 

Carrie Millar 

Kasia Niewinska 

Lindsay Eales 

Ben Fitzpatrick

Jack Accident (Tynan Boyd, Eliot Villalobos, Danny Gorham) 

The Nulls 

& MORE

***************************************************************************

We’re also offering a number of perks to make your festival experience the best it can be, as a thank you to anyone who donates! 

IF YOU CAN’T DONATE BUT ARE STILL INTERESTED IN HELPING OUT, HERE ARE A FEW THINGS YOU CAN DO!

  • Like our page on Facebook
  • Promote our Indiegogo page by posting a link to it on your Facebook or Twitter
  • Volunteer at the Found Festival! Contact Sophie at VolunteerCoordinator@CommonGroundArts.ca 
  • Promote the Common Ground Arts Society’s Facebook Group page so more people can find out about Found, as well as other upcoming CGAS events!
  • Come check out the festival when it’s going on!

story:
In December 2019 I said to the Universe

"I want to travel and somehow have it be involved with the arts."

In January 2020 Sharon DeMattia said to me "I'm going to take my art and go across the USA. Wanna come?"

"YES!! Yes I DO!!"

And so our journey has been planned. 

And I would love for you to join us via my Indiegogo campaign. 

We'll be driving a 30' toy hauler across the USA.  Stopping along the way to have the Humanoids (and us) experience all we can.

More information: http://thehumaninnerface.com/

Plus I'm planning on saying "YES" to as much as I possibly can.

Following my journey via Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/255532992100311/

Thank you for being part of this! 

I appreciate you.

story:
I believe that after a year like 2020, it is a great time to say YES to a wild new adventure!

I believe that after a year like 2020, it is a great time to say YES to doing what you've always wanted!

Will you support me as I see my dream come to life and open Wild Pines, an intentional boutique & creative space in Graeagle, CA?

Wild Pines: The Vision

On February 1, 2021, I will be loading up everything I own in Waterbury, VT, and following my heart to Graeagle, CA to start a new adventure. I am opening a retail shop and creative space formerly known as Ecocentric that I’ve lovingly named Wild Pines. 

Wild Pines is the culmination of my favorite things: Art, nature, intentional living, adventure, and great earrings! It is more than a store. It is a place to gather, connect, learn, and find inspiration. Building on the legacy of EcoCentric, Wild Pines will continue to be a women-owned business, providing local and global products created with integrity and purpose. As an artist myself, I am excited to expand the number of local artisans and innovative makers that we carry. I am also over the moon to have my own studio space in the shop so visitors can see my process of making up-cycled jewelry and more! In addition, Wild Pines will also be carrying a new selection of items that are unique and useful while adventuring in the Lost Sierra and beyond. 

In the future, I plan to host classes, workshops, and small events in the outdoor space behind the shop. I will be offering art classes and inviting local craftspeople and naturalists to come and share their knowledge. These programs will provide a chance to connect Plumas County residents and enhance the experience of visitors to the Lost Sierra. 

As people migrate out of cities & reconnect their lives to the more intentional living found in small towns, Graeagle is poised to see greater numbers of new residents and tourists alike.  Wild Pines has an awesome opportunity to help shape the trajectory of the Graeagle community. Right now seems like the perfect time to be opening a shop in the heart of this magical mountain town!

Wild Pines: What we need to get there

I am basically starting from scratch, and until this summer, was not planning on becoming a retail shop owner, so I need to raise a significant amount of money, plain and simple. I’ve already pulled together a number of pieces to create a workable financing package, but more is needed, which is why I’m reaching out to friends, family, and community members to assist. Please help me get the word out by sharing my campaign through your various social networks, and please pledge whatever amount you can afford. One of the most common reasons that small business startups struggle is due to undercapitalization and I am determined to avoid that! My goal is to raise $8,000 through this campaign which is less than a fourth of what I ultimately need to help with the following costs:

  • Infrastructure and hardware: Although I plan on staying on the frugal side, I do want to give the space a fresh look and feel. Computers/Point of Sale upgrades, a phone, some new fixtures, efficient lighting upgrades, and an updated exterior space--are all at the top of my list.
  • Inventory: Hands down my biggest expense. While the retail space is not huge, it does require a healthy amount of inventory to be full. Because I’m a start-up, I need money upfront to get products from vendors and craftspeople. 
  • Turning the lights on: Rent, insurance, utilities, all go into effect before the store opens in April. 
  • Emergency Fund: Unexpected costs are a given, so I need to make sure I have money set aside to cover them if and when they come up.

Even the smallest contribution of $5 will help me achieve this goal. In fact, if every one of my Facebook friends gave $5 — I would meet my goal! If you can't give financially, I totally understand, and still love you. You might consider sharing this project on your Facebook or Twitter accounts to help spread the word. I am also always open to accepting words of encouragement, a high five, or a (virtual) hug.

Wild Pines: The Back Story

I grew up on the East Coast but I have been in love with California’s Sierra Mountains, specifically the last northern stretch known as the Lost Sierra since I first visited in 2010. I will never forget the first time I saw the Sierra Buttes. The snow-capped peaks hovered gracefully over the sleepy town of Sierra City and I was awestruck. I knew immediately that this was a place that I would call home. 

For the past 7 years, I have been an artist and art teacher in New England and have returned to California every summer to rejuvenate my soul, explore the dusty trails and pristine waters, and to visit with the wonderful people that always make me feel welcome in the Lost Sierra. Over that time, I have developed strong relationships with many community members and businesses. One very special friendship grew with business owner and kindred spirit - Linda Breedlove, of Ecocentric. Linda and her business partner, Nelda, became dear friends whom I would visit regularly at Ecocentric. I loved shopping at the beautiful store which always carried the most unique and desirable goods for conscious living. Ecocentric was the first retail shop to carry my upcycled bicycle tube earrings and has always been a place where I felt I belonged. I even spent a summer working in the shop with them. 

After an abrupt series of life-altering events this summer, including the passing of my mother Cathy, it was proposed that I would become the new owner of Ecocentric. While this was not an opportunity that I foresaw (or was financially planning for), it was an immediate YES from me. Since the day the offer was presented, I knew that my mom was encouraging me to pursue this amazing adventure. I am absolutely thrilled to bring my passion for art, community, sustainability, and the Lost Sierra to a reinvention of Ecocentric, now named, Wild Pines.

Wild Pines: We Got This!

I am devoted to this new venture and am grateful for all of the support that I have received. The invaluable knowledge I have gained from working with a business consultant, the California Small Business Association, a lawyer, an accountant, and a creative team has given me great confidence in moving forward. Now I’m asking YOU to join me in assuring the financial success of Wild Pines. 

Thank you from the bottom of my heart for supporting my ambitious dream to make Wild Pines an anchor business in the Lost Sierra community.
