One of the most common reasons that small business startups struggle is due to undercapitalization and I am determined to avoid that! My goal is to raise $8,000 through this campaign which is less than a fourth of what I ultimately need to help with the following costs:

Infrastructure and hardware: Although I plan on staying on the frugal side, I do want to give the space a fresh look and feel. Computers/Point of Sale upgrades, a phone, some new fixtures, efficient lighting upgrades, and an updated exterior space--are all at the top of my list.

Inventory: Hands down my biggest expense. While the retail space is not huge, it does require a healthy amount of inventory to be full. Because I’m a start-up, I need money upfront to get products from vendors and craftspeople. 

Turning the lights on: Rent, insurance, utilities, all go into effect before the store opens in April. 

Emergency Fund: Unexpected costs are a given, so I need to make sure I have money set aside to cover them if and when they come up.
Even the smallest contribution of $5 will help me achieve this goal. In fact, if every one of my Facebook friends gave $5 — I would meet my goal! If you can't give financially, I totally understand, and still love you. You might consider sharing this project on your Facebook or Twitter accounts to help spread the word. I am also always open to accepting words of encouragement, a high five, or a (virtual) hug.Wild Pines: The Back StoryI grew up on the East Coast but I have been in love with California’s Sierra Mountains, specifically the last northern stretch known as the Lost Sierra since I first visited in 2010. I will never forget the first time I saw the Sierra Buttes. The snow-capped peaks hovered gracefully over the sleepy town of Sierra City and I was awestruck. I knew immediately that this was a place that I would call home. For the past 7 years, I have been an artist and art teacher in New England and have returned to California every summer to rejuvenate my soul, explore the dusty trails and pristine waters, and to visit with the wonderful people that always make me feel welcome in the Lost Sierra. Over that time, I have developed strong relationships with many community members and businesses. One very special friendship grew with business owner and kindred spirit - Linda Breedlove, of Ecocentric. Linda and her business partner, Nelda, became dear friends whom I would visit regularly at Ecocentric. I loved shopping at the beautiful store which always carried the most unique and desirable goods for conscious living. Ecocentric was the first retail shop to carry my upcycled bicycle tube earrings and has always been a place where I felt I belonged. I even spent a summer working in the shop with them. After an abrupt series of life-altering events this summer, including the passing of my mother Cathy, it was proposed that I would become the new owner of Ecocentric. While this was not an opportunity that I foresaw (or was financially planning for), it was an immediate YES from me. Since the day the offer was presented, I knew that my mom was encouraging me to pursue this amazing adventure. I am absolutely thrilled to bring my passion for art, community, sustainability, and the Lost Sierra to a reinvention of Ecocentric, now named, Wild Pines.Wild Pines: We Got This!I am devoted to this new venture and am grateful for all of the support that I have received. The invaluable knowledge I have gained from working with a business consultant, the California Small Business Association, a lawyer, an accountant, and a creative team has given me great confidence in moving forward. Now I’m asking YOU to join me in assuring the financial success of Wild Pines. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for supporting my ambitious dream to make Wild Pines an anchor business in the Lost Sierra community.

story:
I'm Kit Stevens and I've just launched my own company as an artist and illustrator in Ramsgate, Kent, UK.

I studied Graphic Design, Illustration at the University of Plymouth, Devon a few years back. Life took a different tack but now I’m back on course and gradually planning, working hard and achieving my goals.

Greetings Cards

I am a versatile practitioner and to keep my business buoyant I want to develop a number of different product areas in order to reach as large a sustainable audience as possible, and my next goal, which is very dear to my heart, is to launch my first series of Greetings Cards.

I'm always on the hunt for beautifully designed cards and enjoy them as works of art in their own right, adding colour, beauty and fun to my day, and so being able to contribute my own work to this wonderful British tradition would be a great pleasure and a vital contribution to my monthly income.

Costs

I've estimated, based on 2 and a half day’s work, print costs for 500 cards per design and materials, that I need an average of £450 for each of the eight card designs, that's a total of £3600. Each card will be professionally printed and presented in a high quality envelope and cellophane wrap.

I cannot do this without you. Sadly I have no financial backing for my business so I'm relying on this campaign to make this first step possible.

Perks

Each £5 you contribute will earn you one greetings card of your choice from my website, www.kitstevensdesigns.co.uk (when they have been produced and printed), or the value of it against one of my bespoke portraits, within the next calendar year.  You will need to pay P&P and any shipping costs. I am keeping a spreadsheet tally of who has earned what throughout the campaign, so when you come to claim your perk, just let me know and I can check you against the list. :)

This should give me sufficient surplus cards to sell and make enough money to pay for the next set of designs and their print run, thus getting this side of my business up and running under it’s own steam.

I have a wonderful variety of card designs planned, some depicting the fabulous wildlife and unique landscapes of my beloved Britain and some celebrating the quirky way we live and enjoy our lives, from walking our dogs, growing prize tomatoes, the tradition of burying dad in the sand up to his nose and toes on a day at the beach and our insatiable love of amateur dramatics. Each few months will herald another series of seasonal delights seen through my own brand of admiration and gentle humour, so there’s no need to spend all your vouchers at once, you’ll want to keep coming back for more! My first two sets of four cards will have a winter wildlife and winter celebrations theme to them to catch the local seasonal markets and fairs.

If we don’t reach the full total of £3600 once Indiegogo have taken their cut, I’ll tailor the project to give you the best balance of design choices with the funds we have available, so we will still be able to move forward. In the worse-case scenario where we don’t get enough to pay for the first print run then you can redeem the value of your number of allotted cards against one of my portraits (£2.75 for every £5 donated).

My extensive circle of friends and family have been wonderfully supportive in my decision to give up the office job and put my talents to better use. I am going from strength to strength and this will be a wonderful addition to my business.

Together we can make this happen so please be as generous as you can and spread the word as far as you can, (the Indiegogo share tools will help you) and I’ll give you treasures you can enjoy forever.

story:
Short Summary

"Anna" is directed by Elizabeth Yonin-Eldridge and produced by Caitlin Docking, who come from a combined theatre and film background, and have an interest in making film from feminist perspectives that are not often brought to the screen.  "Anna" is crewed by a team of up and coming Vancouver filmmakers,  all of whom are currently enrolled in the Motion Picture Arts program at Capilano University.  It presents sex workers as real people with stories to tell.

Funds are needed to get "Anna" off its feet.  Your contribution will go towards costs such as locations, set decoration, transportation, equipment, and feeding the hardworking cast and crew.

For donations in increments of $100, 10% of each hundred will be donated to WISH Drop-in Centre, a Vancouver-based organization that offers care and services to street-based sex workers.  (http://wish-vancouver.net)

So if you donate $200, $20 of your donation will go to WISH!

NOTE: We are so close to reaching out goal and are humbled and amazed by the short amount of time it took to get us there. We would love to encourage people to keep contributing once we reach our goal - we set our campaign to the bare minimum as we thought it would be difficult to raise funds for this project! More funds would mean more money for art and lighting, funding for post production and festival submissions, and of course, more snacks for the crew!

story:
OUR MISSION

  • Like Anansi the Spider, a trickster god in West African and Caribbean folklore, he represents creativity, storytelling, and knowledge which are all the elements this journal embodies. We publish short stories, poetry, art and essays from creative of color across the world, gathering knowledge and creative storytelling into one book. Volume I. Help us fuel this dream so that we may hold a copy in our palms one day!

HOW WE CAME TO BE

  • Created by womanist writer Veronica Elizabeth Thomas, we wanted to create a place where creatives of color could confidently submit their work to a journal crafted just for them.

  • As someone who would submit to various literary journals and magazines, Veronica found rejection from publications tiresome, as she felt they weren't understanding the gravity of her work. This project is a love letter to all writers and artist of color who are lost and looking for a homeplace for their work!
  • Helping us achieve our goal or in-print journals will help us expand and get our names out there! Most importantly, it will allow us to cultivate more funds to pay contributors in the future (hopefully for Volume II!)

HOW WE'LL DO IT

  • The funds will go in several directions. First, we'll pay for our website to own our domain, upload HD content, SEO and other premium content: (300)

  • The print journal itself: (700)

  • Merchandise (notebooks, t-shirts, totes) : (1,000)

  • Event hosting + planning: (500)

  • Indiegogo's 5% user fee.

  • All leftover fees will go towards creating the Volume II!

WHAT YOU GET

  • Volume I pre-order!

  • A Special Thanks. We'll give you a special thanks with your full name to express our gratitude to your contribution in our first volume.

OUR IMPACT

  • We've already had submissions from creatives from Trinidad to Canada to New York. With your help, we can continue to grow and connect with emerging creatives of color all over the world!
  • We also plan to host events and socials so that we can build personal relationships with the artists and writers submitting to our journal.

RISKS + CHALLENGES

Even if we do not receive all of the funding, we'll still work on our website and Instagram to continually engage with emerging POC and QPOC creatives.

Even if we do not reach our goal, we will still take any funding we've raised and put it into our first Volume. This is our dream and we'll stop at nothing to hold one in our hands!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP 

Help us get the word out! Use the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Tell your friends, family, co-workers, and peers! We're here for you!
  • Best of all, SUBMIT to our journal! Read the submission guidelines on our website!

https://callandresponsejou.wixsite.com/candr/su...

story:
A bit of context

Old people – PAH! Grumpy, moaning, ‘in our day ...’, slow, get in the way, ‘in the good old days ...’, a drain on resources ....

NOT SO.

In March of last year we embarked on our first serious arts and cultural programme with older people ... and it’s been a revelation. Energy, enthusiasm, commitment, creativity, passion, drive, humour – all there in boundless supply. It went so well and everyone enjoyed it so much that we’re proposing FURTIVE ARTS – our next big idea and our first foray into the world of crowdfunding.

We aim to bring older people out from shadows and into the heart of the community – in a very real yet undercover way – to make passers-by smile, younger people curious, visitors intrigued ... and the community proud of the contribution of its older members.

Oh – and we should say that we’re based in Belfast ... on the iconic Shankill Road. Once bustling and the place to be and to shop, it’s been battered by economic, political and urban redevelopment pressures. But now it’s fighting back by embracing the new spirit of Northern Ireland and re-connecting with the old spirit of the Shankill.

What we have planned

We’ll run 4 workshops, each lasting for 4 weeks, with 4 different groups. The workshops will cover knitting, crochet, photography, and ceramics and will be led by an experienced and age-sensitive artist. Older participants will be supported to create pieces of artwork. There will be a relatively blank canvas to allow for creativity and freedom of expression.

Completed works (quilts, ‘oldie Selfies’, plant pots) will then be furtively placed in very public locations for the whole community to enjoy before older people ‘confess’ to being responsible!

What we need

We need £3850 to run the 16 week project. This will fund artists, materials, venues, and help us record and evaluate the project.

In return we offer the chance to grab some unique rewards – as Housing Associations or Sheltered Accommodation to get some arts and crafts workshops and materials; as companies to roll back the years and have a tea trolley visit your base; and as an individual own a limited edition, uniquely designed (thanks Trisha Campbell) badge, window cling or mug!

If we don’t reach our target all funds used will go on workshops with older people and people living with dementia – we might need to scale back but we’ll still deliver!!

What we hope to achieve

For the older people and people living with dementia who will participate in the workshops we offer the opportunity to come together and socialise, be creative, learn new skills, feel good about themselves, reminisce, and find a vital place again within their community. .

For the artists involved – to hone their skills and techniques, work sensitively with older people, and facilitate great creativity and expression.

For us at Spectrum – to work with older people from a range of different settings - residential homes, sheltered accommodation, supported housing, day centres; improve our understanding of the needs of older people and people living with dementia; to bring art to the heart of the community; and to get ideas and suggestions for our next phase of work.

And for our community – foster intergenerational respect; appreciate the creativity and positive contribution of older people; and love that the artwork will brighten and enhance public spaces.

The bigger picture

And we’re already thinking ahead with big, bold and ambitious plans for a 12 month programme of arts and cultural activity, with 5 partner organisations, and a social entrepreneurial twist of training older people to become community artists and for their art work to be regularly available at the local artisan market – so we might be back.

PS

If you can’t contribute hard cash you can still show your support – just help us get our message out to as wide an audience as possible.

So feel free to post, text, tweet, email ... or just even have an old-fashioned chat!!

THANK YOU!!!

story:
The Dream!

I'm just some guy who wants to start tattooing. My name is Aaron, and I've always wanted to be able to support myself with my artistic endeavors. I've loved tattoos as long as I can remember, and I've had the tattoos that I wanted mapped out since 5th grade (thankfully I never did get those 90's flame wristbands). I'm currently serving in the United States Air Force, but after a chance encounter with the great Heath Thomas (owner and operator or Florida Unique Tattoos) while he was tattooing my wife's forearm, he encouraged me to bring in my portfolio after I expressed how much I loved tattoos and wish I could get into the industry. Fast forward, and here I am in my apprenticeship, ready to make my initial gear purchase so I can start working on REAL LIVE SKIN! I am overjoyed that I've made it through my apprenticeship far enough to start tattooing people, however, I am met with one problem: Holy crap, all of this gear is expensive.

****Check out these god-awful portraits I'll do for $15. Embarrass your friends, confuse your coworkers, TRICK YOUR FAMILY! Terrible portraits in digital format for whatever purpose you may have!!****

(This is one of the designs that will be featured in the sticker set!)

I realize that I could reasonably save the money needed to get started, but it would take much longer than if I received some financial help. I only have one year left in the Air Force and I need to get started tattooing as soon as possible to prove to my wife and myself that I can support us with my art. This said, the sooner I can get my equipment, the sooner I can begin tattooing and improving, the sooner I can develop awesome loyal clients, the sooner I can begin transitioning to life as a civilian who makes his money in the amazingly awesome career field of tattoos! Your donations will directly contribute to me living out something I once thought was only a half-baked daydream.

The Tools (and Perks!)

I need $2,200 in order to get my initial set up rolling to include:

- Tattoo machines (one liner, one shader) - $800

- Power supply, clip cord, needles, tubes/grips, inks - $500+

- Storage chest - $400

- Arm rest - $40

- Mayo stand - $100

This all totals to $1,840. The remaining $360 will be used to cover shipping costs, and if there is enough, I will purchase additional needles, tubes/grips, and inks (my current ink purchase plan is only for sample sizes, ink is super expensive!).

The absolute bare minimum that I need to get started is approximately $1,500 to cover the costs of my machines, power supply, clip cord, needles, tubes/grips, inks and the shipping costs associated with all of it.

In exchange for your support, there is a collection of awesome things that you can get in return! These include:

- A poem (written from the bottom of my heart), a terrible photo of me that you can use for the purpose of blackmail at a later date, stickers with my original art on them, high quality digital prints of my orginal art, wood cut prints of my original art (I'll make each of these prints by hand with ink and wood... I think that's pretty neat, but I'm also a nerd), and a custom ink and watercolor portrait of you. Also, if you bankroll the whole thing, you'll get all of the before mentioned perks, a hand-written letter of gratitude, and a large canvas painting of subject matter of your choosing.

(This will also be one of the designs featured in the sticker set!)

(**details of perks explained in the perks section**) 

The Impact

I don't intend to stop at tattooing. I intend to go to school for a fine arts degree and eventually work my way to teaching as well as tattooing. I would love to teach both at a college level and at a community level. I want children and young adults who don't have the finances to get training to have an opportunity to get that training along with a wealth of free resources so they can tell their story through art. Tattooing can help me pay the bills and continue to hone my artistic abilities while I'm gaining an education.

I love tattoos and I want to help people express themselves and be closer to how they see themselves. I want to help people remember their loved ones through living art. I want to help people remind themselves to be better. I want to help people look down at their arm and smile at a piece that they got just because they thought it was cool or funny. I want to achieve self actualization by helping others do the same.

Your contributions will help me get started down a path where I can hopefully help people through art. 

The Struggle is Real

 There is always a chance that I don't make it through the remainder of my apprenticeship. Family problems, suddenly getting deployed, or simply just not being good at inking people, etc. There are any number of things that could interfere. I've already had to overcome several obstacles regarding just having time to balance working for the Air Force, apprenticing, and trying to make sure that I'm being a good husband who takes care of his wife and keeps her happy. There are some things that you just can't account for, and that's something that I have to continue to be aware of, but I intend to continue hard charging until I make it and become a full fledged tattoo artist.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you contribute financially, there are a few ways that you can contribute with no cost to you.

Please share this indiegogo campaign where ever you can!

Exposure is huge! If you could follow my instagram and encourage others to do the same, that'll help me spread my art and potentially develop a wider customer base. My username is: @yuhizzle

(This is the design for the print for the perks!)

Also, in the vein of exposure, if you could like Florida Unique Tattoos on Facebook. If the shop is doing well, I'm doing well. https://www.facebook.com/F.U.Tattoos

Thank you so much for taking time to read all of this, and if you choose/are able to support, I look forward to sending you some sweet goodies! Thank you, thank you!

Please share my ad if you'd like to help me get some visibility!

great Heath Thomas (owner and operator or Florida Unique Tattoos)
while he was tattooing my wife's forearm, he encouraged me to bring
in my portfolio after I expressed how much I loved tattoos and wish I
could get into the industry. Fast forward, and here I am in my
apprenticeship, ready to make my initial gear purchase so I can start
working on REAL LIVE SKIN! I am overjoyed that I've made it through
my apprenticeship far enough to start tattooing people, however, I am
met with one problem: Holy crap, all of this gear is expensive.****Check out these god-awful portraits I'll do for $15. Embarrass your friends, confuse your coworkers, TRICK YOUR FAMILY! Terrible portraits in digital format for whatever purpose you may have!!****(This is one of the designs that will be featured in the sticker set!)
I
realize that I could reasonably save the money needed to get started,
but it would take much longer than if I received some financial help.
I only have one year left in the Air Force and I need to get started
tattooing as soon as possible to prove to my wife and myself that I
can support us with my art. This said, the sooner I can get my
equipment, the sooner I can begin tattooing and improving, the sooner
I can develop awesome loyal clients, the sooner I can begin
transitioning to life as a civilian who makes his money in the
amazingly awesome career field of tattoos! Your donations will
directly contribute to me living out something I once thought was
only a half-baked daydream.
The
Tools (and Perks!)

I
need $2,200 in order to get my initial set up rolling to include:
-
Tattoo machines (one liner, one shader) - $800
-
Power supply, clip cord, needles, tubes/grips, inks - $500+ 

-
Storage chest - $400
-
Arm rest - $40
-
Mayo stand - $100
This
all totals to $1,840. The remaining $360 will be used to cover
shipping costs, and if there is enough, I will purchase additional
needles, tubes/grips, and inks (my current ink purchase plan is only
for sample sizes, ink is super expensive!).
The
absolute bare minimum that I need to get started is approximately
$1,500 to cover the costs of my machines, power supply, clip cord,
needles, tubes/grips, inks and the shipping costs associated with all
of it.
In
exchange for your support, there is a collection of awesome things
that you can get in return! These include:
-
A poem (written from the bottom of my heart), a terrible photo of me
that you can use for the purpose of blackmail at a later date,
stickers with my original art on them, high quality digital prints of
my orginal art, wood cut prints of my original art (I'll make each of
these prints by hand with ink and wood... I think that's pretty neat,
but I'm also a nerd), and a custom ink and watercolor portrait of
you. Also, if you bankroll the whole thing, you'll get all of the
before mentioned perks, a hand-written letter of gratitude, and a
large canvas painting of subject matter of your choosing. 


(This will also be one of the designs featured in the sticker set!)(**details
of perks explained in the perks section**) 
The
Impact

I
don't intend to stop at tattooing. I intend to go to school for a
fine arts degree and eventually work my way to teaching as well as
tattooing. I would love to teach both at a college level and at a
community level. I want children and young adults who don't have the
finances to get training to have an opportunity to get that training
along with a wealth of free resources so they can tell their story
through art. Tattooing can help me pay the bills and continue to hone
my artistic abilities while I'm gaining an education.
I
love tattoos and I want to help people express themselves and be
closer to how they see themselves. I want to help people remember
their loved ones through living art. I want to help people remind
themselves to be better. I want to help people look down at their arm
and smile at a piece that they got just because they thought it was
cool or funny. I want to achieve self actualization by helping others
do the same.
Your
contributions will help me get started down a path where I can
hopefully help people through art. 
The
Struggle is Real
 There
is always a chance that I don't make it through the remainder of my
apprenticeship. Family problems, suddenly getting deployed, or simply
just not being good at inking people, etc. There are any number of
things that could interfere. I've already had to overcome several
obstacles regarding just having time to balance working for the Air
Force, apprenticing, and trying to make sure that I'm being a good
husband who takes care of his wife and keeps her happy. There are
some things that you just can't account for, and that's something
that I have to continue to be aware of, but I intend to continue hard
charging until I make it and become a full fledged tattoo artist.
Other
Ways You Can Help

Whether
or not you contribute financially, there are a few ways that you can
contribute with no cost to you.
Please
share this indiegogo campaign where ever you can!
Exposure
is huge! If you could follow my instagram and encourage others to do
the same, that'll help me spread my art and potentially develop a
wider customer base. My username is: @yuhizzle(This is the design for the print for the perks!)Also,
in the vein of exposure, if you could like Florida Unique Tattoos on
Facebook. If the shop is doing well, I'm doing well.
https://www.facebook.com/F.U.Tattoos
Thank
you so much for taking time to read all of this, and if you
choose/are able to support, I look forward to sending you some sweet
goodies! Thank you, thank you!

Please share my ad if you'd like to help me get some visibility!

story:
Our Story

The (505) FACES project set out to create a beautiful, insightful collection of photographs and personal profiles of the people of New Mexico.  Traveling to 20 cities in every part of the state, we amassed a comprehensive collection of photography and interviews.  These portraits and stories explore the Land of Enchantment in a way that has never been done before.  Through each unique face and every individual story, we discover more about what makes New Mexico so distinct and special  --  it's people.

Now with your help, we are looking to publish a book of the work.


What We Need & What You Get

Publishing a book is no easy feat.  To make this possible we will need to sell 150 copies at $60/book.   If we are able to achieve this figure we will raise the $9000 dollars that will make it possible to print, bind and package the final version of New Mexico: Portraits & Profiles the way that we envision it.

The book itself is going to be beautiful.  For your contribution you will get an 8.5" X 11", Smyth sewn, black linen, hard bound book with a full color dust jacket, printed on 100# Velvet Text paper.   It will be a full on, fine art book with over 130 pages entirely produced and printed locally in New Mexico, by New Mexicans. 


The Impact

The (505) Faces project set out to create a lasting work for the people of New Mexico.  If we are able to take this final step and produce a printed and bound collection of the work, we feel that will have fulfilled our ultimate goal.  We hope that New Mexico: Portraits & Profiles is not only a meaningful look at us as New Mexicans today , but that the book itself will live on.  We hope that future generations will be able to pick up this beautiful book and peer into what it was like then.  Maybe we're just romantic, but we want this thing to be a part of New Mexico's history.

Did we mention that this has been an entirely locally-sourced, statewide, massive art project made entirely possible by the community?  We think that's pretty cool too.


    Risks & Challenges

    We were ambitious, very ambitious.  The scope of the project was so large that we exhausted all of our initial budget just traveling around the state capturing the photographs and stories.  After which we have spent countless hours on our own time curating, editing and designing the final layout for the book.  Fortunately, most of that huge undertaking is done and the book is 90% ready for print.  Now with your support we can overcome the final hurdle and raise the money to get this thing on the press.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      We do realize that $65 is not possible for everyone. Whether you are able to contribute or it’s just nor feasible at this time, you can still help us get the word out and consider using the Indiegogo share tools. Please help spread the word and get this incredible project across the finish line. 
      Thank you all for your support.

story:
Hi, I'm Hunter Moon Laytart and roller derby has changed my life. Now my dad and I have come up with a great idea to share the roller derby love with girls all over the planet. My Roller Derby World Do It Yourself Trading Cards.

Two years ago I asked my dad for a pair of roller skates for my birthday. The next morning my dad showed me a video of a flat track roller derby bout and I knew immediately, I had found my sport. I was born to be a roller girl.

I started practicing roller derby with my dad at my local skate park in Northern California. After a year of training at the skate park, most of the time being the only girl (and the only roller girl all the time), we found a flier advertising a Jr. Roller Derby Camp.

Now, I'm Hunter Bee on my first Jr. roller derby team, The Ego Breakers. I love getting knocked down, picking myself up, racing and getting whipped around the track. I love all the other roller derby girls I'm meeting and playing with too. Roller derby is my life and I want to share this experience with girls everywhere!

So, my dad and I have come up with the company MyRollerDerbyWorld.com to help spread the derby love!

MyRollerDerbyWorld.com is a Do It Yourself Roller Derby Trading Card Template that allows you to upload your picture, then design and modify the layout of your own personal trading cards. Once you're done, you can either print them on your computer, or you can submit your order to us, and just like that you have your own personal professional trading cards delivered to your home.

Roller derby started here in America and was the first sport where women competed on the same level as men. In recent years it has had a renewed popularity which has expanded all over the world! There are even roller derby teams in Africa and in Greenland!

The money we are raising will allow us to create the website and template so you can design and modify your own personal trading cards. 

My dad has ten plus years of experience in the Outdoor Sports Industry working trade shows and doing sales and marketing. He knows exactly where to market and sell MyRollerDerbyWorld.com.

So, if we can reach our goal of $20,000 we can create our BETA version of MyRollerDerbyWorld.com trading card template and website, and still have a little money to spare for advertising at trade shows, in magazines, and on websites like FiveOnFivemag.com and BloodandThundermag.com.

We have lists of fun ideas to build out, like having MyRollerDerbyWorld.com maintain a photo gallery of all your past and present trading cards with plans to be an interactive site where members can like and chat with other roller girls, support their favorite players by purchasing their trading cards, find out where and when bouts and fundraisers are happening, and so, so much more!

Girls all over the world can start creating personal Roller Derby Trading Cards all on their own!

And we have already started our second phase:

TheRollerDerbyTradingCardCompany.com where we will begin pre-packaging and selling Roller Derby All Star trading cards. For more info check out our video and updates on our Facebook. www.Facebook.com/MyRollerDerbyWorld

For Perks, we don't want to create a bunch of shwag "stuff" for you, we want to put as much money into the site and cards as possible and deliver to everyone who receives a membership to MyRollerDerbyWorld.com - the most amazing interactive D.I.Y. trading card site on the planet!

With your financial support and by spreading the word, we can do all this and so much more. But most importantly, with your participation, we can inspire and help build the confidence of girls all over the world!

Thanks Everyone. Keep spreading the derby love!!

Hunter Moon Laytart & Joshua Laytart

PS- Even if we do NOT hit our $20,000 goal, we will STILL BE honoring all perks. However, WHEN will all depend on how far we get and how long it takes us to get where we need to be!

story:
J'AIME ÇA CRU

L'exposition collective J'aime ça cru présente au grand public le fruit du labeur des finissants en Arts Plastiques du Cégep du Vieux-Montréal. Il s'agit de l'aboutissement des efforts investis tout au long du programme par les 67 étudiants, qui, le 22 mai 2013, lanceront leur exposition de fin d'année.

Oeuvres, performances, musique en direct et buffet rendront cette soirée la plus mémorable possible. Toutefois, étant entièrement organisé par les étudiants, ce vernissage s'accompagne de plusieurs dépenses importantes et c'est ici que nous aurons besoin de votre aide.

LES BESOINS

Une grande quantité d'argent  nous est nécessaire pour organiser l'évènement. Nous avons entre autres besoin de financer :

  • L'alcool, bière et vin, mis à disposition des visiteurs lors du vernissage
  • La nourriture qui se retrouvera au buffet
  • Le service des agents de sécurité pour assurer le bon déroulement de la soirée
  • Le service des techniciens qui aideront les étudiants à disposer leurs oeuvres et les éclairer de manière appropriée
  • Le matériel emprunté et acheté pour installer le buffet et permettre les performances des invités et étudiants

L'argent récolté sera encaissé directement dans le compte dédié à l'organisation du vernissage. L'objectif est pour l'instant fixé à 500$, mais s'il n'est pas atteint, la totalité des fonds iront tout de même à financer le vernissage et l'exposition.

Dans le cas d'un surplus d'argent après l'organisation de l'évènement, l'argent restant servira à aider les finissants de la session suivante dans l'organisation de leur exposition.

COMMENT AIDER

Vous êtes invités à faire des dons en argent du montant que vous le désirez. Nous apprécions toutes les contributions, peu importe leur somme. Nous vous invitons également à profiter des paquets disponibles lors de dons.

Si vous êtes dans l'impossibilité de donnez, partagez tout de même la page pour nous aider à accumuler le plus de fonds possibles!

Nous organisons également une soirée de financement à l'Escalier, rue Sainte-Catherine Est, le lundi 6 mai de 18h à 22h. Cliquez ici pour tous les détails.

Merci mille fois de la part de tous les finissants d'Arts plastiques!

story:
My. Name is avis obrien, my traditional name is Nalaga. I come from the Haida and Kwakwakw'wakw peoples of the Northwest coast.

Physically, emotionally and spiritually i dedicate my days to ensuring that my culture is preserved.

In order to continue on my path of cultural preservation I am in need of  your support to ensure that my culture continues to uplift, empower and heal my people.
 
Due to colonization, residential schools  and assimilation , the  Cultural knowledge and tradition was lost for the women in my family for 4 generations. I grew up disconnected from my culture and carried a lot of shame for who i was and where I came from. I had no desire to take part in my culture.

5 years ago my sister brought the  cultural knowledge of weaving back into my family and shared this knowledge with me. I felt my spirit come alive. it was as though my ancestors had been waiting for me to start practicing this art form. This was the beginning of my journey out of shame and into empowerment , excitement and pride for who I am and where I come from.

I am an artist apprenticing with master Haida carver jay Simeon learning the foundations of Haida art.  I just completed my first project with him, this drum. This drum is very important to me because it is the story of my family. It represents where I come from. I want to get prints of this frog made so I can share my culture with the world.

My goal is to raise $7000 so I can get limited edition photo etched prints made of this frog design. This project is so costly because the prints are all photo etched by hand by Peter Braune.

If you donate 25$ you will recieve 2 greetings cards with this frog printed on it.

If you donates $300 you will receive a limited edition photo etched print of this frog

If you donate $1000 I will come to you within a 100 km radius and give a cedar bark weaving workshop for up to 10 people. I will share the spiritual and cultural teachings of cedar bark weaving as well as all of the materials

My culture had almost been wiped out due to colonization. my people were imprisoned for practicing our culture, but the culture did not die. It is now my responsibility to ensure that my culture is perserved


I hope you find it in your heart to support my project and help me to materialize my vision

If you just can’t contribute financially you can contribuite by getting the word about my campaign. And dont forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!


Howa'a for taking the time to listen to my campaign

story:
Video note: during full-screen playback, please select 720p or 1080p for best quality.

After adding four more artists and several photos to the book, it is now 140 pages, plus cover—26 more pages than it originally had. As a result I need to raise a few more bucks! Funds exceeding the goal (knock on wood) will be applied to a larger quantity of books printed, marketing and distribution of the book, and the Citizens Artist Collective community programs described below. Now is a great time to contribute $40 and receive your own copy of the book!

Citizens Warehouse

Citizens Warehouse is in danger of being lost, which would be a tremendous shame as the community of artists here would be displaced, as well as BICAS and their Art Annex. Currently, Citizens Warehouse offers affordable studio space to these artists which, if lost, would negatively impact the arts community—specifically, the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District.

The Historic Warehouse Arts District in downtown Tucson is an eclectic, thriving and growing community. Citizens Warehouse, a cornerstone to this community, is home to 24 artists of varied mediums and disciplines. For the past few months I have been working on this art book featuring the artists of Citizens Warehouse—and it is now ready to go to the printer!

About the Book

The primary purpose of the book is to support and give exposure to the artists in Citizens Warehouse. It showcases select works from the artists, amounting to more than 150 full color images of paintings, drawings, sculpture, ceramics, metal work, furnishings, and multi-media art. There are also photographs to illustrate the culture of the warehouse from events, excursions and figure drawing sessions. It is a perfect bound art book measuring 8"x10" closed, with a soft cover, 140 pages in length.

The book features:

  • Foreword by Julie Sasse, Chief Curator and Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art, Tucson Musuem of Art.
  • An Introduction by author Dennis Herrick.
  • History of the Tucson Historic Warehouse District and the Citizens Warehouse with essays by Dave Devine, David Aguirre and Poster Frost Mirto, Inc.
  • A map of the Historic Warehouse District from the City of Tucson Historic Preservation Office.
  • Essays about Citizens Artist Collective (CAC), Bicycle Inter-Community Art and Salvage (BICAS), and Warehouse Arts Management Organization (WAMO).
  • Twenty-four artists from Citizens Warehouse, each artist having four pages featuring their bios and select, full-color images of their work.
  • Photographs from in and around the artist studios and the warehouse.

Book Sales

All money generated from the sales of this book after printing will be donated to funds for maintenance and repairs on the building, further marketing and promotion of the artists who work here, community programs such as field trips and workshops for students, and programs to help protect the warehouse—insuring it remain a vital part of the Arts District Community.

Our Deadline

This campaign only goes through the end of the month. And the sooner the goal is reached, the more likely we will be able to have the book ready for the Spring Open Studio Tour—which would be awesome. Please contribute today!

Note

If you participated in the first fundraising campaign and see a perk offered here that you would like, please feel free to contribute the additional amount and your perk will be converted. For example, if you contributed $200 for the Signature Edition last time but would like the Signature Edition plus 3 prints offered here, simply contribute $125 and you will also receive the prints.

Thank you in advance for your interest in and support of this project!
story_txt:
Video note: during full-screen playback, please select 720p or 1080p for best quality.
After adding four more artists and several photos to the book, it is now 140 pages, plus cover—26 more pages than it originally had. As a result I need to raise a few more bucks! Funds exceeding the goal (knock on wood) will be applied to a larger quantity of books printed, marketing and distribution of the book, and the Citizens Artist Collective community programs described below. Now is a great time to contribute $40 and receive your own copy of the book!
Citizens Warehouse
Citizens Warehouse is in danger of being lost, which would be a tremendous shame as the community of artists here would be displaced, as well as BICAS and their Art Annex. Currently, Citizens Warehouse offers affordable studio space to these artists which, if lost, would negatively impact the arts community—specifically, the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District.
The Historic Warehouse Arts District in downtown Tucson is an eclectic, thriving and growing community. Citizens Warehouse, a cornerstone to this community, is home to 24 artists of varied mediums and disciplines. For the past few months I have been working on this art book featuring the artists of Citizens Warehouse—and it is now ready to go to the printer!
About the Book
The primary purpose of the book is to support and give exposure to the artists in Citizens Warehouse. It showcases select works from the artists, amounting to more than 150 full color images of paintings, drawings, sculpture, ceramics, metal work, furnishings, and multi-media art. There are also photographs to illustrate the culture of the warehouse from events, excursions and figure drawing sessions. It is a perfect bound art book measuring 8"x10" closed, with a soft cover, 140 pages in length.
The book features:

Foreword by Julie Sasse, Chief Curator and Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art, Tucson Musuem of Art.
An Introduction by author Dennis Herrick.
History of the Tucson Historic Warehouse District and the Citizens Warehouse with essays by Dave Devine, David Aguirre and Poster Frost Mirto, Inc.
A map of the Historic Warehouse District from the City of Tucson Historic Preservation Office.
Essays about Citizens Artist Collective (CAC), Bicycle Inter-Community Art and Salvage (BICAS), and Warehouse Arts Management Organization (WAMO).

Twenty-four artists from Citizens Warehouse, each artist having four pages featuring their bios and select, full-color images of their work.
Photographs from in and around the artist studios and the warehouse.
Book Sales
All money generated from the sales of this book after printing will be donated to funds for maintenance and repairs on the building, further marketing and promotion of the artists who work here, community programs such as field trips and workshops for students, and programs to help protect the warehouse—insuring it remain a vital part of the Arts District Community.
Our Deadline
This campaign only goes through the end of the month. And the sooner the goal is reached, the more likely we will be able to have the book ready for the Spring Open Studio Tour—which would be awesome. Please contribute today!
Note
If you participated in the first fundraising campaign and see a perk offered here that you would like, please feel free to contribute the additional amount and your perk will be converted. For example, if you contributed $200 for the Signature Edition last time but would like the Signature Edition plus 3 prints offered here, simply contribute $125 and you will also receive the prints.
Thank you in advance for your interest in and support of this project!

story:
Changing the world with a book

My life was changed forever in 2012 when a Roma Gypsy man in Sofia Bulgaria offered to sell me his 6 month old baby for 50 dollars, simply because I said he was beautiful.

That moment inspired me to do something. In 2013 I released a photograph every single day with one goal in mind: To publish this book, a 365-day photo journal created to abolish human trafficking. www.shoottheskies.com

In addition to being a beautiful display piece to inspire awareness and conversation, 100% of the profits from this book will go The A21 Campaign.

The A21 Campaign

There are an estimated 27 million slaves in the world today. A21 takes a unique approach to combat those overwhelming numbers by focusing on rescuing one victim at a time. Check them out at www.thea21campaign.org

A Year On The Road

Starting last January, I spent a few months working my way around Seattle & the Northwest, but there was so much more to capture. In May I moved out of my apartment and took to the road in my 1987 Oldsmobile. Some of the highlights that you’ll see in the book are from the 20 national parks and 5 countries that I visited over the following 7 months.

Giving up the comforts of home was a sacrifice, but the adventure I had in return was worth it all. This project couldn't have happened without the generosity of the family, friends, and strangers who helped me along the way.

I saw some of the most beautiful views that this planet has to offer. It is scenery that stands in sharp contrast to the darkness of the trafficking that I hope to expose. I’m truly proud of the shots that you’ll see in this book, as well as the stories behind them.

With a little help from my friends

In addition to the photos, I asked some inspiring leaders to share their thoughts on fighting trafficking. People like Jason Kennedy from E! News, Christine Caine the founder of A21 and NY times best selling author Judah Smith had some encouraging things to say. Their interviews will definitely challenge you the way they challenged me.

Who I am

I’m Tanner Wendell Stewart, a professional photographer born and bred in Wallowa County Oregon but have been living in Seattle for the past 8 years.

My first photograph was published by a local newspaper when I was 13. They paid me $13.50 and I bought a punk rock CD: MxPx’s Teenage Politics.

Since then, I’ve made it my life’s work to capture the beauty of the world I live in. My friends will tell you: I’ll do anything to get the perfect shot. I hope you enjoy the book and give as much as you can to help The A21 Campaign end human trafficking, once and for all.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Every single book in the 1st edition will be numbered, signed by me and sent to your door. When you buy a book, you're giving around $17 to print the book and cover indiegogo’s fee. The remaining $28 will be donated to the A21 Campaign. Which means this book could raise close to $28,000 dollars to abolish injustice and modern day slavery.

  • I need to sell a minimum of 1000 books. If I sell 1,500 books the cost goes down by $4 and 2,000 books by $5. I will be very transparent about all the details and progress. I am taking no proceeds or reimbursements from the book but cannot afford to fund the book myself.

  • International shipping, please add $5 dollars to the donation. Thank You!

  • Since I’ll be managing every aspect of the book printing process, I am only selling the book and no additional perks, just books and more books.

  • It was suggested that a 400 page 8x10 book with photos like mine should be sold for  $70 dollars. I wanted to make this as affordable as possible, but still a significant amount of money to donate.

  • The book is being printed in china but I refuse to print somewhere that would compromise what this project fights for. I’ve spent a lot of time researching quality and making sure of fair working conditions/wages. 

  • If the goal is not reached, all of your money will be refunded and this will have been the greatest adventure of my life (thus far) and a great awareness campaign for A21.

The Impact

  • You buying this book could raise close to $28,000 dollars for the A21 Campaign.

  • The book is about 90% done but is now waiting on the finances. By the time the campaign is over I’ll be ready to send the Shoot The Skies book to print.

  • No matter the future of this project, I’m dedicated to giving the proceeds of the book away, so if you see this book published down the road, it will still give all proceeds to A21.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Its a dream come true to print this book. Words cannot describe how excited I am for the opportunity to have the book in your hands.

  • Please share this video, promote it, talk about it, tell your mom, dad, aunt, grandma, grandpa, or anyone who might share this, or buy it!!!

  • Indiegogo has a share button! Now Go share it!

  • To buy individual enlarged prints, contact shoottheskies@gmail.com for prices.

  • To see some social links click below.

story:
Hello, I’m Erin Taylor, I started working with glass over twelve years ago. Currently I am earning my Master of Fine Arts Degree in Glass at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale. This summer I will be traveling to Novy Bor, Czech Republic, to take a glass engraving class with master engraver Jara Sara(pictured below). This will help me advance my glass skills and contribute to my thesis exhibition I will be making next year.


I meet Jara last summer while I was taking a glass casting class at Pilchuck Glass School located near Seattle. Jara introduced me to some of the basics of glass engraving that helped me finish my cast pieces. This summer, Jara has graciously offered to give me private lessons at his studio located in Novy Bor, Czech Republic. The Czech Republic is known for producing the finest glass engraving in the world. This is a tremendous opportunity for me to learn a highly specialized form of glass working.

A glass engraving of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe by Jara Sara (above).


Budget Breakdown

I am trying to raise $1000. This will cover the cost of the class, food and lodging for one week. It does not cover any of the transportation cost associated with the trip. If I can raise over $1000 I can study additional time ($200/day) up to an extra week.

Glass class (one week) $600

Housing ($40/night for six nights) $240

Food ($25/day for six days) $150

Supplies $100

I am incurring the travel expenses by myself.

Airfare (St. Louis to Prague) $1500

Train (Prague to Novy Bor) $40

Total cost for one week of classes is $2630.

If I raise $2000, I can take an additional week of classes. Total cost for two weeks is $3620.

Additional expenses include postage, ornament production cost, packaging, currency exchange, credit card fees (3%), Indiegogo fees (4% if meet goal, 9% if goal is not meet)


Rewards

Your generous support will help me complete my goal. Every dollar counts! Rewards include a shout out on my facebook page, a handwritten postcard mailed from the Czech Republic and hand blown glass ornaments using my most popular colors. The ‘Daily Sponsorship’ level will help cover the tuition, food and lodging cost for a full day! The ‘Daily Sponsorship’ level includes three ornaments and a limited edition art print.

Blown glass ornament examples. 

Colors may vary.

Approximatey 4" diameter (11cm)


Frequently Asked Questions

What is glass engraving? Glass engraving is a technique that uses wheels of various sizes and shapes to carve impressions into glass. Contemporary engraving commonly uses wheel impregnated with diamonds for cutting. Glass engraving allows for artist to add highly detailed images and patterns to glass.

Why the Czech Republic? The Czech Republic is known for producing the finest glass engraving in the world.

Where is Novy Bor? Novy Bor is located in the northern portion of the Czech Republic. Although it only has a population of 12,000 people, is home to two glass museums as well as a glass trade school for high school students. There are several glass studios and artisans located in Novy Bor.

Why not take a class in the United States? The US has several well established glass schools that bring in quality engraving instructors from all over the world. However, most of them have limited amount of engraving lathes. You might have as many as twelve students sharing four lathes. This greatly limits practice time which is essential. I am getting private lessons in the Czech Republic (including travel expenses) for less than the cost of most US classes.

Will you be doing additional travel? Yes. It was a summer trip to Europe in undergrad that introduced me to glass. Going into my final year of graduate school, my thesis year, seems like a great time to explore both historic and contemporary glass in Europe. In addition to taking this class, I will be giving a glass flameworking demonstration at VICARTE at Universidade Nova De Lisboa located in Lisbon, Portugal. All cost for additional travel will be incurred by me, not from this campaign.


Additional Support

I realize several of you do not have the financial means to contribute. A couple ways you can help spread the word are by hitting the ‘Like’ button and even better the ‘Share’ button. You can do so using the Indiegogo share tools. The more people I reach, the better the chance I reach my goal.

Thank you for your time and support,

Erin Taylor

story:
Short Summary

As a professionally trained ballet dancer, Marie has spent her whole life focusing on creative expression through movement. She believes that movement is the key to a fulfilling life and that there is a movement style for everyone.  Opening Move It Studio is the next step in her goal to bring movement, specifically the fitness and artistic benefits of dance, to a larger group of people. 

With a Master's in Nonprofit Administration from the University of Notre Dame, Marie is committed to running her business efficiently and effectively. Your contribution to her campaign will help her to launch without the burden of a large monthly payment on a high-interest rate loan. She will be able to put her energy into making the studio successful as the first barre studio in Lancaster County and the only movement gallery. 

What We Need & What You Get

The fundraising goal for Move It Studio is $8,500. This goal was carefully calculated to be both reasonable and realistic.

  • The funds raised will go towards equipment such as barres and mats, computer database costs, signage, and other costs associated with getting a business up and running. 
  • In return for your support, Move It Studio has some perks to get you moving including everything from a motivational thank you card, to movement gear, classes, and events.
  • If the goal is not met, Marie will go through the necessary channels to secure a loan.

The Impact

  • Supporting Move It Studio will help to transform others lives through the active and creative benefits of dance.
  • Move It with Marie currently reaches over 700 people virtually and around 100 people in person weekly. Move It Studio will provide a central location for Marie to expand her reach.
  • Evidenced through her efforts coordinating and teaching in the Dance for Parkinson's - Central PA program and pro bono nonprofit consulting, Marie is committed to giving back to the community. The movement gallery at Move It Studio will provide reasonable rehearsal space rentals to local choreographers along with reasonably priced class for adults, and First Friday events open to the community. 

Risks & Challenges

Marie has a team of experts in areas where she falls short, in order to increase the chances of Move It Studio's success. 

Marie's professional focus on dance from a young age has taught her to juggle many tasks simultaneously. While pursuing her graduate degree, she worked full-time, taught part-time, choreographed for various groups, performed with a  company, and completed teaching certifications in Pilates. Spending the past few years working at 5 locations as well as additional part-time work, Marie knows that the movement industry is not an easy one. 

There will be challenges, but Marie is committed to rising to those challenges and making the hard decisions necessary while running a business. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If giving money isn't possible for you right now, you can help spread the word!

  • The more noise we can make about this campaign, the better, share this page with your friends using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • You can also like Move It Studio on Facebook, and try out a class when we're open!

story:
Project Cellule is an art/science fusion piece created by two students in their final year at the University of Westminster. 

The piece explores the ways in which humans may be individuals, but work towards, and within, a larger network. In this sense, humans can be seen as individual cells that exist within a unified body - a body that requires each cell to perform a function in order to work. Unlike most installations, the feedback you receive from interacting with our piece will emphasise the network existence, using your presence to manipulate what others experience.

Our work will take form as a large web of woven IV tubes that will sprawl across the floor,walls and ceiling of the gallery - occasionally falling into a cell inspired structure. Through these tubes we intend to pump bioluminescent fluid, reminiscent of single cell ocean organisms. This fluid will be manipulatable through sensory points around the room; heat, movement, pulse and breath monitors will allow the viewer to change the flow and colour of the liquid in part of the piece. 

This is a challenging and large project, pushing both our creative and scientific boundaries. We hope that you feel as excited about the prospect of this piece as we do - if you do, please follow our tumblr for updates on our progress and challenges along the way. If you would like to donate to our project, we would be so grateful for even a small donation to help us bring our vision to life. We hope this will be a spectacular but humbling experience, both for the viewer of the final project and for us along the journey.

This is the breakdown of our budget. 

 What you'll get in return for contributing:


We realise this is all in dollars, but it works out cheaper than using british funding sites due to the amount they take as fees. 

$5 - 10

  • Invitation to the gallery showing of our work.

$15 - 25

  •  Invitation to the gallery showing of our work.
  •  Weekly updates of our progress (providing you supply your email)

$50 +

  •  Invitation to the gallery showing of our work.
  •  Weekly updates of our progress (providing you supply your email)
  •  Project Cellule Tote Bag (stylish, practical and good advertising for us - win win situation) 

$100 + 

  •  Invitation to the gallery showing of our work.
  • Weekly updates of our progress (providing you supply your email)
  • Project Cellule Tote Bag (stylish, practical and good advertising for us - win win situation) 
  •  Official sponsor mention.
  • Handwritten thank you. 
  • Eternal love and possibly some baked goods. 

Other ways you can help us:

We are students ourselves and understand that money is tight, so, if you cannot afford to give us any dosh - fear not. We will be in desperate need of weavers. You heard correctly, weavers. Our piece involves weaving over 1,000 meters of tubing and if we were to do it alone we are certain we would go insane. If you would like to donate the odd afternoon to us, we would be so grateful and will of course supply tea and biscuits for all involved. If you are close to either of us, please expect to be doing this regardless of if you offer. 

Please share this amongst any arty folk, scientists or rich people that you know. 

If you would like to contact us about this project, please feel free to do so at projectcellule@gmail.com.

Promo Video to follow

Lily and Kitti x

 Invitation to the gallery showing of our work.


Weekly updates of our progress (providing you supply your email)


Project Cellule Tote Bag (stylish, practical and good advertising for us - win win situation) 


 Official sponsor mention.


Handwritten thank you. 


Eternal love and possibly some baked goods. 




Other ways you can help us:
We are students ourselves and understand that money is tight, so, if you cannot afford to give us any dosh - fear not. We will be in desperate need of weavers. You heard correctly, weavers. Our piece involves weaving over 1,000 meters of tubing and if we were to do it alone we are certain we would go insane. If you would like to donate the odd afternoon to us, we would be so grateful and will of course supply tea and biscuits for all involved. If you are close to either of us, please expect to be doing this regardless of if you offer. 
Please share this amongst any arty folk, scientists or rich people that you know. 
If you would like to contact us about this project, please feel free to do so at projectcellule@gmail.com.
Promo Video to follow
Lily and Kitti x

story:
An exhibition catalog for Layering Constructs showcasing in two museums

Wilmington, Delaware, United States

 

Layering Constructs is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for said purposes  must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 If you want to make a contribution to Layering Constructs with a tax deduction and not receive a perk, click the link to the Fractured Atlas page:  https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=10842

In the Spring of 2015 Margo Allman, Charles Burwell and Antonio Puri will be having an exhibition titled Layering Constructs at the Delaware Center for Contemporary Art and the Delaware Art Museum concurrently. At the DCCA we will be showing larger works from April 18 to September 7, 2015, and at the Delaware Art Museum we will showcase medium to smaller works from April 11 to August 2, 2015.

The Delaware Center for Contemporary Arts is a non-collecting art museum located in Wilmington, Delaware dedicated to the advancement of contemporary art.  The Delaware Art Museum holds a collection of over 12,000 objects with a focus on American art.

The process of layering imagery is significant in each of our work. From the conceptual to the physical process of putting one form over another, we approach and use the process of layering in unique and personal ways. This exhibition highlights how we each make paintings through layering.

The exhibition will be accompanied by a substantial catalog documenting our work along with essays and curator statements by Margaret Winslow, Maiza Hixson, Susan Isaacs, and Mary Holahan, all curators of the respective museums.  

We seek your help in securing funds to create this important catalog.  So far we have secured some funds through private donations but require additional monies in order to pay for printing, photographing, designing and mailing the catalog. 

We have all been working for many years developing our unique styles and it is crucial at this point in our careers to document important exhibitions since it will launch our careers even further. 

Your help will impact us in a tremendous way.  Here is a breakdown of costs for the catalog:

Printing: $23,000

Photography: $3,500

Mailing envelopes and postage: $1,500

We have also bartered our individual works in order to secure the design, and written essays for the catalog.  A private donor has paid $12,000 towards our catalog and now we are seeking an additional $15,000 in order to produce this fantastic catalog.  If we are able to secure a larger amount we would like to use the funds to transport our works to the museums and if possible an advertisement in Art in America.

 

Margo Allman


Antonio Puri


Charles Burwell

story:
Short Summary

Studio Current is in transition! We hope to sustain the space for unique programs like Plumage and Walleye, rehearsals, art-practices, community activities, and rentals through this transition time. To do that (and quite a bit more) we're asking for your help. 

This fundraiser supports Studio Current and the artists it serves, the art ecology of Seattle, and two neon wig wearing captains as they steer toward lands of increased sustainability for the organization, more support for artists, more programming, and a few dandy updates to the space.

We are Studio Current - in the heart of the Pike/Pine corridor in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood. Vanessa DeWolf founded the space 11 years ago to support the creative process for artists and their works. It's a space where forms, ideas, community and culture converge. As Vanessa steps into new creative dimensions she passes the captains wig (neon pink, unevenly cut) to kt Shores. 

Transitions hold unique challenges and opportunities. Your support makes a big difference toward reaching our sustainability goal -  administrative costs add up quickly, so money raised here will be used to offset some of them. If we reach our goal, we'll be able to give the space some extra TLC: fresh paint, untangling some electrical issues, and updating the blue room and entryway. Most importantly this campaign and your continued support allows us to continue nourishing artists and artistry. The more money we raise, the less expensive it is for artists (and everybody!) to use the space and access the programming.

What We Need & What You Get 

This campaign is funding some of the front loaded administrative costs for Studio Current. Most of our expenses are fairly low, but have been absorbed historically by the director. We've worked hand to mouth, so if we meet our goal about one month's rent for Studio C will be put into a "rainy day" fund to help us cover those inevitable times when something goes awry. The rest goes directly into paying for operational costs and a few improvements to the space.

Our creative THANKYOUS,  a score, a poem, a map, video postcard, and co-curate a happening campaign perks are all neat things to enjoy along with the satisfaction of knowing you're supporting Studio Current's growth and longstanding commitment to artistic connection and process.

The Impact

This is the first step in our strategy for a sustainable Studio Current. You're funding the foundation of this organization and supporting it's ongoing work. The impact is huge.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are there, and while we can't know what will happen for sure we'll do our best to meet the challenges along the way. We've got great spaces in Studio C and D and we don't want to lose them or the creative community that Vanessa has fostered for over a decade. Our best assets are your support and the amazing team of creatives working the scene at Current.

Other Ways You Can Help

If a monetary contribution isn't in your budget right now you can still help us by getting the word out to everybody - every share helps!

Fill out our survey and then share that too: https://studiocurrent.typeform.com/to/EVivK5

Want to get more involved at Studio Current? Email studio.current@gmail.com

We could also use some RUGS! Want to donate one? Email studio.current@gmail.com

Thank you for your continued inspiration and support. We tip our neon pink wigs to you! They fall off our heads landing in wavy neon puddles of gratitude!

story:
Introducing Freeport FebFest

Freeport FebFest (www.FreeportFebFest.com) is a moveable feast celebrating the richness of Freeport's arts and cultural community -- visual arts, theater, film, music, poetry & prose, food & drink and whatever else springs up along the way will all be celebrated in this month-long festival.

A great many artists, artisans, craftspeople and arts & cultural organizations call Freeport home, presenting performances, workshops and exhibits throughout the year. But Freeport is best known for our shopping outlets -- the arts are far less visible. Freeport FebFest aims to change that. We're opening this somewhat hidden cultural treasure trove with events presented by some of the many artists and organizations based in Freeport.

The calendar is already full of great events from Freeport Players, MASISTA, Pine Tree Academy, LL Bean, Freeport Community Library, Freeport High School students, Greater Freeport Community Chorus, Art Guild of Freeport, and FreeportUSA...with more events in the works.


What We Need & What You Get

We seek $1000 for publicity and administration in this inaugural year. Our publicity plan calls for a mix of traditional and social media publicity, including brochures, posters, print and online advertising, Twitter and Facebook, email campaigns, incentive programs and good old-fashioned word of mouth, all designed to get people to attend as many events during the month as possible. Thanks to a grant from the Davis Family Foundation and a whole lot of volunteer time from participating groups, this $1000 is the last bit we need to complete funding for the Festival promotions.

  • Donate $50-100 to this campaign and you will receive an 11x17 Freeport FebFest poster (suitable for framing) or a Freeport FebFest t-shirt.
  • Donate $100 or more, and we'll send you both the poster and the t-shirt.

Every dollar raised through this campaign -- even if we don't reach our goal -- will be used for this year's Festival. The more we raise the more we can do and the more effective we will be in adding "arts destination" to Freeport's claims to fame.

The Impact

If you've read this far, chances are you already know how important the arts and cultural activity are to a community. The arts enrich our lives, and they are an important part of a community's economic vitality. This is the inaugural year of the Freeport FebFest of Arts & Culture. The enthusiasm we have already seen within the arts community tells us it can grow into a premiere annual event benefiting artists and arts & cultural organizations, local businesses, and the town as a whole.

Although this is the first festival of its kind in Freeport, many of the participating and supporting organizations have proven track records and experience with events and festivals. Freeport Players, who are organizing the festival, have a 25-year history presenting theater and other events and collaborating with other groups. FreeportUSA -- organizers of Sparkle Weekend, Fall Festival and other large events -- are assisting with the festival and their "Flavors Of Freeport" is one of the flagship events in Freeport FebFest. Together, these and the other presenting groups have decades of experience and hundreds of successful events under their belts.


Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest key to success for the 1st Annual Freeport FebFest is grassroots support. There is no better way to support us than to talk about us to your friends, family and colleagues. 

  • Tell your friends about this campaign so we have the funds for what only money can buy. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Make some noise about Freeport FebFest! Come to events and bring friends if you can.

Thank you for your support!

story:
*Campaign Update*

We have recently added agnès b. as our Festival Partner this year
so we are no longer asking for any further funding and have removed all our "perks" from the campaign.   
   

Thank you to everyone who has contributed and everyone who has been so supportive!  Contributors to indiegogo will be contacted soon and still receive their perks. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


HKwalls is an annual Street Art Festival in its second year, and will take place from March 13th to the 21st, focusing on  March 14-15th in Sheung Wan and March 20-21st in Stanley Market.

The goal of HKwalls is to create opportunities for local and international artists to bring their talents to the streets of Hong Kong by transforming ordinary walls into original works of art.

HKwalls的目標是為本地和國際藝術家創造機會展示作品，把普通的大廈外牆變成藝術品，免費供途人欣賞。


Situated at the opposite end of the spectrum from events like Art Basel, HKwalls is not for profit and by turning the street into a gallery, it provides the public free access to the work, the artists and the process.

從巴塞爾藝術博覽會活動光譜的另一端， HKwalls不以盈利為目的，並通過藝術將香港街道變成一個畫廊，向公眾提供免費視覺享受和互動。


In 2014, HKwalls focused on 15 walls in Sheung Wan and involved 19 artists from Hong Kong and around the world.  This year, we want to make HKwalls bigger and better, covering more walls and more territory, reaching out to a wider community. 

去年， HKwalls集中在上環一共15面牆和19位來自世界各地的藝術家共同創作。今年，我們要HKwalls做得更大更有趣，希望以此深入到更廣泛的社區。

How can you help? 你怎麼能幫忙？

  • Donate your exterior wall.  Because without walls, we have nothing to paint.
  • Make some noise!  Share the project with your friends and family, and spread the word on your favorite social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter.
  • Stay connected. Check back often as things unfold, like us on Facebook, follow us on Instagram and join us in the streets March 9-15th.

story:
Meena Wong is running for Mayor of Vancouver. 

Her platform calls for a living wage, rent control, and a sanctuary city for migrant workers. We strongly believe that these—along with the rest of the COPE platform—are principles to stand behind. Her campaign is run by volunteers and community activists hoping to transform Vancouver into a more equitable, compassionate, and just city.  

This t-shirt campaign wants to raise funds to help her achieve that goal.

The last six years Vancouver has been run by Gregor Robertson, a conservative Mayor masking as a progressive. Gregor has proposed fines for being homeless ($10,000), provided tax breaks for developers, evicted artist-run centres and demolished affordable housing. These are not principles that most people would stand by.

The cost of living in Vancouver is growing out of control. When we walk along the sidewalks of Main Street, Chinatown, Hastings or Commercial, we are incensed by the injustice of a city built by the greed of developers and corporations. With Meena the people of Vancouver say no more.

We are COPE members who have come together to support COPE in the municipal election. Some of us sit on COPE committees and are dedicated to doing our best, to get Vision out of city hall. Remember, if you donate to this campaign you'll look good while you're at it!

With courage,

—COPE members B, A, J and others!

Authorized by Margaret Panton, Financial Agent - financialagent@cope.bc.ca / 604 558-1838
