story:
Hello Community

I've been a Burner (gone to Burning Man Festival) since 1995.

I made a big effort to collect maps, what where and whens, signs, stickers , newspapers and other fun stuff concerning Burning Man over all those years just for a great chance to share with people that could be impacted by it and enjoy it someday. Someday has arrived. I'm invited to share it all at the first ever Dutch Decompression Event, November 15, 2014.

Most of our European Burners have only started coming over the past few years since the Belgiums came and built their art on the Playa. I'm thrilled at the International Direction this very special event has attracted. Something i wished for many years. Now i have a desire and passion to share some Burning History with our Newest community and prospective members as well as with other curious kitties living here.

I feel it's quite amazing to see how Burning Man grew over time and that seeing it presented in a timeline of these various expressions could be very inspiring and informative for people interested in the BM subculture. I would hope that it inspires community action and creativity.

it wasn't easy getting all these papers, maps and things thru the wild weather and circumstances the playa sometimes thru at me, but i did quite a good job holding on to them. (I have many many more than in the photo above.) They made it through many, many moves & climate changes from Northern California (2 locations in Navarro) to Southern California ( 2 locations in Hollywood, Topanga), to Sedona, AZ , in storage for a couple years (near Coachella, CA then LA, CA), then overseas to Amsterdam (yay, they didn't fall overboard). it's amazing these documents are as well preserved as they are and well, some are definately delicate by this point. Lot's of heart, time, energy and money has gone into holding on and collecting these things over the years that i have participated in BM. 

It's clear to me that Everything i have, i need to preserve and protect if i wish to share with people. Lamination is the answer for this. As i am still a budding Artist & Entrepeneur  in Amsterdam, i don't quite have the funds i need to do this. That is why i am creating this campaign and asking for your help.

What I Need & What You Get

I need about 250 Euros for Lamination. The remaining 250 Euro, I would use for creating a nice presentation, framing maps, posters, and i would love to print some poster size photos i have personally taken at BM over the years. i have 1000s to choose from and it would be lovely to share some of the most powerful ones.

Lamination process is the priority, so If i don't reach my entire goal that's where the funds will go.

i will have a photographer shoot my installation and the event which i will happily provide a link to you.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you have Lamination Pockets to donate to this project, that would also be very welcome. i have been lent a Lamination Machine for the smaller papers, so Pockets would be stellar. i don't have long for this campaign, so any help you can give to get the word out would be greatly appreciated. Indiegogo has share tools

    Thanks for your care, attention and support

    Stardust Magick

story:
Materials and Supplies

You may be wondering why I don't just take out another student loan and buy more art supplies. Well, these materials are not necessarily school related. I have big ideas for my future and I would like to plan an art show for Winter of 2015. A sturdy easel and high quality paints will help fund my goal. I save costs by stretching my own canvas but wood and canvas is quite expensive. If I sell artwork I will be able to buy future supplies!!

A sturdy easel and high quality paints will help fund my goal. I save costs by stretching my own canvas but wood and canvas is quite expensive. If I sell artwork I will be able to buy future supplies!!

story:
The Nerd Dreams Calendar 2013 - A Memorial to the Digital Revolution!

Some of us are too young to remember, but there was an exiting time when computers were not yet part of everyday life. The Nerd Dreams Calendar 2013 will bring to you the machines that led the digital revolution, long before the smartphones and the tablets of our day and age. 

C64, Amiga, Atari ST, Mac SE were among the melodious names that changed our lives for ever. (The calendar even features the only line of computers produced in the former socialist Germany, the German Democratic Republic GDR, the Robotron KC 87!)

To operate these machines, you needed to know how! Remember 5 1/4 inch floppy disks and command prompts? The beeping modems and slow connections? Matrix printers and fanfold paper?

As a result, a class of computer nerds formed. Call them geeks or even dorks, they paved the way to the all the digital pleasures that make our lives so much richer today! To remember both the early computers and the nerds operating them, I want to produce the Nerd Dreams Calenders 2013.

 

Current Status of the Calendar: Half way there already!!!

Together with Photo-Queen Anna, our make-up artist Ramona and stylist Domenica (and alongside my nerdy buddies Roman and Jan), I already pre-produced the first six pictures. As you can see, quality is superb! It is 'Made in Germany' afterall.

Now, I only need six more pictures and money for printing. To this end, I would like your help to make nerd dreams come true. You can preorder for merely $30, which includes shipping fees. Arrival in time for the holiday season is guaranteed! Wouldn't it be the perfect gift to a nerd a near you? 

We will also have a web-presence up at nerd-dreams.com soon.

 

What do we need the money for exactly?

As said, six of the needed twelve photos for the Nerd Dreams Calendar are already shot. So we have a pretty good idea of how much money we need for the second batch!

  • Anna, photographer, is a real talent. 
  • Ramona, make-up artists, best of her class
  • Domenica, the stylist gets the best-suited outfits
  • six nerdy models
  • location rent for one day
  • layout
  • printing

Mind you, the sum I ask for ($2,999) is half of the total production costs. We are so convinced that the Nerd Dreams Calendar 2013 is gonna fly, that I, Roman and Jan paid the other half out of my our pockets. We are not professional calendar developers or anything like that - just a bunch of nerds dreaming.

 

How can you contribute?

I want to make your nerd dreams come true as well! Please contact me, if you have ideas and suggestions for the calendar! Write to henning {at} nerd-dreams.com

Backing the the calendar starts form $2. 

 

Our Models

Granted, you could say that we just put computers next to beautiful, young women - not such a new thought, is it? To that I say two things:

  • Nerd Dreams models are not just pin-ups, they have something to say. You will find interviews and making-of videos online, so you get to know the calendar girls presenting the computers at your home or office in 2013!
  • In a survey conducted ahead of the project launch we checked around: 96% percent of survey participants wanted to see young female models and old computers, 3% opted for old female models and recent computers, only one participant wanted a calendar featuring old male nerds and rotten computers! 

 

Our Location and shipment to you

The Nerd Dreams Calendar 2013 is produced in and around Karlsruhe, Germany, the country's silicon valley, if you will. In Karlsruhe, you will find the highest concentration of internet companies and many start-ups. Needless to say, it's also where the most nerds live. 

We will ship the calendar to anywhere in the Americas and Europe! If you live somewhere else, please contact us and we will do what we can to get it to you too!

story:
Pentaphilia

Pentaphilia is a large climbable art project, and an ode to the number five. It will be made up of 125 (53) frames, each comprised of two 8-foot pentagons fused at an edge, floating on two large metal rings. The pentagons are large enough to walk through upright (for persons under 6' tall), and spiral around each other in a double-helical Mobius loop. The loop will be enter-able at five openings, with a series of five pentagonal steps to aid entry and exit. Each double-pentagon frame will be illuminated by strips of individually-addressable LEDs (five to an edge), producing a vibrant and high visible light show spanning several thousand points.

Why?

The build team planning Pentaphilia was responsible for bringing Inflection to Burning Man in 2015, a hand-made wood and rope suspension bridge with a unique twist in the center. Building Inflection was extremely time-consuming, but worth all the toil when we watched people enjoy conquering our creation on-playa, and watching its eventual immolation. We want to repeat this experience with Pentaphilia, but we need your help.

More of Hank's Inflection photos can be seen here.

Your contributions will make Pentaphilia a reality for roughly 1,000 people at Critical NW, and roughly 70,000 people at Burning Man 2017. Otherwise, it stays on the drawing board.

Building it

Our main expenses for this project are:

  • Wood for the pentagons,
  • Steel rail to support them,
  • Lights and controllers to illuminate them, and
  • Transportation to move them

All of our design and fabrication is being done by our crew in the Seattle area. Though we have our fingers crossed that we can raise enough money to build the whole thing, we are also planning for a smaller installation at Critical NW. This smaller installation will be one fifth of the project, in a straight line as opposed to a toroid. We hope that through this fundraiser, and others that we are planning locally, that we can bring the full-scale project to Burning Man 2017, where we can burn it at the end of the week.

We have already completed 23 build sessions: designing and testing all joints, ensuring strength through failure testing, building prototypes, and streamlining our build process so that we can complete the project in time.

You can follow our build progress at http://pentaphilia.org/

Perks

We have designed and machined custom pendants, scale models of our double-pentagons. These are made of aluminum and hand-polished, so they're strong and yet incredibly light and smooth. They're available with and without hanger loops. We're still working on the design for the stickers and patches, and the postcard will have to wait until we've actually built the project. We can't wait!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to see this project built, please donate what you can to our campaign. We also appreciate you sharing this campaign with anyone else you think would be interested. Finally, for the really motivated, you can get involved in helping to build Pentaphilia! We are always looking for more volunteers to help with fabrication, on-playa construction, fundraising efforts, etc. Get in touch!

Pentaphilia is a large climbable art project, and an ode to the number five. It will be made up of 125 (53) frames, each comprised of two 8-foot pentagons fused at an edge, floating on two large metal rings. The pentagons are large enough to walk through upright (for persons under 6' tall), and spiral around each other in a double-helical Mobius loop. The loop will be enter-able at five openings, with a series of five pentagonal steps to aid entry and exit. Each double-pentagon frame will be illuminated by strips of individually-addressable LEDs (five to an edge), producing a vibrant and high visible light show spanning several thousand points.

Why?
The build team planning Pentaphilia was responsible for bringing Inflection to Burning Man in 2015, a hand-made wood and rope suspension bridge with a unique twist in the center. Building Inflection was extremely time-consuming, but worth all the toil when we watched people enjoy conquering our creation on-playa, and watching its eventual immolation. We want to repeat this experience with Pentaphilia, but we need your help.

More of Hank's Inflection photos can be seen here.
Your contributions will make Pentaphilia a reality for roughly 1,000 people at Critical NW, and roughly 70,000 people at Burning Man 2017. Otherwise, it stays on the drawing board.

Building it
Our main expenses for this project are:

Wood for the pentagons,
Steel rail to support them,
Lights and controllers to illuminate them, and
Transportation to move them

All of our design and fabrication is being done by our crew in the Seattle area. Though we have our fingers crossed that we can raise enough money to build the whole thing, we are also planning for a smaller installation at Critical NW. This smaller installation will be one fifth of the project, in a straight line as opposed to a toroid. We hope that through this fundraiser, and others that we are planning locally, that we can bring the full-scale project to Burning Man 2017, where we can burn it at the end of the week.
We have already completed 23 build sessions: designing and testing all joints, ensuring strength through failure testing, building prototypes, and streamlining our build process so that we can complete the project in time.

You can follow our build progress at http://pentaphilia.org/
Perks
We have designed and machined custom pendants, scale models of our double-pentagons. These are made of aluminum and hand-polished, so they're strong and yet incredibly light and smooth. They're available with and without hanger loops. We're still working on the design for the stickers and patches, and the postcard will have to wait until we've actually built the project. We can't wait!

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you want to see this project built, please donate what you can to our campaign. We also appreciate you sharing this campaign with anyone else you think would be interested. Finally, for the really motivated, you can get involved in helping to build Pentaphilia! We are always looking for more volunteers to help with fabrication, on-playa construction, fundraising efforts, etc. Get in touch!

story:
The Story

Hello! My name is Alida Carlson and I am a mixed media artist currently pursuing a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Graphic Design at the University of Minnesota. I consider myself a curious and creative soul, constantly seeking new experiences, new challenges, and opportunities that will help me grow as an individual and as a creative thinker. I am proud to say that for the time I have spent on this planet, I have always been committed to the creative process and have lived a life of expression and exploration in the form of visual art. I think ART IS POWER and can be used as a tool to expand young minds and challenge their way of thinking.

For the last year, I have been developing the details of my journey to Tamale, Ghana. I will be traveling with two other artists, Bryn and Kora Gleason. Bryn has a fine art background, specializing in intalgio printmaking. She recently graduated with a BFA from the University of Minnesota. Kora is a phenomenal apparel designer and is finalizing her BFA at the University of Minnesota. We are going on behalf of a truly unique non-profit organization called Brilliant Future International, founded by Minneapolis born, Alita Watson.

Alita explains, "This is your rare opportunity to make a contribution that will change a young girl’s life, with confidence that every penny will be used as promised. I have personally spent time with each and every one of these girls, assessing their individual needs as young woman in Ghana, who are brilliant but unprivileged in so many regards."

Often times, these girls are one step away from receiving an education. BFI works to discover what each individual girl needs in order to be a successful student. Often times, that might be a new pair of shoes. Or, for the girls that live 10 miles outside of Tamale, a bicycle so that they can get to school more efficiently. 

What I aim to do is provide these young girls with the opportunity to express themselves as individuals and create art that inspires them and instigates self-exploration! These girls have such curious minds and big hearts, but struggle to find balance between all of their responsibilities at home and at school. I want to offer a time during their day that they can have a moment away from their daily challenges. 

Please visit http://www.brilliant-future.org/ for more detailed information about who Alita Watson is and what she does to improve the lives of young girls in Ghana. 

Your Contribution 

This is a completely self-funded endeavor. Your financial support with not only go towards helping me cover extensive travel costs, but will go towards helping to purchase the materials needed for a classroom of 20 students for the month of July.

For those of you that enjoy the art I make, this is a perfect opportunity to purchase an original piece or a print! I was limited to the number of "perks" I could include on Indiegogo, so please visit http://indiegogofundraiser.blogspot.com/ to view all of the pieces for sale.

I am incredibly grateful for your interest in my project and would love to answer any further questions you might have. 

You can contact me at carl3844@umn.edu

story:
Hello, my name is Zandria Wyatt. I'm an artist living in Tulsa, OK and a touring docent at the Philbrook Museum of Art. I have a BA in art and have taught private painting classes. I am also a stand-up comedian and I know how to make a subject fun and engaging. I love teaching others how to practice what I do. Moreover, I love the very human history of my profession and how it intertwines with who we are as a culture.

Please allow me to share that with as many people as I can with this project. I want to film a live art class and upload it on YouTube and other similar platfoms so others may benefit. I also wanted this to be a free service so those who always wanted to learn to paint, or have an interest in how our visual representation of things have evolved as humankind has, even if they're not as financially secure as most who get to take these kinds of classes.

Moreover, I will be integrating both the history and the how-to in a way that normally takes two different classes. This is the most concentrated, densely-packed lesson plan I can come up with. You will see for yourself as what follows is a proto-syllabus, which gives you an idea of what we'll be covering.

Art Class Crash Course Syllabus

Session 1. Prehistoric/Greek Art.

*Hieroglyphs, New Grange, relics, Stonehinge, ect

*Exercises: Hand-eye coordination inspired by New Grange, Shading inspired by Venus of Willendorf.

Session 2. The Romans Are Comming!

*Arches, domes, vaults, Romanesqe statues as compared to Greek and Egyptian.

*Exercises: Fun with vanishing points using altars, gesture drawings inspired by sculptures of the era.

Session 3. Churches, Churches, Churches!

*Deconstruction of an altarpiece, pre-Renaissance attempts at atmosphere vs. the celestial background common of the era.

*Exersise: Design your own altarpiece utilizing all the drawing exersices explored thus far.

*MIDTERM CELEBRATION! Farewell to drawing, hello painting!

Session 4. Renaissance!

*Northern Renaissance vs. the one started in Florence, atmospheric and leniar perspective.

*Exercise: Painting landscapes utilizing atmospheric perspective.

Session 5. Mannerist/Baroque/Realism

*The whimsy of mannerist art, the dignified baroque, and the realism revolt, elements of a portrait in each of these.

*Exersice: Portrait painting principles, blending effects on skin tone, hair, and fabric.

Session 6. Impressionism

*response to photography, empasis on light/shading, pointillism, the shunning of imptessionist, the prestigie of the Salon.

*Exercise: Light, shading, and color as primary tools in a painint w/o "lines."

Session 7. Post-impressionism, Modern/Contemporary Art

*The odd couple: Van Gogh and Gauguin, givng Picasso his due, dada, pop-art. Contemporary museum restrictions vs. one housing the work of the dead.

*Exercise: Pop-art project, trying not to cry on the last day.

So that's my quickie art class in a nutshell. Now that there's a plan, of sorts, we must have the gear...

 Here's a bare-minimum list of what I'm going to need:

1. A cinematographer

2. Filming equipment

3. Art supplies

4. Studio rental

5. Projection equipment for power-point mini-lectures

6. MAYBE an editor, but may be able to do it myself. It just may take longer to churn out each episode.

You maky be asking yourself, "Why can't she just get a friend to film her teaching a class?" Well, that can happen, but it's going to look horribe, the sound will suck, the graphics will be cheesy, butts will be in the shot, important info will be edited out,  and I'll probably end up deleting it by mistake. We need to get people on board who know what they're doing, and we need the right equipment to do it in a way that's palatable to first-time and would-be artist.

Becoming a student.: All we ask is a $50 donation, as it is offered as one of our perks, which enables you to become a student. You many also become a Bring-A-Pal student for $75. As the name suggests, this  enables you to take someone with you to also participate in these sessions. Seeing as most art classes cost at least twice as much, this is a pretty sweet deal, as well as a great activity to share with a friend or loved one.

Please help Tulsa, nay, the world, aquire a greater appreciation for the visual arts, as well as the techniques to express itself. Thank you.


.

story:
Who are we?

IREX Europe - We're an NGO founded in 2004 and based in Lyon, France. We work on many different human rights' issues but we're particularly specialised in free media programmes and conflict resolution projects. The Festival builds off our Theatre for Peace projects we've implemented since 2009 with our local partner KOW Media, based in Hargeisa, Somaliland. The Theatre for Peace Road Show program aimed at helping people address conflict using Drama for Conflict Transformation (DCT) methods that combine theatre, debate and poetry to create a “safe space” for exploring incendiary issues such as religion, clan and tribal conflicts, female genital mutilation (FGM), domestic violence, human rights... The program built on KOW Media’s work through its “Geediga Nabada” Peace Caravan team of trained theatre practitioners. DCT is a rich methodology that encourages improvisation and play to help participants develop new views and behaviours. IREX Europe specialists worked with the theatre troupe to help them incorporate DCT techniques in their performances. In situations of entrenched conflict, where debate and historical analysis is rare and often leads itself to conflict, DCT unlocks the creative power of individuals and communities to adopt new perspectives and develop novel solutions to local problems. Not only is DCT a powerful tool for transforming attitudes, it also provides a platform for practicing conflict resolution strategies.

IREX - IREX is our big sister organisation, our 'network partner' as we say! IREX is an international non-profit organization providing thought leadership and innovative programs to promote positive lasting change globally. IREX enables local individuals and institutions to build key elements of a vibrant society: quality education, independent media, and strong communities. To strengthen these sectors, their program activities also include conflict resolution, technology for development, gender, and youth. IREX employs field-tested methods and innovative uses of technologies to develop practical and locally-driven solutions with our partners in more than 100 countries. Founded in 1968 and based in Washington DC, IREX has a staff of over 400 professionals worldwide and is helping us promote the festival both within the US and internationally.

KOW Media Foundation - KOW Media Corporation (KMC) is a Somaliland based media and advertising company that offers multiple services such as advertising, events and media management, billboard and bus wrap advertising... It's Foundation, a non-profit entity, has been working on civic education and engagement work in Somaliland and South Central for many years. The staff at KOW Media, inspired by their Director, run the foundation because they believe in a peaceful future for the Somali people. The last IREX Europe and KOW Media project ended in 2012 with the first Somali Peace Festival - Film, Photo and Art and was a success Somalilanders are still talking about today. KMC wants to make the Festival annual, establishing a major cultural event in Hargeisa that could pave the way for more stability and peace in the region. IREX Europe and IREX are dedicated to supporting KMC in this process and making the Somali Peace Festival a regular, successful event for all Somalis.


What is the Somali Peace Festival?

The Somali Peace Festival - Film, Photo and Art is an art festival open to all Somalis from the Horn of Africa region and the Diaspora that aims to support cultural expression in Somalia as a means of promoting peace and understanding. Amateur artists can submit their art entries to a competition. They will have the opportunity to display their art portraying images of peace, freedom and reconciliation at the Festival and produce live art work. Entries will be judged and the best art work will win prizes. The Festival builds off IREX Europe and KMC's Theatre for Peace work in Somalia and is based on the idea that culture and art can not only facilitate discussion among people but also contributes to building a nation's identity.

                               Children gathering to see the Theatre show.

                         Villagers and the moderator talking after the show.

This video made by KMC explains how the theatre troupe puts on its performances around Somaliland, how they constantly have to negotiate with village elders, religious leaders and the authorities in order to perform. IREX Europe’s Theatre Specialist Steve Grihault is also shown passing on Forum Theatre interactive skills to the actors. The film ends with some shots from the Somali Peace Festival - Film, Photo and Art held in Hargeisa 28 February to 1st March 2012.

The situation in Somalia - after over two decades of conflict - remains desperately difficult: Somalia faces key challenges in order to re-establish safety and security, and to introduce sustainable democratic institutions and processes. Since late 2012, significant progress has been made, notably the establishment of the Somalia National Government and consolidation of an increasingly peaceful Mogadishu. However, Somalia remains in the phase of “early recovery”: while Al Shabaab have been driven out of large parts of Somalia and piracy attacks drastically reduced, for Somalia to ensure a peaceful future, its people must come together under a common understanding. Somaliland and its capital city Hargeisa is an example of peace and stability in the Somali context. Somaliland declared its independence in 1991 but that independence has gone largely unrecognised by the international community. It has however managed to maintain a significant level of stability in the region and this despite receiving little international funding.

Art for Peace – We firmly believe that integrating culture into conflict resolution, and more generally into development work, is essential to the process of nation building and peace building in post-conflict societies which requires the inclusion of the nation, community and/or society’s cultural identity in order to achieve sustainable and concrete peace and stability. Culture reflects a nation’s identity and people need to see themselves in this cultural and national context if they are to embrace the peace process and learn to live together with tolerance and understanding.

Why crowdfunding? We have never used crowdfunding before and have turned to it because we have been unable to secure funding to continue our work in Somaliland and the Horn of Africa. The global financial crisis is still hitting governments and international funders hard and there is less and less money for development projects, especially for what are considered “soft” projects that focus on art and culture. IREX Europe and KOW Media strongly believe in the importance of art and culture in the development of peaceful and stable societies and that is why we have committed to cover the costs of the Festival with money from our savings even if we raise no money from donors or crowdfunding. Your contributions can help us cover those costs and enlarge the different activities, including bigger prizes for the winning artists and more workshops for youth attending the Festival (see below what your contributions will be paying towards)! We strongly believe that the Somali Peace Festival and what it brings to Hargeisa and its region is essential to maintaining peace and stability in the area.

By contributing in any way you can to this project, you will be helping the Somali people maintain and develop a cultural event they can call their own. The Festival brings people together and promotes Somali produced and Somali owned art in a country where radical leaders have banned the use of any form of art in many parts of the country. By helping the Somali people sustain this event, you will be giving them the opportunity to feel proud of their culture and of being Somali. We hope that this feeling will contribute to maintaining the current and growing peace in the region.


What we need and how you can help...

We are hoping to raise 8,970 € to cover costs of venue rental, of the youth drama workshops that will be delivered for youth and children present at the Festival, of the Geediga Nabada Peace Caravan performances, and the cost of prizes for the winning art entries. As stated before, the more we can raise, the bigger the Festival will be, and the more powerful it will be, bigger prizes for winning artists and more theatre and art workshops for youth! The costs will of course be covered by IREX Europe if we do not raise the money hoped for. This will however be coming out of our savings which is somewhat of a risk for us, as we are a small NGO with limited financial capacity. But we are ready and willing to take this risk as we believe that this is exactly the sort of grassroots initiative that should be supported if we’re to secure lasting peace for the Somali people.

In return for your contributions, we will be offering the following:

5 € - IREX Europe will send you (if you wish!) regular email updates on the Festival (its best entries and links to stories) and IREX Europe's work.

10 € - We will send you IREX Europe stickers for you to stick around, wherever you are in the world!

20 € - IREX Europe will send you a Somali postcard that we will have made with a Somali poem, Somali calligraphy or picture!

50 € - IREX Europe will send you a USB stick with a collection of photos of the Festival, the artists and their entries and a video of the prize giving ceremony!

100 € and more! - We will have a local Somali artist do an artistic display at the Festival showing the names (or alias!) of all the most generous contributors! Individual names or the names of an organisation can be displayed.


What your contributions will do...

We think it’s important to say that all funding received will go in priority towards paying for the Festival’s costs, before human resources’ costs. If we receive enough to pay towards salary costs, KMC’s staff will in priority be covered. The amount targeted by this campaign is intended to cover costs of renting a venue for the Festival for two days. This is one of the highest costs as the venue has to be completely secure as Somaliland, Somalia and the region remain high-risk venues for artistic and cultural events. We therefore need a venue equipped with metal detectors, body scans and security personnel to minimise security risks during the Festival. Your contributions will also go towards covering the costs of the prizes we will be delivering to the best artists who submitted entries to the Festival’s competition. We’re budgeting 3,000 € for prizes which is a modest amount. This will allow us to allocate 1000 € per category. If we raise more money however, we will be able to raise the value of the prizes and potentially the number of prizes. Currently we plan to award 500 € for the winner of each category, 300 for second place and 100 for third place.

We also want the Festival to be an interactive event, with shows and workshops for people to attend. Your contributions will therefore also go towards covering the costs of a theatre workshop for youth attending the Festival. During this workshop, youth will be able to learn about Drama for Conflict Transformation methods. The idea is to inspire young people to be creative and use different art forms to promote peace and understanding. To complete everything, the Geediga Nabada Peace Caravan will perform at the Festival, and your contributions will also go towards covering their fees.

The use of art and culture in peace building is a proven development technique that IREX Europe has been using extensively since 2008. IREX Europe started working in Bangladesh in 2008 using cinema and a touring cinema van, coupled with community discussions, in rural communities. In 2009, IREX Europe did similar work with youth in Indonesia, this time using theatre as a tool to spark discussions on taboo subjects such as religious tolerance. 2009 is also the year that IREX Europe started working with KMC and the Geediga Nabada Peace Caravan in Somaliland, South Central and with the Somali refugee populations in Kenya, using theatre, poetry and music to promote peace and understanding and trigger debate on taboo subjects. See the pictures below of our work with Somali refugees in Kenya!


Can't contribute financially? You can still help!

Money isn’t everything! You can also help us promote the Festival and its crowdfunding campaign among your friends, family and colleagues and any one else who you think would be interested in being involved in the Festival or who would like to support our efforts in organising it. If you have any ideas, suggestions, we would also love to hear them! If you live in Hargeisa or around the area, we would love to see you at the Festival. Or are you an aspiring artist and would like to submit an entry to the Festival’s competition? We would be delighted to see your work! Submit your entries to KOW Media by email: kow@kowmedia.net or by post: KOW Media Foundation, Pepsi Area, Abusita Commercial Center, Hargeisa, Somaliland.

to support cultural expression in Somalia as a means of promoting peace and
understanding. Amateur artists can submit their art entries to a competition.
They will have the opportunity to display their art portraying images of peace,
freedom and reconciliation at the Festival and produce live art work. Entries
will be judged and the best art work will win prizes. The Festival builds off
IREX Europe and KMC's Theatre for Peace work in Somalia and is based on the
idea that culture and art can not only facilitate discussion among people but
also contributes to building a nation's identity.

                               Children
gathering to see the Theatre show.                          Villagers and the moderator
talking after the show.This video made by KMC explains how the theatre troupe puts on its performances around Somaliland, how 
they constantly have to negotiate with village elders, religious leaders
 and the authorities in order to perform. IREX Europe’s Theatre 
Specialist Steve Grihault is also shown passing on Forum Theatre 
interactive skills to the actors. The film ends with some shots from the
 Somali Peace Festival - Film, Photo and Art held in Hargeisa 28 February to 1st March 2012.
The situation in Somalia - after over two decades of conflict -
remains desperately difficult: Somalia faces key challenges in order to
re-establish safety and security, and to introduce sustainable democratic
institutions and processes. Since late 2012, significant progress has been
made, notably the establishment of the Somalia National Government and
consolidation of an increasingly peaceful Mogadishu. However, Somalia remains
in the phase of “early recovery”: while Al Shabaab have been driven out of
large parts of Somalia and piracy attacks drastically reduced, for Somalia to
ensure a peaceful future, its people must come together under a common
understanding. Somaliland and its capital city Hargeisa is an example of peace
and stability in the Somali context. Somaliland declared its independence in
1991 but that independence has gone largely unrecognised by the international
community. It has however managed to maintain a significant level of stability
in the region and this despite receiving little international funding. 
Art for Peace – We firmly believe that integrating culture into
conflict resolution, and more generally into development work, is essential to
the process of nation building and peace building in post-conflict societies
which requires the inclusion of the nation, community and/or society’s cultural
identity in order to achieve sustainable and concrete peace and stability.
Culture reflects a nation’s identity and people need to see themselves in this
cultural and national context if they are to embrace the peace process and
learn to live together with tolerance and understanding. 
Why crowdfunding? We have never used crowdfunding before and have
turned to it because we have been unable to secure funding to continue our work
in Somaliland and the Horn of Africa. The global financial crisis is still
hitting governments and international funders hard and there is less and less
money for development projects, especially for what are considered “soft”
projects that focus on art and culture. IREX Europe and KOW Media strongly
believe in the importance of art and culture in the development of peaceful and
stable societies and that is why we have committed to cover the costs of the
Festival with money from our savings even if we raise no money from donors or
crowdfunding. Your contributions can help us cover those costs and enlarge the
different activities, including bigger prizes for the winning artists and more
workshops for youth attending the Festival (see below what your contributions
will be paying towards)! We strongly believe that the Somali Peace Festival and
what it brings to Hargeisa and its region is essential to maintaining peace and
stability in the area. 
By contributing in any way you
can to this project, you will be helping the Somali people maintain and develop
a cultural event they can call their own. The Festival brings people together
and promotes Somali produced and Somali owned art in a country where radical
leaders have banned the use of any form of art in many parts of the country. By
helping the Somali people sustain this event, you will be giving them the
opportunity to feel proud of their culture and of being Somali. We hope that
this feeling will contribute to maintaining the current and growing peace in
the region.
What we
need and how you can help...
We are hoping to raise 8,970 € to
cover costs of venue rental, of the youth drama workshops that will be
delivered for youth and children present at the Festival, of the Geediga Nabada
Peace Caravan performances, and the cost of prizes for the winning art entries.
As stated before, the more we can raise, the bigger the Festival will be, and
the more powerful it will be, bigger prizes for winning artists and more
theatre and art workshops for youth! The costs will of course be covered by
IREX Europe if we do not raise the money hoped for. This will however be coming
out of our savings which is somewhat of a risk for us, as we are a small NGO with
limited financial capacity. But we are ready and willing to take this risk as
we believe that this is exactly the sort of grassroots initiative that should
be supported if we’re to secure lasting peace for the Somali people.
In return for your contributions,
we will be offering the following:
5 € - IREX Europe will send you (if you wish!) regular email
updates on the Festival (its best entries and links to stories) and IREX
Europe's work.
10 € - We will send you IREX Europe stickers for you to stick
around, wherever you are in the world!
20 € - IREX Europe will send you a Somali postcard that we will
have made with a Somali poem, Somali calligraphy or picture!
50 € - IREX
Europe will send you a USB stick with a collection of photos of the Festival,
the artists and their entries and a video of the prize giving ceremony!
100 € and more! -
We will have a local Somali artist do an artistic display at the Festival showing
the names (or alias!) of all the most generous contributors! Individual names
or the names of an organisation can be displayed. 
What your
contributions will do...
We think it’s important to say
that all funding received will go in priority towards paying for the Festival’s
costs, before human resources’ costs. If we receive enough to pay towards
salary costs, KMC’s staff will in priority be covered. The amount targeted by
this campaign is intended to cover costs of renting a venue for the Festival
for two days. This is one of the highest costs as the venue has to be
completely secure as Somaliland, Somalia and the region remain high-risk venues
for artistic and cultural events. We therefore need a venue equipped with metal
detectors, body scans and security personnel to minimise security risks during
the Festival. Your contributions will also go towards covering the costs of the
prizes we will be delivering to the best artists who submitted entries to the
Festival’s competition. We’re budgeting 3,000 € for prizes which is a modest
amount. This will allow us to allocate 1000 € per category. If we raise more
money however, we will be able to raise the value of the prizes and potentially
the number of prizes. Currently we plan to award 500 € for the winner of each
category, 300 for second place and 100 for third place. 
We also want the Festival to be
an interactive event, with shows and workshops for people to attend. Your
contributions will therefore also go towards covering the costs of a theatre workshop
for youth attending the Festival. During this workshop, youth will be able to
learn about Drama for Conflict Transformation methods. The idea is to inspire
young people to be creative and use different art forms to promote peace and
understanding. To complete everything, the Geediga Nabada Peace Caravan will perform
at the Festival, and your contributions will also go towards covering their
fees.
The use of art and culture in
peace building is a proven development technique that IREX Europe has been
using extensively since 2008. IREX Europe started working in Bangladesh in 2008
using cinema and a touring cinema van, coupled with community discussions, in
rural communities. In 2009, IREX Europe did similar work with youth in
Indonesia, this time using theatre as a tool to spark discussions on taboo
subjects such as religious tolerance. 2009 is also the year that IREX Europe
started working with KMC and the Geediga Nabada Peace Caravan in Somaliland,
South Central and with the Somali refugee populations in Kenya, using theatre,
poetry and music to promote peace and understanding and trigger debate on taboo
subjects. See the pictures below of our work with Somali refugees in Kenya!




Can't
contribute financially? You can still help!
Money isn’t everything! You can
also help us promote the Festival and its crowdfunding campaign among your
friends, family and colleagues and any one else who you think would be
interested in being involved in the Festival or who would like to support our
efforts in organising it. If you have any ideas, suggestions, we would also
love to hear them! If you live in Hargeisa or around the area, we would love to
see you at the Festival. Or are you an aspiring artist and would like to submit
an entry to the Festival’s competition? We would be delighted to see your work!
Submit your entries to KOW Media by email: kow@kowmedia.net or by post: KOW
Media Foundation, Pepsi Area, Abusita Commercial
Center, Hargeisa, Somaliland.

story:
Our Story

The 22 is an online magazine that focuses on the fusion of art, music and literature as a symphonic whole. Whether the din is delightfully in tune or charmingly askew, this project is about giving artists, writers and musicians a voice through careful curation of contributors whose work speaks to the many and the few. We thrive on sparking new dialogue. On mixing strange brews. On the abundant, the heady, the experimental, the unknown and the razor's edge. The 22 features professional and emerging artists, writers and musicians from around the world and the first volume culminated in a group show comprised of music, art and readings, with a salon dynamic. The positive response to our first volume was overwhelming and Vol II promises to bring some of the boldest work yet.

 

The Impact

ABOUT VOLUME 2/II: For this volume we've gone theme. Sign & Symbol that is. Inspired by the amazing ability we have as human beings to create mythologies, campaigns, definitions and icons, Volume II explores the crevices of what makes up sign and symbols. Rather than define the meaning ourselves (wouldn't that belittle the point really?) we asked 22 contributors to come together and create a mythology of mythologies. And create they did. These works are brash, beautiful and poignant interpretations of our ever redefined world and pairing poet along artists or musician begs the question, can we ever really define ourselves or is it always open to interpretation?

What You Get

This is our first fundraising campaign and as it is, we're asking for only a minimal amount to fund a portion of Vol II. Most of these funds will go towards a celebratory event and printing costs for the Spring 2012 release of The 22 Review. Any additional fund raised go towards developing projects like the Clamor in the Streets and to help with production and future printing costs. Although we've only asked for a little, it's no lie, we need a lot. So feel free to treat that goal like a rough estimate and fire away!

EXAMPLES OF ARTIST'S GIFTS*


    

TOTES AND T-SHIRTS


Other Ways You Can Help

My goodness do we love it when you tell us what you like and want. And boy do we like it even more when you tell others what you like and want. Especially when those things happen to be 22 related. How can you do this? Well luckily we have a whole slew of options: 


UPDATE on The Facebook

TWEET on The Twitter

WATCH on The Youtube

LISTEN on The SoundCloud

KEEP UPDATED on The Blog

SIGN UP for our Mailing List

VISIT our Events


and if you are really dedicated....


INTERN for The 22

VOLUNTEER for Our Events (Free tickets included!) 

WRITE for Our Magazine

SUBMIT your Artwork/Music/or Writing

CLAMOR in the Streets


*Please note perks are subject to change based on funds raised! Everyone will get something!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Derek Gores, a collage artist from Florida. I recycle maps, data, magazines, and assorted scraps to create my portraits on canvas. I've had some great clients, collectors and shows in the US, and I'd like your help to take my work and my technique to Europe. 

I'm taking a 7 day trip to the UK and France. Here's the plan:

  • 2 Day COLLAGE WORKSHOP at Stockton Sixth Form College, at Stockton-on-Tees, UK. Recently I've had hundreds of students reach out to ask about my art and methods. For most of these young artists, it would be beyond their means to come take a workshop in Florida, so my plan is to take my technique to them. When the college wrote to me, I said let's figure it out... and here we are. We have a couple workshop spots open for project backers too.
  • SHOW THE WORLD my art, specifically Paris and London, through visits to galleries and a live demo/presentation.
  • MAKE NEW ART inspired by my trip... and culminating in an exhibition back in the US in Fall 2012. The show will include 10 new collages, as well as select work created by workshop students and new friends I meet along the way. Yes, you are invited.

What I Need & What You Get

To make this trip happen, I need to raise $9251

That $ will cover my travel, art supplies for demos as well as the original pieces, lodging, a touch of advertising, photo shoot expenses, archival reproductions, a skype shoot, and a couple bags of peanut m&m's.

And what do YOU get for helping me?

Check the perks at the right- You'll see your shot at the original 10 pieces of art I will create, as well as a few spots in the workshops, signed reproductions of art, even your name or photo in one of the original collages... :) a skype studio tour, custom postcards behind the scenes on the trip... Not bad for art made from trash.

If I don't quite make the goal... I'll still take the trip but cut it back where it makes sense. And if I go way beyond the goal, that means I can scale things up... free workshops for more students, and more than the 10 original pieces of art.

The Impact

  • Magazines in my recycled art look much prettier than in a landfill.
  • You get cool stuff.
  • I introduce Paris and London to my work... which I hope lands somewhere with a leg in Abstract Expressionism, touch of figurative Impressionism, bit of Rube Goldberg-ism, pinch of Street Art, Advanced Scrapbooking, and what LA dubbed the New Contemporary Movement.
  • I see the world a little, and make new pretty pictures.
  • Young cutting-edge artists get turned on to new techniques and a new way of thinking. I find that collage helps artists get beyond the pre-thought marks of painting and drawing, and into another place where the history in each piece of paper adds a sense of time and a different spatial experience. Good for the head... of the artist and the viewer.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute cold hard cash? Next best thing would be:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.

And that’s all there is to it.

FAQ: What Will the Art Look Like?

Good question! The art will be consistent with my body of work, figures in a space, some black and white and others certainly inspired by the colors of the trip. Definitely depicting scenes from these fantastic destinations. You'll find new takes on my favorite themes: Beauty, Strength, Mystery, Time, and a teasing Narrative.  There will be 10 originals to choose from :) First come, first served.

Derek Gores' BIO:

  • Born 1971 New York
  • Rhode Island School of Design, BFA 1993

Best known for fine art collage on canvas. Honors include being named "One of the 40 important artists of the New Contemporary Movement" in 2010, and being one of 15 artists invited to exhibit at the Manifest Hope:DC show prior to the Presidential Inauguration in 2009. 

Galleries include:

  • Thinkspace Gallery, LA,
  • Elliott Fouts Gallery, Sacramento
  • Able & Baker, Cologne, Germany
  • Baisden Gallery, Tampa
  • Parlor Gallery, Asbury Park
  • Lakind Fine Art, Santa Fe
  • EGAD Art Lab, Melbourne, FL
  • Joy Gallery, Key West

Clients include: ESPN, Lucasfilm, Livenation, Sony, Madonna, Lenny Kravitz, Van Halen, Reebok, Toyota, and numerous private collectors.

story:
Our Story

It's ON!!!  Come be part of a public arts project that lets kids use their voices and speak out.  Help kids use art to express a vision of change and invite people to listen…

Hello there one and all.  My name is Andrea Lomanto and I need your help to get to Port Elizabeth, South Africa, this October to build a street procession with the kids of the Joe Slovo School.  

 

Me, I am a painter, a puppeteer, a performer, and also a teaching artist.  The kids, they are part of the Art Works for Youth program, which is a non-profit arts-in-education organization based in Port Elizabeth and committed to making free visual arts instruction available to under-served youth in South Africa.

 

Processional art, it's one of the most right on ways of making and sharing art as a community. It's an art form that goes into the streets and into the community using all the ways we've got of expressing ourselves: painting, sculpture, movement, music.  A parade with a purpose.  It's the thrill of the spectacle and it brings together and tightens the bonds of all those participating, whether as builders, performers, or the public.  And the idea here is to bring to kids an opportunity to use this vehicle, this beautiful, spectacular platform, as a way to raise their voices about an issue close to their hearts.

 

The Impact (a.k.a. Why fund this project? Why send me?)

In a nutshell, because Port Elizabeth's kids have extremely limited access to the arts, haven’t before had access to this kind of project, and because this is what I do, both at home in NYC and abroad.  I’m going to share the skills I've got with a program that deserves support for the critical void it fills. 


And your contribution makes it possible for these kids to use their voices and make art in a way they’ve never done before.


Each child has a right to reach their fullest potential creatively, emotionally and intellectually; to know they belong in and play an important part in the world.  Imagining, building and sharing their ideas and concerns through the vehicle of this project offers kids an experience of being active participants in their world, and of considering themselves capable agents of constructive change.


The more we can provide these kinds of experiences to kids, the more they thrive.  And don't we want our kids to go beyond just surviving?

 

What We Need & What You Get 

So, what do we need to make this happen? A plane ticket, funds to cover expenses while there for 3 weeks, and also to cover supplies, art materials. October is low season for a flight between NYC and Port Elizabeth; a round-trip ticket should cost $1400.  Living expenses should total $600; it's all volunteer time otherwise. The remaining monies pay for paints, inks, fabrics, papers, lumber, hardware, and necessary tools.  At this point, I've got the plane ticket, so it's supplies, supplies, supplies...


It doesn’t take much to help; the smallest donations add up, and go far... And for you?  There are sweet thank you's that range from public declarations of love, to original artwork, including the actual banners and puppets made for our extravaganza.  The physical results of what you've made possible.


Other Ways You Can Help

There is just a day and a half left of fundraising, so please, oh please, help us by spreading the word!  Please share the link to this campaign on your Facebook wall, with your email lists, and your Twitter followers.  This project is happening solely because of the involvement of each and every one of you...

 

And speaking of your involvement, extra thanks go to Stephanie Rooker and Rachael Shaffer for their invaluable assistance, and to J.K. Kim (jkc.nyc@gmail.com) for video and editing expertise.

story:
Short Summary

We're starting a fundraising campaign after Tim Burke’s Detroit Industrial Gallery on Heidelberg street was torched by an early morning arsonist. This house has been Tim’s studio for the last 14 years. 

Tim Burke has been a leader in the outsider art movement for the last 28 years. He has recovered pieces of at least 15 historic buildings which have been demolished in Detroit and has incorporated them into his artwork.

His work is in the Detroit Institute of Arts gift shop. He has works that were recently installed in the Michigan Legacy Art Park. He will be installing a commission piece at the Chrysler House in downtown Detroit. You can also see his work in the children’s section of the Lafayette Greens garden. He also restored the tiles following the fire at the Gratiot Central Market in 1999.

Your contribution to this campaign will enable Tim to continue with his art process that he started 30 years ago. With your help he will be able to recover and salvage what he can our of his fire ravaged studio. There's a lot of sifting and expensive cleaning of both smoke and water damaged materials to be done. It will require a team effort, some of whom will be paid.

Some of the item to be salvaged:

  • Copper cross from St. Matthew Church (one of the oldest African American congregations in Detroit)
  • Decorative architectural terra cotta pieces from the Riviera Theatre.
  • Historic Pewabic tiles
What We Need & What You Get

I have to pay a crew to remove all the burnt art materials from the house. A crew will also be needed to clean each of the items we recover. Then there's the house. The entire roof must be replaced along with the gutters. Inside the wet plaster walls will need to be removed and replaced. Many of the ceiling joists will have to be replaced along with the electrical wiring and attic flooring. The entire inside of the house will need to be prepped to kill the smoke smell before being repainted.

The Impact

You will be a part of a rescue and restoration project. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity that you can be involved that will help restore and preserve a collection of artifacts that Tim will use in his art to continue to tell the story of the people and history of Detroit.

In 1999 Tim single handedly restored the entire facade of historical terra cotta tiles on the Gratiot Central Market. The original architects were Smith, Hinchmen and Grills circa 1915.

    Volunteer are Always Needed

    Just because you can't contribute monetarily doesn't mean you can't be a part of this restoration project. Please contact me if you can lend a helping hand.

    PS.

    Next time you’re by the gallery, share a hug with Tim. That’s priceless and something money can’t buy.
story_txt:
Short Summary 
We're starting a fundraising campaign after Tim Burke’s Detroit Industrial Gallery on Heidelberg street was torched by an early morning arsonist. This house has been Tim’s studio for the last 14 years. 
Tim Burke has been a leader in the outsider art movement for the last 28 years. He has recovered pieces of at least 15 historic buildings which have been demolished in Detroit and has incorporated them into his artwork.
His work is in the Detroit Institute of Arts gift shop. He has works that were recently installed in the Michigan Legacy Art Park. He will be installing a commission piece at the Chrysler House in downtown Detroit. You can also see his work in the children’s section of the Lafayette Greens garden. He also restored the tiles following the fire at the Gratiot Central Market in 1999.
Your contribution to this campaign will enable Tim to continue with his art process that he started 30 years ago. With your help he will be able to recover and salvage what he can our of his fire ravaged studio. There's a lot of sifting and expensive cleaning of both smoke and water damaged materials to be done. It will require a team effort, some of whom will be paid.
Some of the item to be salvaged: 
Copper cross from St. Matthew Church (one of the oldest African American congregations in Detroit) Decorative architectural terra cotta pieces from the Riviera Theatre. Historic Pewabic tiles 

What We Need & What You Get

 I have to pay a crew to remove all the burnt art materials from the house. A crew will also be needed to clean each of the items we recover. Then there's the house. The entire roof must be replaced along with the gutters. Inside the wet plaster walls will need to be removed and replaced. Many of the ceiling joists will have to be replaced along with the electrical wiring and attic flooring. The entire inside of the house will need to be prepped to kill the smoke smell before being repainted.
The Impact
 You will be a part of a rescue and restoration project. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity that you can be involved that will help restore and preserve a collection of artifacts that Tim will use in his art to continue to tell the story of the people and history of Detroit.
In 1999 Tim single handedly restored the entire facade of historical terra cotta tiles on the Gratiot Central Market. The original architects were Smith, Hinchmen and Grills circa 1915.
  Volunteer are Always Needed Just because you can't contribute monetarily doesn't mean you can't be a part of this restoration project. Please contact me if you can lend a helping hand.

PS.
Next time you’re by the gallery, share a hug with Tim. That’s priceless and something money can’t buy.

story:
Artistic creativity has played a significant role in culture across the centuries. We often ask artists to create without compensation. Music, art, writing, film making and other artistic endeavours are now being downloaded or viewed for free. What if we could inspire artists to be more creative and compensate them in a unique way?

My name is Sue Kenney and I am an artist. Thank you for checking out our campaign. Several years ago after I was downsized, I walked 800 kilometers alone in the winter, across the north of Spain on a medieval pilgrimage route known as the Camino de Santiago de Compostela. When I returned home my creative side flourished. In the span of a few years I became a film producer/director, best-selling author (with a feature film adaptation of my book in development) and a screen and stage play writer/performer and a storyteller.

After conducting some casual research in the artist community, I found out that the majority of artists were inspired through walking. A story in Ripley's Believe it or Not talks about how Beethoven was once commissioned by three Austrian noblemen to write music. Instead of paying him for the composition, they paid him money to walk every day from sunrise until noon because they knew if he walked, he would create a masterpiece.

This inspired the creation of a foundation to pay artists who walk.

It's called Vision One Walk.

We are in the process of becoming a Not for Profit group. To create awareness about Vision One our goal is to raise $8000.00 to cover the costs of the fall Vision One Walk  expenses, promotion, social media campaign, collateral materials and accommodation. We also see this IndieGoGo campaign to be the jumping point for exploring more projects in a similar spirit and funding the start-up of this foundation. Our next Vision One Walk is scheduled to coincide with Culture Days in September 2013, with the intention of supporting a select group of artists to be paid in product, cash or services.

To bring awareness to the correlation between walking and creativity, Sue Kenney and Amanda Stillemunkes, both Camino pilgrims, will walk 425 kilometers along the rugged Bruce Trail and Sue's doing it barefoot! 

What you can do for this campaign? http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8t_0aAa4uQ&feature=relmfu

Share.

Follow us and retweet on Twitter @visiononewalk

Like, share and tell a story on Facebook visiononewalk

Tell a friend about Vision One Walk.

Walk.

You can join us virtually by going for a walk in your neighbourhood (shoes are optional) and Tweet @visiononewalk or Facebook Visiononewalk about your experience and how it affected creativity in your life.

We are inviting other artists to join us on the last day of the Bruce Trail walk on September 29, 2012 to walk into Collingwood for a huge Culture Days event at the Treemont Hotel with other artisans. The event starts at 10:00am and we should arrive at 2pm for a big celebration.

Donate.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TXpIYMF900Q&feature=relmfu

Indiegogo is our main fundraising platform for donations of $10 or more. If you would like to offer something else, we welcome your creativity! Donate products, services, gift certificate, loyalty points, your love, your creativity, ideas, art and more. Email visiononewalk@gmail.com or call 705 8264641 and we'll be in touch with you right away.

For each level of donation we will express our gratitude by sharing your name on various social media platforms, offering a gift like a pair of ZemGear Minimalist shoes,  an audio book and more.

Why Donate?

  • You believe that walking inspires creativity
  • You believe in and realize the importance of creativity in this fast-paced technological world
  • You value the extensive time and love artists put into their work, often for little or no compensation
  • You are passionate about the arts and want to foster greater creativity
  • You believe that through creativity we can make a dramatic difference in the quality of life
  • You want to make a contribution to the greater good in the world!

We value your sponsorship, and by donating you can feel good knowing that you have taken one step towards fostering creativity and more importantly, contributed to the development of this unique foundation to support artists who walk. We appreciate your support in whatever way it is given and send you a big virtual thank you hug!

Love and light,

Sue Kenney

Artist and Founder - Vision One Walk

 

One step. One artist. One creative idea. One world.

Vision One Walk....it's for Every One!

story:
Since this Campaign does't reach $20.000 
So we will refound all the donation

thanks 


=-=======================================

 will give back your money if the campaigns does not reach

$20.000


People love pictures. We love to make pictures. So, we're going to make AWFULLY LOTS pictures so that people can use it for any occasion or purposes. We'll do it for people who wants it, and probably its YOU!
Buy us a cup of coffee and we'll draw for you! We'll draw as much as 10.000 illustrations and spend the rest of the days we'll have for the rest of this year making them, and then grant you a personal use license and send those pictures to you so that you may use them for any purposes (both commercial and non-commercial) in exchange of A DOLLAR you have right now in your wallet! as simple as that!

Why we're doing this?

It's just sounds crazy and fun, and we have the time and skill to do it. and of course, lot of people will get benefit from this, So, why not?

But to tell you the truth, this is how it all begins...

On one cold rainy evening, Iksa Wongsalam77 and Dimas are hanging out in the small cafe for their rendezvous and within those conversations, they're talking about pulling out something crazy once in a while. Both of those guys are professional graphic designers in Indonesia, and they make living from designing stuff for people. You guys can check out their work here :http://www.shutterstock.com/gallery-2602540p1.html


So, there they're thinking...

" People need pictures for a lot of different things that could happen in their life! whether just to say a
birthday wishes, congratulate someone in graduating college, a friend that having a baby, impress someone on your romantic Valentine's date, you named it! 



Most of the people they know might buy anything that already done for them in Walmart or Circle K, or any other stores basically. BUT, and it is a BIG BUT,... "

" Some are creative and original enough to want to make something by themselves for someone or something that they care about! and usually, a picture will do it PERFECTLY for them, because a picture speaks of thousand words.... But the ugly truth is, not everyone is able to draw a good picture. You may learn to design your own DIY T-shirt, Season greetings card, and maybe your own Skateboard art!

But if you're thinking to go to download an image with decent quality from those stock websites that will cost you couple of dollars, just to have a picture stamped on your DIY Mug for your crush in the high school, why don't you let us do it for you? Send us a dollar and by the end of the year we'll send you a 10.000 different pictures and illustration to chose from! I'll tell you what, that is an INTENSE AMOUNT of pictures to go through!! "


Now, for those of you who are more in a professional field, a fellow designer, a corporate representatives, or just a businessman yourself. You can also back us up by donating a dollar, or more.. :) and in return we have couple of different rewards option waiting for you!

Our Timeline

story:
The Show

On Janurary 12th of 2013, I will be opening an exhibition of my photographs from a series called Abandon/Decay.  This will be the first public showing of this series.  It's also to be my first solo exhibition.  Kathmandu Gallery is a very well respected gallery in Bangkok, which is owned and managed by Manit Sriwanichpoom, a well-known art-photographer.  In Januarary of this year, K. Manit accepted my series for this upcoming exhibition, though there was a year-long waiting list for the space.  Since then, a few of the pictures have been shown in a group exhibition at H Gallery with quite a good response. We're getting closer and closer to the end of the year and it will soon be time for me to start work on my prints for this show.  I am quite particular with my printing and it takes some time to get each print exactally how I want it, so I'm allowing myself plenty of time to make this exhibition.  I intend to spend as much time as I can during November and December working on this. But- I need to invest some money in materials and studio-time.  That is the purpose of this- money to help cover my production costs.   

What I Need

So, what I need to pay for is:

  1. Paper!  Paper is expensive!  I'm printing this series on a kind of paper called Epson Hot-Press Bright.  It's really a nice archival paper, here's a madman talking about it.  But, it is not cheap.  
  2. Printing!  These are archival-quality Giclée prints.  To have consistantcy in the high level of quality throughout each edition I will print the works using a massive, high-end printer at Bloom Labs, here in Bangkok.  So I'll be spending a lot of time sitting in their studio, working on the images, testing a print, adjusting the Digital Negative, testing another print, adjusting, testing and so on.  For the four prints that were in the group show at H Gallery, I spent 4 days at Bloom working.  All this testing eats up paper and ink pretty quickly and Large-Format ink is very expensive.   But it is the only way to make the prints perfect.
  3. Mounting/framing.  Each of the works must be prepared to be able to hang in the gallery.  This means dry-mounting them in an archival fashion and building frames for them to go in.  Again, these materials are not cheap.     

Those are the main costs that I need to cover before the show.  Should this campain exceed its goal, the remaining funds will go to continuing work on this series.

 

What you can get

In return for your contribution, there are a number of things I can send to you, from some nice little cards with the artwork, to the actual prints that will be in the exhibition (at a discounted rate!), to some very high-end light-box prints that will not even be available at the show!  Please have look to see what sorts of things are available before the show opens •--------------------------------------------------->

Whether or not this fund-raising campaign reaches its stated goal, your contribution will get to me and I will send you what you want.  The only difference is I will have to find other avenues to cover the remaining costs.  As they say- The show must go on!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by

  • Sharing this page with other people who might be interested in the show.
  • Telling me nice things.
  • Having a look through my webpage and sharing it with other people.
  • Following via Facebook to keep up-to-date with my progress.
  • In Kind/Sponsonship:  If you have a business, Kathmandu will be printing 2,500 postards for the exhibition.  Please contact me ( Liammmm@gmail.com ) if you are interested in having your logo on these cards as well as other promotional material for the exhibition.

Thank You!

story:
ABOUT THE VENEZUELAN ART FESTIVAL

This festival was created back in 2010 in New York City as an initiative by  Ishow NY Production and the Centro de Directores para el Nuevo Teatro. Its main goal is to provide a platform to promote and exhibit Venezuelan art in the Big Apple For two weeks, Venezuelan art takes over New York City with plays, staged readings, live music shows, films, visual arts and fashion. The Festival has been supported by the Repertorio Español,  The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute, Roy Arias Studios & Theaters, Instituto Cervantes, Taller Latinoamericano ,  The Producer’s Club, Teatro LATEA, Centro Español, Goya Foods, Delta Airlines and Fractal Studios.

Since the creation of the Venezuelans in New York City Festival (former name) in 2010, Venezuelans around the world have asked its producers and directors to endorse and also produce similar events in different cities and countries apart from just the NYC area, and to help promote Venezuelan art at a larger scale. 

For this reason, the Venezuelans in NYC Festival (VNYCF) officially changes its name to “VENEZUELAN ART FESTIVAL (VAF)”. New York City will remain as the original headquarter for the VAF but the festival will also travel (starting in 2014) to Miami, Madrid,  London,  Paris  Shanghai and Beijing 

It is the aim of the board of directors that with hard work, time and effort, the Venezuelan Art Festival will have an official edition in as many cities and countries as possible.  

It is important to highlight that we do not have any support from the government or any political parties from our country. We have already produced 2 editions thanks to the support of individuals, institutions and companies from around the world. 

This is why your support is so important to us, without it, we won't be able to continue with our efforts to promote the best of our country so the world gets to know what Venezuelans really have to offer: Our wonderful culture, our incredible artists and our love for life and for art. 

The Venezuelan Art Festival is a huge project, and many people think we are a little bit crazy for putting so much effort, resources and time into promoting our culture around the world, but for us, there is no better way to spend our energy, money and time than to do so. 

If you are unable to contribute, you can always help by letting your friends and family know about this campaign, make some noise! we would really appreciate it! Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools so you can let your social media friends know about us! 

THANK YOU SO MUCH! 


www.venezuelanartfestival.com
