story:
Soutenir les Jardins réinventés !


Cet été, les mystérieux petits hommes des jardins auront besoin de vous pour que l’événement artistique les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François puisse se poursuive. La 8e édition de l’événement le plus attendu de la saison estivale à la Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton (MACB) permettra à des artistes multidisciplinaires principalement du Québec de créer des oeuvres in situ audacieuses bien enracinées dans le parc de la Rive, un site enchanteur situé à Sherbrooke, dans l'arrondissement de Brompton, et bordé par la rivière Saint-François. Quant à vous, public avide de nouveauté, vous redécouvrirez le parc sous un aspect créatif et innovant.


Les Jardins réinventés, c’est quoi?

Créé en 2008, l’événement les Jardins réinventés constitue le seul laboratoire d'expérimentation et d'innovation alliant installation in-situ et land art sur le territoire sherbrookois.

Comme vous le savez, les Jardins réinventés connaissent un grand succès depuis déjà 7 ans. Vous êtes toujours plus nombreux à vous émerveiller devant les installations audacieuses. Malgré ce succès, il devient de plus en plus difficile de financer cet événement artistique d'envergure en ces temps d’austérité.

Il est primordial de continuer à offrir un territoire de création ainsi qu'une vitrine pour les artistes, à l'extérieur des lieux institutionnels conventionnels pour que l'art puisse s'épanouir pleinement et librement. C’est également une manière de rendre l’art plus accessible, car le parc est un lieu public.



Thématique 2015 des Jardins réinventés

La thématique de la 8e édition de l’événement attirera votre attention: Foultitude, la nature des liens. Formé à partir des mots foule et multitude, le terme fait référence à la multiplicité, au rassemblement d’individus ou d’objets, à la réunion et à l’amalgame. Une culture foisonnante est rendue possible par les liens qui unissent les citoyens comme les artistes. En cette période d'austérité, il est temps de se rassembler et de créer un élan de solidarité, une collectivité d’artistes et de gens qui croient en la culture, une foultitude de liens quoi! 


À quoi servira le 7000$ ?

Les artistes sélectionnés bénéficieront de 75% de la somme amassée. Le reste servira à assurer la portion logistique ainsi qu’une partie de la publicité associée à l’événement. 7000$ est le minimum à amasser pour que l'événement puisse se réaliser. Pour ce montant, vous pourrez visiter les jardins de 5 artistes professionnels + 2 jardins collectifs. Pour les jardins collectifs, 2 groupes pourront vivre l’expérience des Jardins en tant que créateurs: les élèves du programme arts et culture de l’école Montcalm ainsi que les étudiants au Certificat en arts visuels de l’Université de Sherbrooke. 


Si nous dépassons notre objectif, la campagne se poursuit. Voici ce que vous allez obtenir en plus:

Par tranche de 1000$, un artiste (donc un jardin) s’ajoute pour que votre visite soit encore plus enrichissante. De plus, un événement inusité sera offert au cours de l’été.

8000$: 6 artistes professionnels (donc 6 espaces jardins) + un événement inusité alliant performance et installation, sera réalisé à travers les jardins artistiques.

9000$: 7 artistes professionnels (donc 7 espaces jardins) + un événement inusité alliant performance et installation, sera réalisé à travers les jardins artistiques.


Votre soutien est précieux

Ce projet a besoin de vous pour se poursuivre!!! En contribuant, vous encouragez et soutenez le maintien de projets culturels stimulants et originaux ainsi que leur démocratisation. Vous donnez également une vitrine ET une importance au travail des artistes professionnels d’ici et d’ailleurs. Les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François ont grandement besoin de votre foultitude de contributions!

En plus de participer à la création de cet événement artistique d’envergure, vous allez également recevoir, en échange de votre contribution, un cadeau attrayant. Chacun des mystérieux personnages a mis beaucoup d’énergie à vous concocter ces offres auxquelles vous ne pourrez résister!

Avec votre foultitude de contributions, vous bénéficierez d’une foultitude d’avantages. Comment résister ? 


Comment contribuer?

Participez financièrement via Indiegogo en choississant la contrepartie qui vous inspire à droite de la page. 

Quel personnage voulez-vous encourager ? 


15 $, 30 $, 50$, 60 $, 120 $, 150$,  250 $, 500 $, 1000 $, 2000 $

Peu importe le montant, toutes les contributions sont précieuses !!!

Vous préférez un envoi par chèque ou en argent? Acheminez le montant ainsi que votre choix de contrepartie à l’adresse suivante:

                  Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton

                  1 rue Wilfrid-Laurier

                  Sherbrooke, (Qc)

                 J1C 0P3

Pour aider les petits hommes, vous pouvez aussi faire circuler le lien de cette page dans vos réseaux.

Chaque clic contribue au positionnement stratégique de la campagne. Nous vous encourageons donc à faire faire de l’exercice à vos doigts en partageant ce lien!

Les contreparties vous seront distribuées lors de l’ouverture officielle des Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François, soit le dimanche 21 juin à 14h. Pour ceux et celles qui ne peuvent être présents(tes) au vernissage, vous avez tout l’été pour venir chercher votre présent. (Du 21 juin au 16 août 2015).

info@maculturebrompton.com


Des contreparties attrayantes!

Voici un peu de visuel pour certaines contreparties

NOUVEAUTÉ !!!

ENCOURAGEZ LA CONTREPARTIE POUR LA CAMPAGNE 

FOURNIE PAR L'ARTISTE AU GRAND COEUR

Dans ses créations visuelles, dans ses chansons, dans sa vie, ses relations et son engagement pour la communauté, Kate Morrison signe et persiste à voir le côté positif des choses. En attendant son exposition  en septembre, découvrez ou offrez les deux albums de cette artiste semeuse d’espoir!


ENCOURAGEZ LE PHOTOGRAPHE TOUT TERRAIN !

* Choisissez une photographie de Yves Harnois et envoyez votre choix à l'adresse suivante APRÈS votre achat: info@maculturebrompton.com


ENCOURAGEZ L'AVENTURIER DU DESSIN PERDU !
Oeuvre originale de Mathieu Pepin, "vrai de vrai"
Explorant la qualité de la main humaine, l’artiste nous propose des œuvres épurées aux compositions étudiées. Travail à saveur anthropologique, des scènes arides nous confrontent, transcendant l’angoisse du paradoxe de la modernité. Peu importe les médiums utilisés, il est facile de reconnaître la touche et l’esthétique linéaire de Mathieu Pépin.

* Choisissez votre oeuvre originale de Mathieu Pepin (Format 9 x 12 pouces) et envoyez votre choix à l'adresse suivante APRÈS votre achat: info@maculturebrompton.com


Détail d'une oeuvre de l'artiste Mathieu Pepin


ENCOURAGEZ L'ARROSEUSE DE PEPIN !



Témoignage sur les Jardins

En créant Les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François, il y a huit ans, la Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton s’est positionnée dans la région en tant que diffuseur d’un art actuel, multidisciplinaire.

Seul laboratoire d’innovation et forum d’expérimentations récurrent en art des jardins contemporain in-situ sur le territoire Sherbrookois, l’événement Les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François est un lieu d’inspiration qui offre une vitrine stimulante pour les artistes. En sortant l’art des lieux institutionnels traditionnels, la Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton se fait le lieu d’expression de propositions artistiques libérées des contraintes classiques d’exposition et s’ouvre à un plus large public. Elle se positionne donc également face à l’art d’aujourd’hui et ses nouveaux modes de présentation.

Sarah Boucher, conservatrice Musée des beaux-arts de Sherbrooke.



Que la foultitude de liens commence !


Merci de votre générosité!  
Votre soutien est précieux !

Merci à tous ceux et celles qui ont rendu cette campagne possible: Jean-Benoit Baron, Yves Harnois, Maude Pelletier, Kathleen Gélinas, Martin Labrie, Sébastien Richer, Anne-Marie Auclair, Evelyne Papillon, Edigar Nzeyimana, Marika Roy, Guillaume Houle et tous les membres du conseil d'administration du Comité arts et culture de Brompton ainsi que la Ville de Sherbrooke.
story_txt:
Soutenir les Jardins réinventés !


Cet
été, les mystérieux petits hommes des jardins auront besoin de vous pour
que l’événement artistique les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François puisse se poursuive. La 8e édition de
l’événement le plus attendu de la saison estivale à la Maison des arts et de la
culture de Brompton (MACB) permettra à des artistes multidisciplinaires
principalement du Québec de créer des oeuvres in situ audacieuses bien
enracinées dans le parc de la Rive, un site enchanteur situé à Sherbrooke, dans l'arrondissement de Brompton, et
bordé par la rivière Saint-François. Quant à vous, public avide de nouveauté,
vous redécouvrirez le parc sous un aspect créatif et innovant.

Les Jardins réinventés, c’est quoi?

Créé en 2008, l’événement
les Jardins réinventés constitue le seul laboratoire d'expérimentation
et d'innovation alliant installation in-situ
et land art sur le territoire sherbrookois.
Comme vous le
savez, les Jardins réinventés connaissent un grand succès depuis déjà 7
ans. Vous êtes toujours plus nombreux à vous émerveiller devant les installations audacieuses. Malgré ce succès, il devient de plus en plus
difficile de financer cet événement artistique d'envergure en ces temps
d’austérité.

Il est
primordial de continuer à offrir un territoire de création ainsi qu'une
vitrine pour les artistes, à l'extérieur des lieux institutionnels
conventionnels pour que l'art puisse s'épanouir pleinement et librement. C’est
également une manière de rendre l’art plus accessible, car le parc est un lieu
public.

story:
Ok since we have limited time and money (Internet does not come cheap here :-/ ) this indiegogo page is pretty basic.. 

We are students from your legacy academy, a creative business school in the Netherlands. We were under the impression of going abroad for a holiday with a couple of assignments and boy, we were wrong! 

Monday morning we received a boarding card and some T-shirts and the order to hand over our phones and wallets (including all our money). 4 hours later our plane landed in Malta!

Ok, do you think this story is strange? Well, we have to travel back to Amsterdam via Rome, Bologna, Geneva, Paris without money or phone. On the 15th of July we need to be at our graduation party, in, yeah you got it, AMSTERDAM! 

That is where we need your help.. Be part of our adventure en follow us on www.facebook.com/yourlegacyacademy 

Every dollar/euro/pound is more than welcome!

story:
Once upon a time there was a cute little creatures named Lostiks. They could exist for some time and disappear for nowhere. No one could see them, but they saw everyone and everything. Exactly every small thing that they could take and hide. Several days ago one of them was caught in the kitchen. This little baby couldn't stand tasty smell of our hot cookies and milk and got caught! We chatted all night and now we are best friends. But Lostik told me that there are other Lostiks that dream to find their homes and we ask you to shelter them! :)

Who are Lostiks?

Lostik is a magical creature, brownie, keeper of peace, comfort and lost things
After the birth of the first couple of weeks, the babies require intensive care and milk, and after 2 weeks they can already exist.

Lostiks are avid varmints, they're always up to something and love to retrieve objects, especially keys!;)

The character is cute, friendly, affectionate.
They are whimsical at food so you need to feed them milk, fruits, and most importantly cookies!:)

When Lostik gets older, we try to find them a loving family willing to take care of them.

*The inscription on the photo "Looking for family"

Shelter Lostik!

Types of Lostiks

Сurrently found only 2 types of Lostiks:
Imp:


And Fidget:


But we do not stop and continue to search for new types!


How to create Lostiks?

Each toy is unique and  handmade by master. 
Creating  Lostiks we use only harmless synthetic materials.


When I get my Lostik? 
If company becomes successful first Lostiks will hit the road to their new homes in first month!


We will be happy to answer all of your questions!

story:
About Me and "Confessions Of A Stay At Home Mom"

Hi, I'm Barbara Pickles. As a fine art photographer, I'm an Artist In Residence at Studio Channel Islands Art Center In Camarillo, CA. I have been accepted to exhibit in the Director's Gallery of the Art Center in September of this year. 

I will be showing my "Confessions Of A Stay At Home Mom" portfolio. (BarbaraPickles.com/confessions) This is a series of 13 self-portraits that evovled over 2 years as I worked to convey my personal reality within the family. This process constantly brought me back to the dining room table. Here the family comes together in various mutations at all different times of the day for a full range of activities. In all the images I was absent. Ultimately I stepped in front of the camera, and through pose and gesture found a language to communicate my emotional experiences as an American woman, wife, and mother.

I'm asking for your help to raise $3,500 by August 5th to fund the printing, framing, and marketing of this show. The images will be large format archival pigment prints so the frames will be big as well. The marketing will include a catalogue of the work, limited edition prints of a couple of the images to sell, direct mail, and invitations to the show.

What You Get and How the Money Will Be Spent

Perks: Everyone who contributes will be acknowledged at the show and in the catalogue. The show will be adjusted to the money I raise through this campaign. More money means bigger prints and more collectibles. The money will first be used to print and frame the show.

  • $50 - Thank you note and signed offset print postcard - unlimited
  • $100 - Thank you note and signed archival pigment 4X6 print - 10
  • $500 - Thank you note and signed show catalogue - 5
  • $1,000 - Thank you note and 1-8X12 limited edition archival pigment print -4
  • $1,750 - Thank you note and 2-8X12 limited edition archival pigment print -3
  • $3,500 - Thank you note, 2-16X24 limited edition archival pigment prints, and signed show catalogue - 2

How Your Contributions Will Help

  • 13-40X30 Frames and Matts                           $1,300
  • 13-31X21 archival pigment prints                     $1,300
  • Catalogues (10-7X7 softcover Blurb)                 $200
  • Limited Edition Prints (10 ea of 2 images 8X12)  $200
  • Limited Edition Prints (5 ea of 2 images 16X24)  $250
  • 1000 Postcards for marketing                          $160
  • Postage                                                      $90

Why Does This Show Matter?

I am an emerging artist even though I’m well older than 25 or 30 when most artists begin. By contributing to my campaign you will be encouraging a new professional photographic voice in an era when newspapers (The Chicago Sun) and corporations (Yahoo) are unilaterally discrediting the value of professional photographers. You will also acknowledge the credibility of a mature female perspective of the world in an age where this viewpoint is often dismissed. 

All Help is Deeply Appreciated

Whether or not you can contribute financially, you can contribute by spreading the word. Use the Indiegogo tools to share this campaign on your Facebook or Google+ page, tweet this campaign, or email your friends about this campaign. You have my deepest gratitude.

story:
PASSION FOR FREEDOM

Short Summary

We are a group of volunteers and idealists from various corners of the world. We are passionate about art that makes difference. Working in creative industry we often meet artists that their freedom of expression was limited or forbidden in their home country. Our London Festival creates the space for these artists. We admire their courage and strength. 

Supporting us you support them.

What We Need

$1400 – Gallery hire cost

 

No donation is too small.  We can’t stress that enough.  Every pledge enables our festival to proceed and every donation is greatly appreciated!

Testimonials

'Honoured to have been the recipient of last year’s 'Visitors Choice Award' I would urge everyone to support, in whatever way that they can, the tireless work being done by the 'Passion for Freedom Festival’.

The Festival brings together artists from many corners of the globe whose work treats about human rights issues and defends freedoms of expression. It provides a much needed platform for information dissemination, reflexive discussion and artistic articulation.

It highlights ongoing repressive issues and potentially enables social, governmental, and dogmatic change at this time of increasing global conservatism.’

Steve Rosenthal (UK)

Visitors Choice Award 2011

--

‘As an artist, I am very glad to have been a part of Passion for Freedom London Festival 2011.

It was a great experience, starting from the excellent level of professionalism displayed by the staff to the respect shown for the artist and their work. It was the first time I exhibited in London and the show has provided great visibility to my work.

Even though I was not able to attend the opening, I feel that the show was a big success. The reception was spectacular with people queuing to enter the gallery. I believe my work was seen by many people who really appreciate art and I was very pleased to see my work on display in company of works by so many talented artists. Many thanks!!!’

Magdalena Czubak-Vlasak (USA)

2nd Freedom Award 2011

--

 ‘My experiences of Passion for Freedom 2010 were incredibly rewarding. The people I met, the vision of the organisation together with the energy of the movement were inspiring to me both as a person and as an artist. I would urge everyone thinking of entering to enter. It will enrich your life and play a small and important part in providing a better life for women all over the world.’

Anna Sundt (UK)

1st Freedom Award 2010

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

There are many more ways in which you can help with the Festival. Here are just a few more:

 1) Forward this page and spread the word to everyone in your address book!

 2) Click here and like our page on Facebook

 3) Follow us on Twitter - @P4Freedom

 4) Sign up to volunteer during the festival to work at the info tables, to help move furniture, to pick up food for the volunteer staff. Email info@passionforfreedom.co.uk with 'Volunteer' in the subject line.

 5) We gladly accept in-kind donations of food, drinks or other services

PASSION FOR FREEDOM
Short Summary
We are a group of volunteers and idealists from various corners of the world. We are passionate about art that makes difference. Working in creative industry we often meet artists that their freedom of expression was limited or forbidden in their home country. Our London Festival creates the space for these artists. We admire their courage and strength. 
Supporting us you support them.
What We Need

No donation is too small.  We can’t stress that enough.  Every pledge enables our festival to proceed and every donation is greatly appreciated!

story:
Legacy was conceived about a year ago.  I have been growing more and more concerned about the effects of natural resource extraction on our environment both locally and across the country, and  I decided it was time to stop talking and take action. 

I wanted to address the pitfalls of our 'economic development at all cost' approach to the environment, and this combined with the fact that the killer whale has long been one of my favourite animals, made this a perfect opportunity to combine these two passions into one project.

On entering the exhibit, viewers will marvel at a life-sized, 25 foot long, killer whale skeleton sculpted entirely from reclaimed cedar and suspended from the ceiling, encircled at ground level by a ring of information pedestals representing barren stumps left after clear-cut logging.

The goal of Legacy is to initiate discussions about the impacts of natural resource extraction on local communities and ecosystems.  It encourages the audience to ask questions such as: How did we get here?  Are we doing this for the right reasons?  Is this venture sensible and/or sustainable?  What can I do about it?  Legacy will provide guidance for answering these questions and will encourage the audience to examine their own local issues more deeply.

I need your help to make this happen.

Artist concept of the Legacy installation:

 

In today's throw-away society, more and more people are being taught to consider only their own welfare, and to disregard the consequences of their actions as long as it serves their short-term goals. This is partly due to the effects of rampant consumerism, and partly due to a growing detachment of urban society from the environment that nurtures and provides for it.

Legacy will try to help reconnect people to their environment, appealing to all generations and helping to visualize the fragile and highly interconnected nature of our ecosystems.

Legacy deals specifically with the issue of logging on Canada’s West Coast and the effect this is having on the local resident Killer Whale population.  The logging is affecting the whales both directly through pollution and indirectly by poisoning and warming the rivers, which is damaging key salmon spawning grounds.  With fish being the main diet of the resident whales, the reduction in salmon is putting great pressure on the whales to find enough to eat, and what they are eating is often highly contaminated.

All over the country, communities are facing difficult decisions presented by proposed and on-going extraction of natural resources.   Ventures such as the logging of vast tracts of forest in British Columbia, the extraction of petroleum from the oil sands in Alberta, the proliferation of gravel quarries in Ontario and the construction of hydro generating dams in Quebec are just a few of the areas where our need for resources and our local environment are colliding head-on. 

We as individuals need to understand where the resources that support our ever growing cities and our economy are coming from and we need to be aware of the impact that extracting them is having on our environment so that we can proceed in a sensible and sustainable manner.  Legacy is a warning that indiscriminate consumption of our natural resources can have devastating, often unforeseen impacts on our environment.

 

Funding will go toward the design and fabrication of Legacy.  This will cover costs from material acquisition and printing of promotional material to the engineering assessment of the suspension of the completed piece.

Funds received beyond the initial target will be used to help Legacy tour the country, in order to make the installation accessible to a larger audience and to spread the message as widely as possible. 

 

Legacy is the expression of Mulmur sculptor Ken Hall's passion for wildlife and the preservation of natural habitat needed to protect our fragile biodiversity.

Ken creates fine art & architectural sculpture in stone, wood and metal.  His work covers a wide range of media and techniques, from custom furniture design and fabrication to stone entrance signage and large welded wildlife sculpture.  He has worked for many civic and corporate clients as well as undertaking private commissions. 

You can see some of Ken's previous work on his website: Ken Hall Art

Legacy will initially be shown at the Dufferin County Museum and Archives in Mulmur, Ontario during the Summer/Fall of 2013.  The museum is planning a curriculum with the local schools based around the sculpture and the theme of natural resource extraction. 

 

The final two months of 2012 are crucial for the project development.  We need to generate enough momentum to see Legacy through to completion! 

Once we've got enough support behind us, then 2013 begins with fabrication of the skeleton itself and the information pedestals.  With over 160 bones in a killer whale's skeleton, there's a lot of sculpting to be done.

With the skeleton complete, each piece needs to be left in the sun to bleach - hopefully we get a few nice days in the spring time!

Finally we can bring the pieces together and install them at the musem - the earliest the sculpture will be on display is July 2013, but we'll post updates as a specific installation date becomes more clear.

Remember to check back here often for progress updates and behind the scenes pictures.

The current timeline looks like this:

 

Legacy is a community funded project.  We need your support to make this happen.  Financial contributions are essential to secure materials and help with fabrication costs, if you can contribute, even just $25, it will help us to make Legacy a reality.  If you can't donate, there are other ways you can help too. 

The goal is to sculpt Legacy entirely from reclaimed cedar.  As such, if you or anyone you know of has just taken up an old deck near Mulmur, ON, I would be most grateful for any donations of material.  Please e-mail me at ken@kenhallart.com and I will be glad to come and pick the wood up and save you throwing it out.

Most importantly, we need you to help spread the word!  Simply by telling others about the Legacy project and sharing the link with your friends and co-workers, you can help us raise awareness both for this project and for environmental issues in general.

Please share our link with as many people as possible:

http://www.indiegogo.com/legacyproject

E-mail it to your friends, put it on your blog or post it on Facebook - get creative!

You can make a difference!

 

A couple of words of thanks need to be said at the outset: 

  • Thank you to Darrell Keenie, Ruby Qureshi and the Dufferin County Museum & Archives for their support and encouragement in getting this project going.
  • Thanks also go to the Idaho Virtualization Laboratory and the Port Townsend Marine Science Center for their excellent work on the Orca Bone Atlas - an interactive 3D atlas of a complete killer whale skeleton.  They have also graciously allowed me to use the 3D files for rendering my design drawings.

story:
Hi! We're The Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space (MoRUS): a group of volunteers who are starting a new museum on the Lower East Side.

We were getting ready for our grand opening on November 17...

But then Hurricane Sandy hit, and our basement space was immersed from floor to ceiling with flood waters from the East River.

MoRUS volunteers and the East Village community were able to clear out much of the water, but there was already serious damage to the walls, and some of the museum's archives were damaged or lost.

Because we're entirely volunteer-run, we need your support -- it will go directly toward materials to help us rebuild. Our grand opening party December 8 was amazing and now we need to keep going!

***

More about MoRUS

The Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space is a brand new, one-of-a-kind museum preserving the rich history of grassroots activism in New York City’s East Village.

Over the last thirty years, East Village community members and local organizations have stepped up to transform abandoned buildings and vacant lots into vibrant community spaces and thriving community gardens. We want to share this story and these incredible spaces with you -- and the rest of our neighbors -- to keep this community strong!

With the help of our neighbors and our all-volunteer staff, we've been able to clean up and opened our doors on December 8. The funds from this campaign will go to purchase and replace emergency materials, repair floors, repair and replace electrical equipment, and replace and restore sheet rock. We've been doing everything we can, but this is extensive work!

The Impact

We're trying to bring to light a lot of incredible stories that would otherwise be lost. Our goals at MoRUS are to preserve the rich history of grassroots movements in New York City’s East Village, and showcase the unique public spaces for which the neighborhood is renowned. Over the last forty years, East Village community members and local organizations have come together to transform abandoned buildings and vacant lots into vibrant living spaces and thriving community gardens. Today, urban sustainable practices can be observed worldwide -- just one of many trends that got a partial start here! 

The museum also organizes workshops on sustainability-themed DIY projects and maintains an archive of photographs, videos, and articles, many of which have been shared and donated by community members as well as by local grassroots, nonprofit organizations such as Time’s Up!, Earth Celebrations, More Gardens, The Lower East Side Collective and Green Map.

Check it out:

  • Besides memberships and patches, we've created a NEW perk just for our Indiegogo funders: Private tours! These exclusive peeks into the history of the East Village, with the chance to meet the people who made this community great, are not being offered anywhere else.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we can still buy part of the materials, or smaller things that a museum always needs like archival storage. Any additional amount we get (dare we even hope?) will be put toward future expenses.  

Other ways you can help!

  • If you would like to be a volunteer, MoRUS can always use help with construction, IT services, museum staffing, marketing & PR.
  • If you happen to be in New York City, stop by!
  • You can also help by sharing this page with people you know, or encouraging new folks to get involved. We're a very young organization and every bit of effort helps! Use one of the links on this page to share this campaign with anyone who'd want to help make a difference.

Thanks for your support!

story:
Hello, My name is Mazie Bishop, and I am the founder and President of the Nerds and Geeks of Niagara (NGN)

The NGN is a place for the proclaimed Nerds and Geeks of Niagara . For the serious gamers, the RPG Players, comic book hoarders, otakus, the fan girls and guys basically any and all fandoms/interests. 

I started this club to create a community so that people with such strong and passionate interests could meet others like them, and learn about other awesome things. 

We have successfully created a safe place to have fun, meet unique people and to share some of the most interesting conversations in history, and that is more than I could ever ask for.


What We Need

We are fundraising in hopes to raise $500 to go towards not only this year, but to hopefully invest in other merchandise to raise more money for the years to come. I want to create a sustainable club that will be able to run on its own.

The $500 will cover:
- $100 will cover any giveaways or contests we plan to host, whether there are gift card giveaways, or movie tickets or maybe even convention ticket giveaways. 
- $250 will be put towards renting out space to host multiple big events like movie viewings, or gaming tournaments. We already have the equipment (from our members and our friends involved with tech) we just need the space to do it.
- $150 will be put towards getting new tshirt designs, maybe some buttons or lanyards made up.

The first thing that anyone who contributes will receive is the purest satisfaction that they supported a community full of the most unique and passionate (and nerdy) artists, musicians, photographers, filmmakers, game developers, computer analysts and writers.... and that should feel pretty great! 

It is one of the most rewarding accomplishments of mine that I get to say that I brought all of these amazing people together, now just imagine how great it will feel to support them!

We are also working on some pretty great designs for a badge that you can put on your site/ blog or social media that will express that you supported the Nerds and Geeks of Niagara.

The Impact

If we can raise this money we will be able to focus more on building the community and worry less about how we are going to get the funding to do so. The first year was so much fun, and we all got to know each other really well, but there are not very many places that can accommodate 300+ members. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to contribute but would still love to get involved we would greatly appreciate if you could pass this along and post it for everyone to see. We need all the love we can get and that would really help us out. It is super simple to share this page through the Indiegogo sharing tools.

    Thank you so sincerely for reading this and for your time and contributions!

    Live Long and Prosper!
    - Mazie Bishop,
    President of the Nerds and Geeks of Niagara.

story:
Project 200: Botanical Documentation of Tallgrass Prairie.

This project is broadly engaged with art, the environment and education. 

Purposes: 

  1. Documenting 200 native tallgrass prairie plants and building an image bank for scientific and educational use.  http://www.project200imagebank.blogspot.com/            
  2. Raising awareness about the declining plant population and promoting conservation through exhibitions and community activities.
  3. Helping teenagers and young adults to find opportunities to enjoy the beauty of nature, and to explore possible careers in art. 
  4. Documenting American medicinal plants.

Why Does the Tallgrass Prairie Matter?

  1. It is one of the planet's most imperiled ecosystems with less than 1% of the original prairie remaining.
  2. It covered about 150 million acres in the central United States before the 1830s. 
  3. This 8,000 year old ecosystem was brought to the brink of extinction in about 50 years. WE DID THAT!
  4. It is home for many struggling native plants, insects and animals that support the planet's health and our own.
  5. Prairie plants have been used as medicines by native Americans for thousands of years. Losing them means losing potential cures for diseases.  
  6. Tallgrass prairie plants are disappearing faster than one can imagine. There is no time to waste! They need to be documented.
  7. We are the ones who must protect this unique American heritage for future  generations.

Who Am I?   What Can I Do?

                   

                      Royal Catchfly, Silene regia, listed as federally endangered

I am Heeyoung Kim, a botanical artist living in the Chicago region of Illinois. I believe I was born to be a botanical artist. I truly do. I discovered this wonderful gift in my 40s after taking a drawing class at the Chicago Botanic Garden. I went on to paint plants in watercolor, drawing on brush skills I learned as a child from my father, a second-generation master calligrapher.

 One of my first watercolor paintings, Royal Catchfly (image shown above), was accepted for an international juried exhibition of endangered plants. From 2009 to 2011, it was exhibited at Smithsonian Natural History Museum, Royal Botanic Garden KEW, London and three other venues.This image has been displayed on the Smithsonian Natural History Museum website exhibition page since 2011.  http://www.mnh.si.edu/exhibits/

Painting rare and endangered native plants has been my passion ever since. My humble wildflower paintings have won some of the botanic art world's most prestigious awards. My exhibition 'Plants of American Prairie' won a Gold Medal from Royal Horticultural Society London, 2012, and my painting of iconic tallgrass prairie plant, Compass Plant won Best in Show award at 16th Annual International, Horticultural Society of New York, 2012.    

Plants are one of the most important resources on earth. However, industrial agriculture, climate change, and other human related activities are destroying their habitats. Nearly 5,000 of 20,000 species of U.S. flora urgently need protection, according to a leading conservation group, NatureServe.org. We have lost a greater percentage of native tallgrass prairie than tropical rainforest. (Fifty percent of tropical rainforest remains, compared with less than 1% of original tallgrass prairie.) 

Project 200 is important to future generations. Consider how much we value the monumental collection of John James Audubon's bird paintings. Consider how important his 'Birds of America' is to natural history. He painted 435 watercolors identifying 497 bird species in the early 1800s, and many of the birds do not exist any more. An extensive collection of tallgrass prairie plants botanical paintings has the potential to become important to America's natural history. I will carefully select the plants to ensure the collection also documents American medicinal plants.

Passion and patience are required to paint rare and endangered species. I spent years tracking, studying and sketching my subjects, often in remote areas and working with little gear to avoid disturbing their habitats.  

Showing the beauty of native plants can be powerful. 

Native plants are collectively categorized as "weeds" in the minds of people. They are not allowed in well maintained gardens. They are gardeners' enemies. They are eradicated.

Exhibitions can change this view.  When I exhibit, I like to invite a conservationist or a plant expert as a guest speaker in order to provide convincing information about the benefits one gains from maintaining native plants in a home garden. Many people have told me they enjoy Royal Catchfly in their gardens after seeing my painting.  

My exhibitions bring plant science and conservation efforts to the public very effectively. People learn about non-native invasive plants that destroy ecosystems. Many sign up to volunteer or support local conservation groups after being inspired by exhibitions.  

Every stage of plant life is beautiful and so is every human.              

             

                            Prairie Crabapple, Malus ioensis

Weak or strong, new or old, live or dead, all creations are beautiful in every stage. This painting celebrates resurrection of a native crabapple tree. A dead trunk is the main character, and a half dead, less than perfect tree is pushing all its energy to shoot a new twig and succeeds in blooming. 


Help this project continue, please!

Indian Hemp in Fall, Apocynum cannabinum, 

copyrighted by Heeyoung Kim

          

                                       Fringed Gentian, Gentianopsis crinita, 

                              rare, endangered or threatened in several states

                 To the Fringed Gentian
                                   William Cullen Bryant (1794-1878)
Thou blossom bright with autumn dew,And coloured with the heaven's own blue, That openest when the quiet light Succeeds the keen and frosty night. 
Thou comest not when violets leanO'ver wandering brooks and springs unseen,Or columbines, in purple dressed,Nod o'er the ground-bird's hidden nest.
Thou waitest late and com'st alone, When woods are bare and birds are flown,And frosts and shortening days portendThe aged year is near his end.
Then doth thy sweet and quiet eyeLook through its fringes to the sky,Blue---blue---as if that sky let fallA flower from its cerulean wall.
I would that thus, when I shall seeThe hour of death draw near to me,Hope, blossoming within my heart,May look to heaven as I depart.

Imagine that your grandchild comes across this beautiful poem and asks you where he/she can see the flowers colored with the heaven's own blue! 

I wish you could hold the child's hand and go to the prairie where hundreds of Gentians look through their fringes to the child's eyes. 

Yet if that is not possible, the child can see a Gentian through my art.  

What I Need & What Supporters Get

This prairie plant project will take good ten years, if I could paint full time. When it is finished, I will start painting 200 woodland plants, which will take another ten years. Painting rare and endangered native plants doesn't provide financial rewards. I do this for history and our future generations. Without support, I cannot complete this project in my life time. Raised funds will go directly to painting supplies and exhibition costs, and work space for Project 200. All contributors will be honored at "Contributors for Project 200" wall at the image bank blog: 

http://www.project200imagebank.blogspot.com/

  • Royalty Rates when licensing: 
  • 1. Greeting cards, gift wraps, and other types of paper goods- 5% from net sales.  2. Household items such as cups, mugs, dinner wares - 8% from net sales. 3. Fabrics, T-shirts, and other apparels - 10% of net sales. (Net Sales= Gross Sales - (Customer discounts + Returns + Allowances))'
  • Shipping Information

  • * Shipped in a round container, rolled in PH neutral paper, not matted, protected in a plastic bag. Free shipping within USA

    • Other Ways You Can Help

    I thank you sincerely, even though you can't contribute now. Just read this, and be mindful that the tallgrass prairie needs to be protected! Of course there are more you can do. 

    • Go to my blog and enjoy watching the images and leave encouraging comments, please! And share it with your friends via social media!
    • Spread the words using the Indiegogo share tools!
    • Plant native plants wherever you live and share your garden plants with native insects and animals!
    • Mother Nature would appreciate your efforts!

    *Music for Pitch Video: Questa O Quella- Extreme Music, Verdi, Giuseppe
story_txt:
Project 200: Botanical Documentation of Tallgrass Prairie.This project is broadly engaged with art, the environment and education. Purposes: 

Documenting 200 native tallgrass prairie plants and building an image bank for scientific and educational use.  http://www.project200imagebank.blogspot.com/            

Raising awareness about the declining plant population and promoting conservation through exhibitions and community activities.
Helping teenagers and young adults to find opportunities to enjoy the beauty of nature, and to explore possible careers in art. 
Documenting American medicinal plants.
Why Does the Tallgrass Prairie Matter?
It is one of the planet's most imperiled ecosystems with less than 1% of the original prairie remaining.
It covered about 150 million acres in the central United States before the 1830s. 
This 8,000 year old ecosystem was brought to the brink of extinction in about 50 years. WE DID THAT!
It is home for many struggling native plants, insects and animals that support the planet's health and our own.
Prairie plants have been used as medicines by native Americans for thousands of years. Losing them means losing potential cures for diseases.  
Tallgrass prairie plants are disappearing faster than one can imagine. There is no time to waste! They need to be documented.
We are the ones who must protect this unique American heritage for future  generations.
Who Am I?   What Can I Do?                                         Royal Catchfly, Silene regia, listed as federally endangeredI am Heeyoung Kim, a botanical artist living in the Chicago region of Illinois. I believe I was born to be a botanical artist. I truly do. I discovered this wonderful gift in my 40s after taking a drawing class at the Chicago Botanic Garden. I went on to paint plants in watercolor, drawing on brush skills I learned as a child from my father, a second-generation master calligrapher. One of my first watercolor paintings, Royal Catchfly (image shown above), was accepted for an international juried exhibition of endangered plants. From 2009 to 2011, it was exhibited at Smithsonian Natural History Museum, Royal Botanic Garden KEW, London and three other venues.This image has been displayed on the Smithsonian Natural History Museum website exhibition page since 2011.  http://www.mnh.si.edu/exhibits/Painting rare and endangered native plants has been my passion ever since. My humble wildflower paintings have won some of the botanic art world's most prestigious awards. My exhibition 'Plants of American Prairie' won a Gold Medal from Royal Horticultural Society London, 2012, and my painting of iconic tallgrass prairie plant, Compass Plant won Best in Show award at 16th Annual International, Horticultural Society of New York, 2012.    Plants are one of the most important resources on earth. However, industrial agriculture, climate change, and other human related activities are destroying their habitats. Nearly 5,000 of 20,000 species of U.S. flora urgently need protection, according to a leading conservation group, NatureServe.org. We have lost a greater percentage of native tallgrass prairie than tropical rainforest. (Fifty percent of tropical rainforest remains, compared with less than 1% of original tallgrass prairie.) Project 200 is important to future generations. Consider how much we value the monumental collection of John James Audubon's bird paintings. Consider how important his 'Birds of America' is to natural history. He painted 435 watercolors identifying 497 bird species in the early 1800s, and many of the birds do not exist any more. I will carefully select the plants to ensure the collection also documents American medicinal plants.Passion and patience are required to paint rare and endangered species. They are gardeners' enemies. They are eradicated.Exhibitions can change this view.  When I exhibit, I like to invite a conservationist or a plant expert as a guest speaker in order to provide convincing information about the benefits one gains from maintaining native plants in a home garden. Many people have told me they enjoy Royal Catchfly in their gardens after seeing my painting.  My exhibitions bring plant science and conservation efforts to the public very effectively. People learn about non-native invasive plants that destroy ecosystems. Many sign up to volunteer or support local conservation groups after being inspired by exhibitions.  Every stage of plant life is beautiful and so is every human.                                                       Prairie Crabapple, Malus ioensisWeak or strong, new or old, live or dead, all creations are beautiful in every stage. This painting celebrates resurrection of a native crabapple tree. A dead trunk is the main character, and a half dead, less than perfect tree is pushing all its energy to shoot a new twig and succeeds in blooming. 
Help this project continue, please!

copyrighted by Heeyoung Kim

story:
About me.

My name is Dominic Martin Gilberto Marín, I am a visual artist based in Baltimore. Over the last years I have written and directed short films, worked with modeling agencies in Philadelphia and New York. I recently graduated from the University of Maryland with a degree in Visual Arts. I've been presented with a great opportunity to have my first solo exhibition in September, however I need your support to get my photographs printed on canvas.

Moderne Wave - Project

Moderne Wave is a collection of abstract paintings and photographs, inspired by urban landscapes, nature and anatomy. 

My photographic journey started in 2008, throughout this journey I've done plenty of fashion photography, nature and urban landscape photography, weddings and events. I've been consistently refining my skills to deliver a unique perspective that is worth sharing with the world.

The photographs will be printed on large canvases, which will allow me to add another medium, paint. This will give the images more depth and create an interesting combination of mixed media. Ultimately, I am looking to create painted over photographs on canvas.

Eubie Blake Center

For more than three decades, the Eubie Blake Center has sought to bring creative expression and urban consciousness to Baltimore.

Why donate?

High quality photographs printed on 40" x  60" canvases are expensive to produce and the printing costs will make out the biggest part (about $7.800). I also have to cover the costs for paint, brushes, framing and promotional materials for the exhibition. I have settled all my travels and other expenses over the years myself. Your support will ensure that these images will be printed on canvas to the highest possible standards. The actual costs for my project have been calculated at $10.500. 


This is why I am reaching out to the Indiegogo community.

I've finally been presented with a great opportunity that I've been patiently waiting for, to have my first solo exhibition at a Gallery. However, I need your help to get my work printed on canvas.

Thank you for your consideration and support!


Additional ways you can help.

Besides the funding, you can help us so much by spreading my campaign through mail, facebook or twitter or just simply talk about it. For more information about my work please visit my website.

www.aharivision.com


Thank you!

story:
My daughter and I hit a snag in our living situation, and are going to have to move to a new home by the end of May. 

My landlord, without notice, raised our rent $150 more than we can afford. I'm a single mom, so I am not able to save the money quick enough before May 1st gets here. I don't receive any outside help. And have been forced to live paycheck to paycheck since I'm limited on what hours I can work, so I can get my daughter to and from school. To add to  our misfortune, my daughter broke her arm at school this past September. And the doctor bill to have it fixed made my heart sink. It was more than I could afford. Its been one thing after another. And has been extremely hard to manage to make things work, and to see the light at the end of this pitch black tunnel. But to make a long story short, my rent was raised to push my daughter and I out of our home.

So I want to ask for help in raising $550.00 to help with the cost of the deposit, and the fees for setting up the utilities in a new home. 

I could never ask for something like this without giving something back in return, so I've included perk options to give back in return for all your help!

*If you do not wish to receive these items, donations are greatly appreciated!


Thank you in advance for reading our story, and for all your help! You would be a blessing in our endeavor to find a new hope! The place that we call home.


* Update - 3/26/2015

Thanks to Adem and Stephanie for being the first to help us! And thank you for everyone that immediately jumped in to share the Campaign across the internet! 

As of last night our need for this Campaign to reach it's goal has become our only hope.

 My landlord informed me last night that she has found two people that want to rent out both our rooms for $300/each. She has given us our Official 30 Day Notice. 

The shock of all of this is devastating, and the cross stitching has become my way to handle the anxiety of it all.  I've always paid on time every time, and don't understand why this is happening all of a sudden. But thank you to every single person for the help and compassion for my daughter and I. It means the world to us. I will continue to post updates as things progress. 

Thank you for your compassion, generosity, and understanding in our time of need!

story:
Summary

Hey everyone! My name is John, and I'll soon be a fourth-year participant at Burning Man 2018! By day I'm an automation engineer in the electronics industry, but at night my passion for weird LED projects takes over. 

One of my strange prototypes made it to the 2017 Burn, and after a bit of scaling, it has evolved into a fully-fledged honorarium project! A few tireless friends and I are working to present you: Ring Theory! It is a highly interactive sculpture that melds light, reflective rings, and a gift of your inertia to produce some very neat effects. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

As our team was fortunate to be included among 2018 Honoraria recipients, the Burning Man organization will be giving us a portion of the funds we need to deliver this project. Funding is only partial, however, so we've come up with a plan to get us all the way to the Playa! Our target is to close the $2500 gap in funding. 

In exchange for your support, we are giving you the opportunity to "adopt" one of the 40 orbs that make up this project. Your funds go towards the bill of materials for each unit, and after the event, you will receive the standalone orb you sponsored! We'll be cleaning them up to the best of our abilities, wiring them with a remote control, and then sending them out into the world. 

There are three tiers of orbs -- the 16", 22", and 28". Each one contains a set of rings, addressable LEDs, and a structural hoop. Five of these orbs make up a panel, and Ring Theory will have eight panels in total. 

We have perks available for any budget, so make sure to check them all out! Everyone who donates will also receive access to a very special gallery after the event.

 

The Impact

As some of you may know, most Burning Man projects are entirely community-driven. This effort is what makes this very special event possible. Ring Theory is a chance to get engaged with this amazing culture, pitch in, and bring Black Rock City to life!

 

Meet our amazing team!

 

John

 

 

Rainbow Girl

 

 

Nao

 

 

Ivan

 

Andrew

story:
Introduction
The Temple of Brad Pitt (TOBRIT) is the latest installation by Geodesic Temple that channels the famous Hollywood actor. It captures Brad Pitt’s aura, extracts the essence of his being through data gathering and redisplays it as a data portrait and performative sculpture enabling Burning Man 2019 participants who enter a special apparatus to briefly experience what it is to be him.

This year's installation is the 9th iteration of the Geodesic Temple on playa and the second one to be burnt. A little bit about Geodesic Temple aka GeoTem - it is a modular system that uses the octahedron as a building block to create self-supporting structures. The octahedron, a geodesic polyhedron, is one of the five platonic solids. It has been used through the ages in sacred geometry and spiritual architecture. Geodesic Temple is an expression of the Disorient philosophy: individual cells work together to create the ever-evolving landscape of life.

 

Who we are
Geodesic Temple is a community of dreamers and doers exploring the sacred dimension in sculpture. GeoTem is a modular system that uses the octahedron as a building block to create self-supporting structures. The octahedron, a geodesic polyhedron, is one of the five platonic solids. It has been used through the ages in sacred geometry and spiritual architecture.
 

DISORIENT Collective
Disorient is a sound, visual and performance art collective. We create art projects and art installations with hardware including wood, scaffolding, palette rack, containers, recycled materials, your body, Raspberry Pi, geodesic domes, inflatable structures, video, repurposed objects, black lights and vehicles. We develop software for our installations. Our guiding principles are outlined in the Disorient Model and in the Political Economy of Disorient. 
Disorient is an open creative platform powered by love.

 

All proceeds go towards this installation, TOBRIT . To be effective and environmental friendly there is minimal packaging and we ask that supporters collect their perks at Disorient Camp on the Playa. Please email us at geodesic.temple@gmail.com if you have any questions. 

Sincerely grateful for your support!

story:
Pieces

My name is Christopher Griffin and I am an artist in Ottawa, Canada. Four years ago my studio building was tagged with graffiti. Originally disheartened, I was about to paint it out when I thought I would have fun with it instead. I took a before picture and then I added legs and a head and turned it into a blue pony. I then simply posted both images on social media. Within 24 hours I received 26 000 views. I realized then that I had tapped into something: People have to deal with graffiti on a daily basis and often feel powerless, violated and upset. My blue pony changed the discussion. I didn't obliterate the original graffiti tag, I actually celebrated it. It became a collaboration of two individuals into one visual image.

Most cities and municipalities want graffiti gone. They spend a lot of money to wash it off or paint it out. Both approaches create a brand new blank surface to be tagged once again. My strategy is softer and more respectful and actually claims that specific geographic space on the wall. It is very difficult to tag on top of what I do, simply because it becomes too cluttered. It is easier for the graffiti artist to go elsewhere. It is not a solution, but another way of existing with it.

This past summer I have transformed graffiti in Madrid, Barcelona, Lisbon and Ottawa/Gatineau. I have transformed 100's of graffiti tags and this journey has been documented by Roberta Gal and  Christopher Snow. We will be self publishing a coffee table book designed by Nicole Vallee and written by Stewart Dudley. This book will open eyes to different possibilities for our shared urban environment. 

It will cost more than $14 000 to publish this 120 page 11 1/2" x 8 1/4" coffee table book.  I have set a goal of a lower amount of $8000  in order to not get penalized for missing my target. There are a range of perks from donations of $50 and up with my original artwork and sculptures. Please share this campaign amongst your friends and stay tuned for our book launch! Thank you for your attention and your support of Pieces.

The money raised will go directly to the costs of publishing. I am hoping with this book, I can branch out to other cities worldwide and explore different options of celebrating graffiti. This may be the beginning of a whole new movement in public art.

Please share this project amongst your friends on social media. I am very thankful for your support!

Christopher Griffin

christophergriffin.ca
story_txt: PiecesMy name is Christopher Griffin and I am an artist in Ottawa, Canada. Four years ago my studio building was tagged with graffiti. Originally disheartened, I was about to paint it out when I thought I would have fun with it instead. I took a before picture and then I added legs and a head and turned it into a blue pony. I then simply posted both images on social media. Within 24 hours I received 26 000 views. I realized then that I had tapped into something: People have to deal with graffiti on a daily basis and often feel powerless, violated and upset. My blue pony changed the discussion. I didn't obliterate the original graffiti tag, I actually celebrated it. It became a collaboration of two individuals into one visual image.Most cities and municipalities want graffiti gone. They spend a lot of money to wash it off or paint it out. Both approaches create a brand new blank surface to be tagged once again. My strategy is softer and more respectful and actually claims that specific geographic space on the wall. It is very difficult to tag on top of what I do, simply because it becomes too cluttered. It is easier for the graffiti artist to go elsewhere. It is not a solution, but another way of existing with it.This past summer I have transformed graffiti in Madrid, Barcelona, Lisbon and Ottawa/Gatineau. I have transformed 100's of graffiti tags and this journey has been documented by Roberta Gal and  Christopher Snow. We will be self publishing a coffee table book designed by Nicole Vallee and written by Stewart Dudley. This book will open eyes to different possibilities for our shared urban environment. It will cost more than $14 000 to publish this 120 page 11 1/2" x 8 1/4" coffee table book.  I have set a goal of a lower amount of $8000  in order to not get penalized for missing my target. There are a range of perks from donations of $50 and up with my original artwork and sculptures. Please share this campaign amongst your friends and stay tuned for our book launch! Thank you for your attention and your support of Pieces.The money raised will go directly to the costs of publishing. I am hoping with this book, I can branch out to other cities worldwide and explore different options of celebrating graffiti. This may be the beginning of a whole new movement in public art.Please share this project amongst your friends on social media. I am very thankful for your support!Christopher Griffinchristophergriffin.ca

story:
GUSTBABDEN

Hello! 

We are a small team of independent film makers, based in London. And we need your help! 

Our aim is to re-produce a modern day roman-photo; replacing the photographic still images with moving image, using professional film and post editing techniques. 

Alan Resnais auteur camera work in 'Last year in Marienbad' is a key reference for the photography. We’re obsessed with the French Avant guard, Film Noir and the bold, impactful images of the silent movies of the early twentieth century.

Take our hand, and follow us into a surrealist's painter's feverish tale in which the final blow of an infinite duel is given post-mortem through a mirror... 

GUSTBABDEN;

Umberto Toselli has written our story. 

In which the narrator (THE OLD WOMAN) unravels the mystery behind a Duel that took place with no witnesses. She does this by reading between the lines of the book. Looking at the story with fresh eyes. 

Places the nameless characters against a period backdrop, in the heart of mid nineteenth century England. 

Inspired by the last fatal Duel fought in 1852, a time when a man could be sentenced to death for winning. 

Production Costs

We need £2,500 to make this film! 

We all believe in Gustbabden and want to realize the film. But we need your help! 

We’re looking for investors to help us achieve the production costs. Which we have managed to keep very low due to an incredible core group of friends; DOP's, director's, screen writer's, art department, costume, make-up and wardrobe that have kindly given their time and services for free! 

Our main cost at £1125 is for the camera equipment to make a moving image, roman-photo effect.  

Luckily, our good friend Emily at EMMY LAND (emmyland.com) has given us a bargain price on an ARRI MINI, which is the perfect camera to achieve the look we desire. She’s even offering her time to operate the camera!

Our second cost at £500 is for set build and dressing two key scenes in our film. 

Our DOP and owner of Black Door studios, Samuel Thomas, is a core member of the team and is kindly giving his studio for free. 

That is where we intend to build the sets. Samuel's in house set builder, Simon is giving his time for free also!

Our Third cost at £150 is food for the 3 days of shooting. Our good friend Paul has offered to cook up a storm for the production at a low cost for 10 members of crew.

Our Fourth cost at £200 is for travel. This will cover any courier costs in production, ferrying crew and cast to the locations at Pergola Hill from our production base in Golders Green.

Our Fifth cost at £300 is for Film festival entry. We have several festivals in mind. Each costing approximately £150 entry fee (We'd like to enter Gustbabden into at least two festivals). 

Which leaves £225 in the pot for emergencies!

MAKING GUSTBABDEN A REALITY

Even the smallest contribution will make a huge difference to the production.

Please share GUSTBABDEN!

Even if you can't pledge towards the productions costs, you can alway just spread the word about GUSTBABDEN in your circles. 
Maybe some of your friends might back us... 
Maybe one day we can do more than just have a drink, we can perhaps have lunch.
Are you a budding film maker? Looking for on set experiences? 
Maybe you'd like to help us on the GUSTBABDEN production?

story:
Too Late Summary

Too late will explore that of a young man named Anthony who is willing to stop at nothing to help his sister out financially. There is only one problem. Anthony is a wrongly convicted felon who has no hopes of getting a decent job. What does he do now? Time is ticking. 

  • Too late is a story that reflects what is going on right now in america and a story I wanted to tell, to help shine light on those who's lives are corrupted by the criminal justice system.
  • My campaign is important to me because it allows me touch and speak to people through my art. I truly believe that compelling stories are what help change the world. 
  • By contributing you will help bring me one step closer to graduating, and changing the world through art. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • I currently need $2000 dollars for the film. The $2000 will cover everything needed for production including props, costumes, film equipment, and location.
  • Donating towards this film I feel is a way of giving back to the community. This film is a reflection on contributors investment in me as an artist.
  • Any little bit that is donated will go straight to production. Any excess amount of money will be put towards the film festivals and competing worldwide. 

The Impact

  • This project is very valuable to me as an artist because it allows me a voice in this world, and with that voice I get the opportunity to make a difference.

Risks & Challenges

  • There are no risks. Everything donated will be put towards the film and bring me one step closer to telling a story that is very dear to my heart.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word.
  • Help share this campaign with others. 

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Konferencja larpowa (“KOLA”), ze swoją sześcioletnią tradycją na stałe wpisała się w życie polskiego środowiska larpowego. “KOLA” jest miejscem, w którym organizatorzy, twórcy i gracze wymieniają się wiedzą i doświadczeniem. Tutaj ogłaszane są najnowsze projekty i inicjatywy larpowe, promuje się najnowsze trendy.  Tegoroczna edycja jest już 8 w historii “KOLI”. Przewidujemy na niej ponad 100 uczestników oraz gości polskich, a także zagranicznych.

Tradycyjnie, udział w KOLI jest bezpłatny dla uczestników. Dzięki temu pozostaje ona możliwie otwarta na wszystkich uczestników. Bardzo zależy nam na utrzymaniu tego aspektu, stwarza on jednak organizacyjne wyzwania. Mimo współpracy z partnerami, organizacja konferencji wymaga pewnych wydatków. Koszt sali na afterparty, napojów dla prelegentów, bufetu z kawą i ciasteczkami składają się na konkretny budżet. Nie za wysoki, ale jednak trudny do sfinansowania ze środków stowarzyszenia larpowego jakim jest Argos. Dlatego zwracamy się do środowiska larpowego z prośba o pomoc.

Dla sfinansowania KOLI uruchomimy akcję crowdfundingową, za pośrednictwem której każdy chętny będzie mógł wesprzeć konferencję. Pomogli nam tu organizatorzy kilku doskonałych polskich larpów, oferując bilety które stały się nagrodami w naszej akcji. Dzięki temu możesz jednocześnie pomóc sfinansować KOLĘ, jak i zaopatrzyć się w bilet na ulubioną grę!


Nasi partnerzy:

story:
Hey Everybody!

I'm starting up this campaign to get my first shirt manufactured for you guys to wear fashionably. This will also be a big head start to get myself up and going and start selling awesome artwork and pushing my business even further. 

For almost about a year, I've always had this idea in mind of making an Animal Crossing print all over shirt, but never got around to finishing the drawing. Finally I was able to finish it a couple weeks ago and thought of making it into a collared shirt. I worked really hard to finish this and get samples in which was a pain in the butt.

With your guy's support it'll help cover the expenses  of the production and freight. I am looking for at least 50 people, or potentially even more, that are willing to want to get their hands on these suckers because I got to limit 50 pieces max. Once I affirm orders, I'll let the manufacture know how many sizes and quantity I need to get the shirts made for you guys. 

Thank you once again for your incredible support and help me make my clothing into a reality!

 

Contact Information:

  • xepherchild@gmail.com
  • instagram.com/absentdays.us

story:
Why I'm running this campaign

I am a contemporary visual artist who has been given the opportunity to create a public bronze sculpture for one of the lawns at Sandham Memorial Chapel, a National Trust property in Burghclere that is famous for its cycle of paintings by Stanley Spencer. 

This sculpture would be part of the exhibition Of geometry and gods, side by side which will take place from 8th to 26th April 2020 when I'll be showing my work alongside a number of stone carvings by the sculptor and architect James Dunnett.

This is a exciting opportunity for me as it would mean I could create my first ever large scale sculpture and install it at a historic location.

The foundry costs involved are £3,960. I am preparing my application to Arts Council England for funding however they expect at least 10% to come from other sources. A higher percentage will improve my chance of success. I am therefore seeking 50% of the foundry costs, i.e. £1,980 via this campaign.

So far I have produced a series of studies that suggest what the finished sculpture would look like. To see those, and find out more about the ideas behind my work, please watch the short video.

Ways to help and get rewarded

If you would like to help you can choose from seven different levels of support and each has an associated 'perk'. In return for your level of support a special reward will be yours by way of thanks.

Why this campaign matters

My artistic training was in painting and printmaking but in recent years I have been getting more ideas that need to be explored in three dimensions.  So far I have made some small sculptures in clay and plaster and I was further encouraged when earlier this year one of my ceramic reliefs was selected for the Creekside Open by Sacha Craddock.

If this opportunity goes ahead it would mean I could get valuable experience of working with the foundry technician to create the mould ready for casting. If you watch the video you can see shots of what processes are involved.

Risks & challenges

The creation of the bronze is a mini-project inside the main exhibition project that will need careful planning. It is therefore important that I can confirm my level of funding by the end of November to allow enough time for the application to the Art Council as it has a six week review cycle.  I have previously been awarded funding so I know success is possible.

Other ways you can help

If you aren't able to support directly please use the Indiegogo tools to share with friends, family and anyone you know who you think might be interested.

Thank you very much.

The Team

story:
Third Eye Wide Collective presents the Painted Foot Project

 

TAME THE MIND ~ LIBERATE YOUR SOUL ~ BE YOU

THIRD EYE WIDE is a collective of artists, creators, healers, yogis, learners, and other creative beings. We provide opportunities to embark on a journey of deep self-discovery, release, healing, and authentic self-expression.

Our intent with the PFP, as is with all our creative endeavours as a collective, is to build community and connection, deepen awareness and understanding of the Self, and allow for thoughtless expression and healing release. We want to empower people to get in touch with their own creative power and let it flow into and through them. This project allows you to play with your inner child, engage in deep levels of self-expression and connection, and encourages ecstatic emotional release. 

This event is simple in action - get barefoot, paint your feet, and DANCE - but it is rich in experience.

By facilitating an event where you can immerse yourself in music and vibrations and express it with color and movement, we provide not only a fun outlet for people to dance, but also an opportunity to engage in a social-science-art experiment! Do the different types of music provoke different themes and feelings within the finished canvas artwork? How about the environment? Are people drawn to different colors or dance differently at different events? We can't wait to find out!

We are extraordinarily excited to launch our first event, which will take place on May 4th, 2018 at the Fairie Festival in Pennsylvania. But, we cannot do it without your help!  We do everything on a volunteer basis and want to ensure the quality of all the products we use - from the paint and canvas to the cleaning wipes - to optimize the finished product and experience for everyone. After the event, we will be sending everyone who donated photos and videos of the creation, as well as an update on future PFP events.

Join us in the journey as we connect to the music, our bodies, and each other. We release and we CREATE!

 

Our Budget

We've taken the time to break down the costs for this event so you know exactly where your contribution is going:

  • Canvas (20' x 20') - $90 on Amazon
  • Paint (acrylic) - $250 on Amazon
  • Plastic paint trays - $20
  • Streamers and Tikki torches to demarcate space - $25
  • Tarps for under canvas and shoes/cleanup - $60
  • Stakes for canvas and tarp - $10
  • Baby Wipes - $30
  • Paper Towels - $20
  • Spray bottles with soap and water - $25
  • Trash bags - $12
  • Transportation - $35

Keep in mind, Indiegogo takes a percentage of what we raise overall as well as a portion of each credit card donation, so we gave ourselves about $100 of wiggle room when figuring out our fundraising goal.

 

Contact Info

​If you want to learn more about the PFP project, Third Eye Wide Collective, or the people behind it, you can go to www.3iwide.com. For any questions, you can email us at thirdeyewide3@gmail.com. Please follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/thirdeyewideart and Instagram @thirdeyewideart.

story:
UPDATE!

In under 24 hours you guys did it! Thank you SO MUCH for helping. Sylv really appreciates it, as do I. You're the best!

All art shown was painted by Sylv.

Short Summary

My wife and I are disabled artists - I was born with a birth defect and am in a wheelchair, and my wife has severe auto-immune issues and is legally blind. She is able to create art digitally by working on a tablet screen with her face only a few inches away. Her current laptop is on its last legs, is past its warranty, and fairly outdated besides. I'm trying to put together funds to get her a Lenovo Thinkpad - a tablet-screen laptop capable of heavy-duty processing for art software. The laptop is also her only real link to the outside world as her health issues have left her housebound since 1999. You can see a portfolio of her work at http://somnambule.deviantart.com/. Once she's back up and running, she'll be coloring my covers for my Image book.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is very simple and specific - I will use the funds to purchase her a new laptop: a Lenovo Thinkpad with 16GB of RAM and a 500GB hard drive.  I addition to knowing you've helped someone in need, I am offering artistic services as perks. My wife's health is too fragile to guarantee set delivery dates on art, hence my stepping in and providing the perks. 

I am a professional caricature and comic book artist - I draw with my mouth - and have been doing caricatures for over 20 years. I have a comic book series coming out from Image/Top Cow in November, but won't see royalties (if any!) until the new year, and I'm concerned that her current laptop won't last that long.

Contributors can get caricatures, portraits, and even comic book script and art portfolio critiques.

The Impact

You will be, simply put, keeping my wife's connection to the outside world alive, and helping her to once again create art as a healing process. We live below the poverty line, and there's no way that I could buy her this laptop myself before the new year. I'd hoped to be able to wait until then, but her current laptop is dying, and it probably won't make it.

I have several successful Kickstarters that helped me get my comic book deal, and a successful Indie Go Go campaign that helped me upgrade my own computer equipment last year and pay a few bills. I'm very transparent and keep in regular communication with my contributors, and have built a reputation for honesty.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by spreading the word and letting your friends and online communities know about the campaign. Signal boosting is greatly appreciated!
story_txt:
UPDATE!
In under 24 hours you guys did it! Thank you SO MUCH for helping. Sylv really appreciates it, as do I. You're the best!
All art shown was painted by Sylv.
Short Summary
My wife and I are disabled artists - I was born with a birth defect and am in a wheelchair, and my wife has severe auto-immune issues and is legally blind. She is able to create art digitally by working on a tablet screen with her face only a few inches away. Her current laptop is on its last legs, is past its warranty, and fairly outdated besides. I'm trying to put together funds to get her a Lenovo Thinkpad - a tablet-screen laptop capable of heavy-duty processing for art software. The laptop is also her only real link to the outside world as her health issues have left her housebound since 1999. You can see a portfolio of her work at http://somnambule.deviantart.com/. Once she's back up and running, she'll be coloring my covers for my Image book.



What We Need & What You Get
This campaign is very simple and specific - I will use the funds to purchase her a new laptop: a Lenovo Thinkpad with 16GB of RAM and a 500GB hard drive.  I addition to knowing you've helped someone in need, I am offering artistic services as perks. My wife's health is too fragile to guarantee set delivery dates on art, hence my stepping in and providing the perks. 
I am a professional caricature and comic book artist - I draw with my mouth - and have been doing caricatures for over 20 years. I have a comic book series coming out from Image/Top Cow in November, but won't see royalties (if any!) until the new year, and I'm concerned that her current laptop won't last that long.

The Impact
