story:
Short Summary

GUEST BY COURTESY is an original performance developed by Jenny Larson – artistic director of Salvage Vanguard Theater – and Hannah Kenah – company member, performer, and writer for the Rude Mechs. Original music was composed by Graham Reynolds, who performs live when possible.

GUEST BY COURTESY portrays the mangled story of a pair of cousins waging their bizarre relationship over the course of a failing afternoon tea. Using high physicality, sharp language, and sheer vulgarity, the show plumbs the comedic depths of duration and desperation. 

GUEST BY COURTESY has, thus far, delighted audiences in Texas and in Eastern Europe. We aim to add Brooklyn to that esteemed list. The show premiered in Austin in 2011 at the Salvage Vanguard Theater. GBC was then selected for the 2013 Fusebox Festival, an awesome contemporary performance festival that takes place in Austin every April and draws in work from around the world. For our Fusebox Festival run, we performed in a Masonic lodge - our absurd, feminist work entertained full houses and the portraits of ancient, dead men that surrounded us. The most incredible and surreal piece of the map fell into place when, in the fall of 2013, our team traveled to Sofia, Bulgaria as part of an artist exchange with the University of Sofia. There we performed the show in the opulent arms of the former royal palace turned National Art Gallery. 

Our map is not complete. We want more entries. 
Next stop, Brooklyn!!!

Kenah, Larson, and their amazing third-partner-in-crime Jason Hays will take their comedy to an East Bed-Stuy living room. Presented by the Brooklyn Yard, July 23rd- 30th 2016. http://www.brooklynyard.org/

The Brooklyn Yard is generously producing the show but the creative team needs help paying for airfare and housing. 

What We Need 

  • $1000 to pay for three airline tickets to get Kenah, Larson, and Jason Hays to Brooklyn. 
  • $2000 to rent an airbnb apartment for the two week run.

What You Get

Perks are listed on the right side of the screen --> gifts for your contribution can include tickets to Kenah and Larson's next collaboration WITH GREAT DIFFICULTY ALICE SITS, drink tickets, fancy party passes, and a handwritten letter from your favorite GUEST BY COURTESY cousin.


What if we exceed our fundraising goal? 

If we are lucky enough to exceed our goal of $3,000, we will use any additional funds in the following order of priorities:

First and Foremost, if we raise an additional $1,000 (making our grand total $4,000) we will bring Graham Reynolds on board for two or three shows where he will play the score live! Dreamy! If this becomes a reality, we will advertise far and wide what nights he'll be playing.

Secondarily, we will provide Jason, Jenny, and Hannah with per diem and artist stipends.



A few things people have had to say about the show:

"Kenah has a steely, wicked energy and a lovely Bacall growl, and Larson's shifts from uptight shop-girl to WWF harpy are straight-up dazzling. Their bravura turns are what makes Guest by Courtesy smart, explosive, and --dare I say it?--ballsy." -The Austinist

“Larson and Kenah, with perfect comic timing and tempo, keep us laughing for a good solid hour” – Austin Chronicle

"Hannah Kenah and Jenny Larson have a natural chemistry onstage. Their ease of expression is apparent" -Austin American Statesman


"The writing rang wild, clear, and exceptionally funny. All the movement was terrifically staged and played. " -Deborah Hay, choreographer 


Other Ways You Can Help

-Airline miles

-Tell your New York friends to see the show!

-Do you know someone who needs a house sitter July 18th- 31st in Brooklyn? 

Contact jenny@salvagevanguard.org if you can help with any of the above. 

Thanks friends!

story: Seattle Performance Collective is a dance and music collaboration. Fourteen local  artists join forces for one summer to expose the Seattle community to an interdisciplinary arts experience. Our goal is to create a series of performances that will be presented at three outdoor Seattle locations. The music will be improvised; providing a different experience for each performance. This project features musical guest Daniel Mullikin. Daniel's experimental approach to cello includes a mixture of industrial classicism and hip urban beats. The dance will be choreographed by Alicia Garcia and will also feature several improvisational scores. Alicia's aesthetic is heavily weighted, momentum driven, and emotional. Local dance film artist Kelsey Murphy will be recording the process and creating several short dance films that will be available to the public via the internet. Our shows will be free to audiences and in public spaces, making it easy for those who are not normally exposed to dance and music to attend our performances. All contributions will be used towards performance production and artist payment. You can also contribute by sharing our page with others and attending our performances July 19, 20, 21, times and locations TBA. Please help us immerse the Seattle community in collaborative art forms. We greatly appreciate any and all support. Thank you!

story:
Inspiration, Motivation, Determination, Commitment = Realization.

I have been to Black Rock City, or Burning Man, for the last 5 years in a row. Not an easy trip coming from Bali, Indonesia, but it has always been way worth any effort. I go for the dust (not really), the friendships I've forged, the spectacle, and the art. Being a Bali based artist I am always fascinated at what the desert has in store, and it never ceases to amaze me. And for a number of years I have been wanting to give back to Burning Man, in the form of art on the Playa. Then late last year I was inspired. Inspired by this friends family photo.

The fun and emotions shown, got me and got me good. I thought, wouldn't it be amazing to replicate those emotions, and create that moment at Burning Man. Wouldn't it be awesome to build an actual size static wooden roller coaster on the Playa. You climb the stairs and enter one of the cars. The lead car has a big red button at the front, when all are seated and ready it's pushed, a 15 second sound-byte starts over the speaker system, "clack clack clack, whoosh whoosh, scream scream", getting riders in the mood, ending in, BEEP BEEP BEEEEEEP, when a camera captures that moment, to remember that dusty moment forever. Dusty smiles.

Imagine. Well that's what I did. Couldn't stop. Thoughts started growing outside my head. I started running my idea by like minded friends and their response was always the same, awesome, great idea, very Burning Man, do it. Do it? Alright, I will.

Needing to start somewhere I contacted Charlie, an architect friend of mine with the intention of asking him a few simple questions, was it possible, what would it cost, how would it be it made, how long would it take, where would I start, to name a few. We arranged a meeting, a sunset drink to hash it out. And that's when serendipity called, because at that meeting I also met Neil Thomas. I was to later find out that Neils London based company Atelier One, is the structural engineering firm responsible for world renowned Gardens by the Bay in Singapore, Cloud Gate in Chicago and has handled some of the biggest U2, Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd tours, among many other incredible projects. Charlie and Neil loved the idea. We bounced ideas, drew plans in the sand, and talked like it was happening. Neil especially took a shining to the concept, offering his services to help achieve this....

Above are his services. That was the start. And after that first meeting, there was no turning back. I was building a roller coaster. That's why I am sitting here, 6 months down the track, writing this. People were putting time energy and money into this project. It needed follow through. Commitment. I needed a team, and if Burning Man was good for only one thing, its forging life long friendships with like minded people. I now knew carpenters, builders, riggers, sound guys, electricians, lighting techs, artistic and construction types. And it wasn't long before I had a committed team of dust lovin', hard working, burn lovers, who are excited as I am to be fulfilling this dream.

This is important to me because I started this emotional roller coaster. It is important because we have been working on this all year, every day, on some aspect. It is important to not let people down. It is important because I would like to think that in this day and age, people are still willing to contribute for fun, and life's not all doom and gloom. And mostly, it is important to dream and to prove dreams can be achieved and goals can be attained.

Since the beginning I had a picture in my head. It is a line of people standing in the desert sun, laughing, chatting, happily waiting their turn to have their moment, their emotional moment up on the coaster. And if funded, I believe this will become the reality. I really do.

Imagine, SURPRISE - of first seeing An Emotional Roller Coaster on the playa, JOY - of riding up to it, FEAR - of seeing what's involved, EXCITEMENT - of participation, DISGUST - of the having to wait your turn, CONTEMPT of others getting a better photo, and the SADNESS - of having to leave.
An Emotional Roller Coaster promises to bring back old and make new emotions.

This dream will only be made possible through your generosity in funding and our dedication to bringing this incredible art to Burning Man.

What We Need & What You Get = Money & A Roller Coaster

As simple as the plan may seem, this project costs money, and lots of time and effort from many. Over 100 people have at some stage already put valuable input in regarding the sourcing, buying, building, transporting, lighting, powering, storing and camera and sound aspects involved. Dozens of people have been spending countless hours for a dream. And now comes the crunch. Now comes the countdown. The core crew is primed and ready, every one hand picked for specific tasks, with the ability to achieve this crazy roller coaster.

The wooden trestle roller coaster aspect of the project is being pre-built late July in Nor Cal. The roller coaster vehicles are being made in Reno, and the other components, lighting, power, sound and signage are heading from L.A. to Black Rock City 20 Aug, for the on-site build.

While the biggest challenge now is funding, the biggest risk is under funding. In the event of the project under funded, depending on the amount received, will depend on the size of the dream achieved. Funds will determine the size and scope of An Emotional Roller Coaster. If funding  meets budget, expect all the bells and whistles. We will do whatever it takes to make this happen and some. Believe us, we have lists of emotional ideas to choose from and implement. If funding doesn't meet budget but will cover the basic wooden trestle coaster, coaster cars and lighting, (the bare minimum to achieve this this project this year), then that's what we will do, 150% bare minimum, as things can  be added on in the coming years. If funding does not reach the bare minimum, funds will be set aside, untouched, and we will apply for the 2020 Burning Man Honoraria Art Grant, which depending again, hopefully will bring us up to speed.

I am donating beautiful arty incentives from my Bali store, SKULL, for different tiered pledges, and special promotions.

Due to project fulfillment being priority, I will not be making any of the perks mentioned until after the Burn, so...Oct. Due to the nature of some of the perks, please understand that these things take time. I hope to have all delivered early 2020.

You can see my art work on insta @rhetttttro

Or check my store to see what I do,  https://www.skullbali.com/

You can keep up to date on the blog https://www.anemotionalrollercoaster.com/

And I will be updating news here as we progress.

Lasting Impact

There is no intention to burn An Emotional Roller Coaster. This project has been designed for longevity. All components have been selected for durability. The plan is to bring An Emotional Roller Coaster back to the Playa every year. Build, dismantle, store, repeat. We are currently looking at storing in Carson City, being cheaper than Reno, and that means we don't have to lug everything back over the Sierra Nevada's. The facade and cars can be easily modified to help support the annual Burning Man theme. And we will have a slew of fresh options for emotional interaction, to be poured into the mix.

Risks & Challenges

The main obstacle is financial. The other obstacle foreseen is time, however, close as the 2019 burn is, we still believe this project is possible. If funded, it's full steam ahead, we got this.

To be honest, there are many obstacles, however, like we have done in the past, we will overcome them through teamwork and dedication to the goal. Between us all, we have created numerous playa projects over the years from art cars to theme camps. We are prepared to meet and tackle any obstacles. Feel free to ask any questions

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't help. Pls use the Indiegogo share tools on the link. We need to make some serious noise and the only way to do that is to share share share this campaign.

Thanking you kindly

Peace

RHETT and Are You Fucking Shitting Me, (the Emotional Roller Coaster core crew)

story:
EVERY $1 WILL BE MATCHED (up to $4,000) BY THE ROI COMMUNITY!


Our Story

Jews in ALL Hues (JIAH) was founded by Jared Jackson in Philadelphia. We are  an education and advocacy nonprofit organization that supports multiple-heritage Jews (Adoptees, Jews by choice, Jews with intermarried parents, and Jews of Color) in the creation of sustainably-diverse communities. Our goal is to build a future for the Jewish community where a person’s heritage is never a barrier to acceptance or integration

Jews in ALL Hues is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization. Everyone will receive a receipt for the tax-deductible amount for any donation. 

.

Our Impact

Over 50% of Jewish millennials are adoptees, Jews by choice, children of intermarried parents, and/or Jews of Color. We know that there are many communities in which diversity is a major priority, yet are seeking better tools for a sustainable impact. Our programs have helped many multi-heritage Jews build a stronger connection to the Jewish people, and helped communities better accept and integrate diversity.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $10,000 to build ground-breaking Jewish diversity curricula that will equip Jewish communities in North America (synagogues, havurot, Hillel, outreach organizations, independent) with the  BEST tools to greatly improve their ability to welcome of Jews from all backgrounds. 

Your donations will fund:

Pilot sessions - testing, improving, and perfecting our menu of workshops and training seminars

New Jewish diversity media - videos, website, podcasts etc.

Consultants and staff - bringing in some of the greatest minds so we will be as effective as possible in achieving real change in American Jewish communities.

You will get a chance to really make a positive impact on the future of the Jewish people. Checkout our perks for more information! 

Other Ways You Can Help


Share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, email, text message, and personal Phone Calls! Make sure that everyone who wants diversity to thrive in the Jewish community gets the message. Ask us about our volunteer opportunities. It doesn't matter where you are, there's always something you can do to help.  And don't forget about the sharing buttons!

.


Our Impact
Over 50% of Jewish millennials are adoptees, Jews by choice, children of intermarried parents, and/or Jews of Color. We know that there are many communities in which diversity is a major priority, yet are seeking better tools for a sustainable impact. Our programs have helped many multi-heritage Jews build a stronger connection to the Jewish people, and helped communities better accept and integrate diversity.





What We Need & What You Get
We need $10,000 to build ground-breaking Jewish diversity curricula that will equip Jewish communities in North America (synagogues, havurot, Hillel, outreach organizations, independent) with the  BEST tools to greatly improve their ability to welcome of Jews from all backgrounds. 
Your donations will fund:
Pilot sessions - testing, improving, and perfecting our menu of workshops and training seminars
New Jewish diversity media - videos, website, podcasts etc.
Consultants and staff - bringing in some of the greatest minds so we will be as effective as possible in achieving real change in American Jewish communities.
You will get a chance to really make a positive impact on the future of the Jewish people. Checkout our perks for more information! 







Other Ways You Can Help




Share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, email, text message, and personal Phone Calls! Make sure that everyone who wants diversity to thrive in the Jewish community gets the message. Ask us about our volunteer opportunities. It doesn't matter where you are, there's always something you can do to help.  And don't forget about the sharing buttons!

story:
A comic book about suicidal ideation

My name is Trishelle Jeffery. I've spent my life struggling with mental health issues and drawing comics about it.

I'm working on a book that takes an autobiographical approach to the question, "How many parallel universes exist in which I am dead?" The plot focuses on multiverse theory, and how that can relate to things we think about doing but don't act on. The book is intended for mature audiences.

It will be made with roughly 30 pages of fine art printing, all done by hand. I will be printing and binding the edition of books myself at Constellation Studios in Nebraska during a residency I'm doing at the end of the summer.

This fundraiser is a way for you to pre-order this book, which will be printed in an edition reflecting how many people order it.

For me, for you

The money I earn in this campaign will largely go to studio fees for Constellation Studios and travel. I will also use these funds to purchase supplies, including paper, book board, binding thread, and matrices to print from.

The book will be printed as a limited edition, reflecting orders. So if you order one, a book will be made, just for you. I will not be printing any more than what is ordered. There will be no more printed after this, and no possibility to buy the physical handmade book in any other way.

Former work

I'm currently pursuing my MFA in Print Media at Wichita State University. Between receiving my undergraduate degree and moving to Kansas for Grad school, I did a residency at the Book Arts Program at the University of Utah in 2013. For that residency, I made a much smaller book piece.

Some of my previously published comics appeared in SLUG Magazine and Grayhaven Comics' anti bullying anthology You Are Not Alone 2. My art has shown in exhibitions at the Utah Museum of Contemporary Art, in the Ulrich Museum, and various other spaces. My work has been exhibited alongside internationally famous artists such as Matthew Barney and Felix Gonzalez-Torres. You can see some of the work I've done over the past few years at my website, trishellejeffery.com.

How you can help

There is an option to purchase a PDF of the book, for those that can only provide minimal support.

Regardless of what you decide to buy or not, please help spread the word!

story:
We are pleased to announce a special night of premieres in Brooklyn on December 9,
plus a new CD and video! 

**A NOTE ABOUT SUPPORTING US THROUGH THIS SITE:
Indiegogo fills in a default amount of $100 when you click Back It in the upper right corner of this page.  We are working on fixing this.  So please know that you can donate any amount you wish and that we are not expecting minimum donations of $100.  Our suggested donation is $20, which is about the price of a ticket.  (Of course, if you would like to give us more, we won't say no!)

Thanks!  Now onto the interesting stuff:

On December 9, James Ilgenfritz and Sarah Krasnow's newest collaboration, I Looked At The Eclipse, premieres at Roulette.  This new opera blends video, theater, language games, free improvisation, and chamber music.  Using a solar eclipse as a metaphor for a widespread epidemic of problematic human interactions that range from the mundane to predatory, the work is a surreal vision of self-regulation in a society obsessed with shifting culpability and consequence.

The December 9 concert will also feature James's band Anagram Ensemble, performing the New York premiere of In The Summer Every Truth Is Like A Saturday.  James wrote this piece for the Vienna-based ensemble Studio Dan, and it received its world premiere at Ostrava Days 2019 in the Czech Republic. 

And finally, December 9 will include the world premiere of Federico Garcia De Castro's Themuru and a performance of James's Terminal Affirmative from Pauline Kim Harris and Alex Cohen.  To see a teaser video of Terminal Affirmative, beautifully shot by Yuri Zupancic, click the image above.

**CONCERT DETAILS:**
DECEMBER 9, 2019, 8PM AT ROULETTE 509 ATLANTIC AVE., BROOKLYN
Click here for tickets and more info: https://roulette.org/event/the-anagram-ensemble...

Terminal Affirmative is the opening piece on James's new album, You Scream A Rapid Language.  The album also features the violin duo String Noise (Pauline Kim Harris and Conrad Harris) performing Fanfares For Modest Accomplishments, as well as two works in James's Apophenia series. Apophenia III: The Index features violinist Jennifer Choi, pianist Kathleen Supové, and guitarist James Moore (playing through a Talk Box), and is based on a short story by experimental fiction writer JG Ballard.  Apophenia IV: A Bell In Every Finger was premiered earlier this year, and features William Winant, Joseph Kubera, and Thomas Buckner, singing poetry by Steve Dalachinsky about Cecil Taylor and Muhal Richard Abrams (the subtitle "A Bell In Every Finger" refers to Muhal's statement that Kubera plays as though he has "a bell in every finger"). The weekend Steve Dalachinsky passed away, James was finalizing the edits of this recording.  Since then, the outpouring of attention to Steve's work is a testament to how much Steve and his wife, artist and poet Yuko Otomo, mean to the artistic community.

The piece at the center of this album (and at the center of the new opera to be performed December 9) is How To Talk To Your Children About Not Looking At The Eclipse, performed by flutist Margaret Lancaster.  To purchase the album, please follow this link:
 https://infrequentseams.bandcamp.com/album/you-...

We hope you can join us at Roulette, purchase a copy of You Scream A Rapid Language, or support us with a donation.  We are honored to be able to share these works with you!

story:
WHO WE ARE



Anthony Benedetto is an award-winning illustrator and designer with works ranging from book covers to music packaging, and from movie posters to children’s books. Anthony studied at Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design and graduated with a BFA in Illustration.

Courtland Urbano is a highly recognized composer, music producer, and sound designer who has produced music for over fifteen studio records. He is a founding member of the group Beautiful Eulogy, and has also composed musical scores and sound design for a variety of commercial clients.

 

WHAT WE'VE DONE



We’ve been close friends for the last 13 years and the two of us have been operating as freelance artists for the last 8 years. In 2010 Courtland was signed with Humble Beast as a recording artist and in-house producer. Humble Beast is an influential ministry that bridges the gap between theology and creativity through music, and gospel-centered resources. In 2014, Anthony took the job of Creative Director for Humble Beast to oversee all of the visual aspects for the label/ministry.

For the last 4 years we have been working together at Humble Beast to create a wide range of art forms. We have worked on album packaging, apparel design, music videos, short films, photography, branding, web design, animation, book covers, poster art, illustration, musical scores, sound design, album production, social media campaigns, live events, and the list goes on and on. While working for Humble Beast, the two of us were also offering these same services for other companies as freelancers. We have been fortunate to work for a variety of great clients including Blue Moon, Red Bull, Adobe, Invisible Creature, Crossway, Moody Publishers, B&H Publishing Group, BF Goodrich, Arrow Electronics, Jordan, and more.

See some of Anthony’s work at: anthonymbenedetto.com
See some of Courtland’s work at: @courtlandurbano 

 

WHAT WE'RE DOING NOW



The fact is, we work really well together. And because we have such a great friendship, and creative connection, we were like, “Let’s start a studio!” So we decided to build a company where we can continue to combine our abilities. We have given all of this much thought and we have been taking all of the necessary steps to start up a business like this. We have decided to call our studio NOVA NIMBUS (more explanation on our name to come).

NOVA NIMBUS will be a multi-disciplinary studio creating illustration, design, film scoring, sound design, and more for our clients, but we will also be creating our own original works independently, such as films, animation, fine art prints, music and merchandise. We are certain this is what we need to do with our lives. Both of us feel that we have been made to make art for the world, and whether that is in the commercial or independent realms we feel like NOVA NIMBUS will help us to do that.

 

WHAT WE NEED


We’ve already started the process and created our branding, and we’re currently building our website. We have registered our company through the state of Oregon, set up an accounting system, and established our banking. But, starting a business is difficult and although we’ve done a lot already, we need your help to get it off the ground.

We are raising money to help us cover our first year of overhead.

The money raised in this campaign will be used for our recurring monthly expenses. If we reach our goal, we will be covered for a full year of business!

These expenses include:

Studio Lease (we’re currently set up in Courtland’s home)
Utilities
Insurance
Software
Internet
Email
Website
Misc. Bills
*Any money raised above our goal will go to updating our current equipment. 

Many companies begin with some initial investment to get started, and we find ourselves in need of some financial backing to do just that. Your support will help us to cover these expenses and will also allow us to focus on establishing relationships and contracted work with clients while taking care of our families. We do not want anything to come to us without effort and hard work, and both of us have worked very hard to cultivate and put to use our talents. Please consider helping us start NOVA NIMBUS!


HOW YOU CAN HELP


Since we’re starting a creative company, we thought, we should create something!

MODERN ROMANTICISM

Anthony has illustrated an original fine art print titled, “Modern Romanticism”. This illustration was created to celebrate the beauty of the Oregon landscape, our love of mid-century modern aesthetic, and the wonder our imaginations produce. We wanted to give you guys a taste of what we love and hopefully bring a bit of that into your space. Shipping of the print is included and each print comes with a 1” border to make framing easier.





GLASS CLOAK

Courtland has compiled a selection of his unreleased instrumentals and we’ve titled it, “Glass Cloak”. This album is a 19-song collection of rare tracks that he's produced over the years, some of which have never been heard before. We’ve put this album together to give you guys an experience of the varying range of soundscapes he creates. We love to listen to instrumentals while we work and play and we thought you would too!




We feel that these perks are fitting because they are a meshing of our audio and visual palette and a foretaste of what we hope to produce as a company.


PERKS

 

SAY WORD!


We understand that not everyone can contribute financially, so please help us get the word out and share this with your friends and family.

We appreciate you guys and we’re looking forward to what lies ahead!
